description:
Great place! I got a set of pork siu Mai, shrimp dumplings, sticky rice with chicken, char siu Bao, custard bao & red bean puff and thousand egg puff for $16.6 total! What a great price.
I love their siu mai and shrimp dumplings. Their char siu bao was huge but with little fillings. It's understandable given the price, but personally I would prefer having the size smaller so that the pork-bun ratio would be better.
I was hungry so I started eating part of my take-away food in store. The staff was very nice that she came over to offer a better soy sauce and chatted with me. I told her I came from NY and she asked me about housing in NY. I complained about the Wall Street people pushing the rent & sale market high while she accused the local tech people for the same thing haha! It was such a fun and informative conversation. She was so friendly and considerate. Would love to come back!
author: Tian G.

description:
The dim sum here is the best deal out of any restaurant in Chinatown. For only $10, I got a plate of shrimp dumplings, pork shumai, radish cakes, beef rice noodle rolls, and lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice. The service is super nice and fast, so even if there is a line, you will still get your food quickly. 

The shrimp dumplings and pork shumai were packed with meat which surprised me because the price was so low. They were full of flavor, the meat was nice and juicy, and the wrapping was chewy and soft. The radish cakes were the best deal because they were cheap, huge, and extremely filling.

The beef rice noodle rolls were delicious and had a ton of flavor from the beef and green onion. The menu says one roll is $2 but the lady gave me three rolls, so I don't know but I'm not complaining. My favorite item was probably the lotus leaf sticky rice. There was so much stuff inside the sticky rice so it had a bunch of flavor. The lotus leaf added a nice floral tea flavor and smell. The sticky rice was soft and chewy which contrasted well with the texture from the meat inside. 

You have to come and try this place if you like dim sum. It is actually the cheapest and one of the best dim sum places.
author: Shao-Lon Y.

description:
Very fortunate there wasn't a long line for this place this go around.  My wife and I always make it a point to come here each time we are in the Bay area to get some no fuss, no frills, cheap authentic dim sum to go.  

This time, we just opted for an order (one order = 3 pieces) of the Chiu Zhou Dumplings and they were a little disappointing.  The filling was very hot and flavorful but the skin was just a tad bit too thick for my liking.  

Therefore, my 4 star rating is indicative of what I have had in the past and I will just deem this one poor experience as an aberration.
author: Johnny N.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The food is cheap, but that's Dim Sum. It's one of the few places that also accepts CC for a purchase, but you have to spend a Minimum $10. You pay the 2% CC fee (they use Square). Bring a bag if you plan on ordering a lot b/c they charge an extra fee if you want a bag to carry out your stuff. Which you most likely will have to b/c they have 1 table.  

~~Parking:  Street parking b/c it's in Chinatown, but you've probably parked somewhere else already and you're just looking for a place to eat. 

~~Service: Ok. The man that was serving me and my fam was nice, but he handed us over to a woman that was NOT. She was the one ringing us up to and gave us the utensils and sauces. I had asked for forks and sauces, since the employees were eating their lunch/dinner at the one table inside the place and she provided enough forces for us but only 1 soy sauce and 1 chili sauce packet, sadness. 

~~Best Part: Their har Gao (shrimp dumpling) is pretty good along with their chive and shrimp dumpling. 

~~Worst Part: Service and some of the food. Would NOT recommend getting the Shanghai dumpling (if you've had really good ones before). The skin is hard and there's no "soup" inside. 

~~Tips: If you only have a CC and want dim sum, then go here. But there's a lot of ATMs around chinatown for a lot of banks. So I would recommend hitting up an ATM, getting cash, and actually going to Dim Sum Bistro (https://www.yelp.com/biz/dim-sum-bistro-san-francisco) which is just a couple of streets over. 

~~Return: prob not, just because there's so many other dim sum places around Chinatown and I prefer the Bistro's
author: Jean T.

description:
We went there on Saturday noon, we got really lucky since there were no line and we also even got seat(there was only a small table in the entire place which can fit 4 ppl.) right after we sat down the line got super long. They lists dim sum in term of 3 pcs, but just tell her if u only want one, they r usually willing to divide the cost to just let u try. I got so much food and only spent 10 dollars, I literally couldn't finish half. I highly recommend the shumai and the shrimp dumpling, and I DO NOT recommend the bbq pork bun and the radish cake. 

For those who wants to eat nearby, there is a park but usually really crowded.
author: Shuang W.

description:
Mmmm. Came here for lunch on Friday. It was pretty busy but we managed to snag ourself the one and only table inside. 

Things usually come in 3s (except the rice wraps). We got the chives and shrimp dumpling, suimai, lohbakgoh, and a lotus rice wrap (it had a regular boiled egg, ground pork, and not one but TWO chinese sausages. Wow I was impressed).

There's a sign that says cash only and under that, minimum $10 for credit card use. So go crazy!
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Long line on a Sunday morning around 11am. Probably spent 20-30 minutes out on the street in line. However, I think it was worth it. Pretty good quality dim sum items. Selection is standard, such as shrimp dumplings, pork buns, turnip cakes, etc. Pretty fresh tasting and I can see that they were constantly putting out fresh products.

The cheap prices is what makes this place stand out. You can get a LOT of food for under $10. You should have a good idea of what you want to order as the staff is in a hurry to fill your order. 

There is virtually no seating offered. I walked over the Washington Park just down Stockton to eat my dim sum items and turned the experience into a nice picnic.
author: Charles H.

description:
Pros: Authentic, inexpensive, delicious food, large portions, and friendly staff. A hole in the wall that is DEFINITELY worth it!

Cons: parking and one table to sit.

Even though there is only one table, my family and I enjoyed eating while standing outside on the sidewalk; it was a fun and memorable experience!
author: Claire G.

description:
Stopped by here early on a Thursday morning.  The interior is very small with enough seating for honestly 2 people (we were fortunate to get the table).  The menu has your typical dim sum items but because the location is really meant for take-out, the prices were pretty good especially when compared to Boston.  For $7 you can definitely get enough dim sum to satisfy one person (they also let you order single items if you want to try multiples unlike sit down restaurants).  

Overall I was quite happy with what they served and if you're in the area give them a go!
author: Bob L.

description:
The name says it all. Every single bite was delicious, even the turnip cake, which we sort of tried on a dare.  Don't expect any ambience, but the dim sum is the best I've ever had.

We enjoyed all of what you see here for $18..
author: Caroline W.

description:
One dim sum spot was not enough.  After trying another shop, we (ok, ME)wanted to try more to compare and really get our dim sum fill before returning home where dim sum options are almost non-existent.

Delicious Dim Sum is located right across of the Gold Gate Fortune Cookie Company, so it's really convenient to just hop across the way and get your dim sum fix.  The shop is small, but surprisingly had a few tables inside.  It's also nice and clean and fortunately for us had no line at all when we came in.

The menu is printed on the cupboards and everything is priced so reasonably like many other places in Chinatown. Again, I got a pork dumpling, a BBQ pork bun, pan fried chives dumpling, & some others I don't remember. Too busy eating, I forgot to take photos. Hehe.  They did have some unique (to me) offerings like shark fin dumplings, but I'll have to try those on another trip.

Anywho, the pork dumpling. Oh my yum! Their version edged out another establishments by just a smidgen. Flavors were similar, but this one didn't taste as "porky" and the filing was also generous. The pork bun was also pretty good & reminded me of our manapuas back home in Hawaii! All in all, their dim sum was indeed delicious and worth a stop if you're craving dim sum or looking for some cheap eats in SF.
author: Maria P.

description:
Recommendation: Cash only, but a must visit. Really good Dim Sum, come as early in the day as you can for max selection, $20 can easily feed multiple people.


It's unbelievable that I haven't reviewed this place yet. This is one of the best Dim Sum places we've been to, and even got the stamp of approval from our friend who grew up in Hong Kong. We traveled with them to HK and also think it's the closest we've gotten to HK dim sum. 

The same 3 people are almost always staffing the counter, with the same few cooks peeking out from the kitchen in the back. Good to see that these people are happy and sticking around, even over the few years we've been coming here. 

Much of the food is hidden in steamers, so it's recommended that you look at pictures and know the names of what you want to get before going in. Once the line lets you get into the shop itself, you'll only have a minute or two to look before your order starts getting assembled. It's commonplace to order only a couple of many different things, so if you want to try 5 different dumplings, it's totally fine to order 1 or 2 of each different type. Note though that some items come in 2s or 3s, so if they give you extra it may be that it's their minimum order quantity. 

It's not necessary to speak Chinese to go here, as you can just name the number of the menu item you want with the new menu on the back wall that they put up a couple months ago. Name what you want, they'll find it and ask you how many, and then you can tell them.

If you're going to eat on the go, don't forget to ask for chopsticks. Also, use the squeeze bottle and hot sauce bowl on the table in the back to  dress up your dumplings before heading out! The seasoning is essential to good dim sum.

Other reviewers have mentioned the lack of space: It's true, there's one 4 person table in the back and then 2 or 3 chairs meant for waiting for your order, and that's all the space and seating there is. That being said, there are locations nearby that are suitable for eating. Portsmouth Square, downhill and a block south from Delicious Dim Sum, has a bunch of benches that you could sit and eat at while watching the crowds go through. There's also the roof of The Punchline comedy club, which is open 7 days a week for free. The entrance is between Clay and Washington, on Battery Street. Again there are benches, but it's much more secluded and better if you don't like crowds. From that area, you can also take a pedestrian bridge over Clay Street into a public area in the base of Two Embarcadero Center: It's protected from the elements, there are bathrooms, and even tables! On your way there, you can also grab a $3 bubble tea from Quickly, down the hill from Delicious Dim Sum. 

As for recommendations from the menu, we're pescatarian so we haven't tried any of the meat options. That said, we've had the following:

- Turnip Cake: good if you can pick out the meat bits, we usually order 1
- Shrimp Roll: long rice roll with large whole shrimp inside, served with sauce. We usually get 2 or 3, but they're bigger than most other items
- Shrimp Dumplings: steamed dumplings with shrimp inside, we usually get a few since they're small
- More (I'll update this list!)

We always try to guess how much we spent, and we almost always overestimate. We typically spend 10 to 15 dollars on Sunday mornings, and that's enough to hold the two of us over until dinner. 

Absolutely love Delicious Dim Sum and I hope it stays this good for a long time to come!
author: John B.

description:
Very good dim sum! Extremely cheap. 

They give a ton of food even when you say just one. We loved the red bean buns too!

Probably goes without saying, but they are cash only. Enjoy!
author: Leslie T.

description:
There are oodles and oodles of dim sum places in Chinatown, but we went with this one because of the stellar reviews and yummy pictures. Thank you, Yelp community, for not letting us down.

First off -- this is a SMALL and unassuming little shop. It's not a restaurant, really. Upon walking in, the counter takes up 3/4 of the interior, plus a 4-top table off to one corner. It's not immaculate. The walls are a bit stained and void of any art or elaborate decorations. The register and other machinery don't feature cutting-edge technology. The windows could use some cleaning. The food is prepared in a separate room. 

But, honestly, the food makes up for the shop's appearance, and then some. The dim sum was, as promised, delicious. The prices are great -- we spent $16 on lunch for two. It is CASH ONLY, though, so keep that in mind before coming...

We ordered:

- Pan Fried Chives & Shrimp Dumplings (3 per Order): Thick, filling, and perfectly crunchy. Heavy on the chives, so expect a strong taste.

- Shrimp Dumplings (3 per Order): Steamed, thick wrap. Classic dim sum, and highly recommend.

- Beef Dumplings (3 per Order): Steamed, thin wrap, juicy. Classic dim sum, and highly recommend.

- Shrimp Noodle Roll: Comes with a sauce to soak the noodles in -- try to eat on-site for convenience. Generous amount of shrimp per noodle. Couple noodle rolls per order, cut for you.

- Beef Noodle Roll: Comes with a sauce to soak the noodles in -- try to eat on-site for convenience. Beef was minced, and tasted much better than it looked. Noticeably more flavorful than others that I've tasted. Couple noodle rolls per order, cut for you.

- Sticky Rice with Pork Wrapped in Lotus Leaf: One piece. Most of the rice stuck to the lotus leaf... seemed overcooked. I wouldn't order this particular item again.

We had the opportunity to eat on-site, but this is more of a takeout type of shop. They combine everything you order into one box, if possible. Service was quick and efficient -- don't expect pleasant small talk with the employees.

We needed a nap shortly after our meal here. For such seemingly little food, we were full!
author: Kathy Z.

description: This was my first meal in my visit to San Francisco! These dim sum bakeries are the epitome of all that I look for in food places: cheap, down-to-earth (a lil rough around the edges even), and YUMMY! The line was much shorter than at Good Mong Kok as well. My friend and I got taro cake (2), lotus paste bun (3), shrimp and chive dumplings (3), char siu bao (2), sesame balls (3), another dumpling that I'm forgetting the name of (3), and xiao long bao (3) (except they didn't have soup in them LOL). All for ~$20! The only thing is we didn't know we could get any number of any item, since the prices are priced in quantities of 2-3 :( and the guy working the counter was super friendly, but he forgot to get some of the items we wanted (goodbye my egg custard bun and my shiu mai). Oh well! We were completely stuffed before we even finished everything we got, which was all amazing. It's really a special kind of experience to sit on the little chairs with the box of dim sum between you and listen to the hustle and bustle of Chinatown and other customers ordering around you as you eat.
author: Shelley P.

description: Dim sum is always my favorite food! I would highly recommend sesame ball and all kinds of noodle roll ( my favorite one is with shrimp), not only in this place but noodle roll in al Chinese restaurant!!
author: Patricia L.

description: Super cheap and good. Go earlier in the day since they always run out of the popular items.
author: Meya J.

description:
Delicious indeed!

Little seating is available but this is more of a take out spot. They offer a variety of dim sum, all displayed behind their glass case. Employees are friendly enough and quick. Just point at what you'd like and it's wrapped up before you know it. Their dim sum is well made and the price is definitely right. It won't hurt your wallet. 

Cash Only.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Oh so delicious, but be prepared.

It's a small shop in Chinatown with alone out the door.  When you get in, it's a small space and can be a bit overwhelming.
You can't see most of the dim sum and so it's a fun game of pick, taste and see.

In the tiny hole in the wall there is 1 table with 3 chairs so if you're able to eat there it's like winning the lottery- timing and luck.

All in all, once we got back to our hotel and tried all the random things we ordered I came to 1 conclusion:
Delicious Dim Sum has Delicious Dim Sum.

Will definitely make it a usual when Visiting Chinatown.
author: Desiree V.

description:
So sketch but so good! Bought about 5 different dumplings. The cilantro and shrimp was my
Favorite. It's like a ceviche dumpling!
author: Matt J.

description:
Snagged some Pork Siu Mai, Shrimp n Chive Dumplings and potsticker. Everything was solid but nothing amazing. I also gave neighboring Mongkok the same 3 star review in case you were curious. Like Mongkok know what you want to order because they want you in and out as soon as possible. 

Both of these places obviously have a great value for the amount of food you get.
author: Rod M.

description: My favorite carry out dim sum spot! I've been going for a few years now and they added a sign with photos and prices of food items -- very helpful for first timers or if you want to try something new. My favorites are the har gow, shrimp cilantro dumpling, and pork shu mai, which are all $2 and change for an order of 3. Make sure to add chili and soy sauce from the bottles to the side of the register, or get to-go packets. Don't forget to bring cash!
author: Edwina D.

description:
Overall rating 4--A terrific no-frills Cantonese Dim Sum to-go joint; there are no tables.  We had a Dim Sum breakfast for 2 for total cost $13.  Bring along your own chopsticks, or preferred utensils (they offer none).  Also, just carry out your styrofoam food container a plastic bag for it will cost an extra dime.. 

Their sticky rice in lotus leaf (Lo mai gai) dim sum was the highlight for us.  Opening up the steamed lotus leaf packet released an earthy and alluring aroma.  Inside the glutinous rice was a massive quantity of filling.  We'd give this a 5.

Chive Dumpling -within the translucent dumpling skin were emerald green chives and large chunks of shrimp.  This is pretty good; and earns it a 4 1/2. 

Char Sue Bao  and Sesame Seed Balls (Jian dui)  were fresh and warm and rated a 4 1/2 .

The Siu Mai and the Potstickers were not so much to our liking.  Though there was a lot of pork, they were just not warm enough (3).

Turnip Cake was just OK, again it was just not warm/pan fried enough and lacked sufficient filling for our tastes; this is a 2.5.

We'd rate this place higher if the food was warmer. But food quality and price was right!
author: Frank L.

description:
My parents were dropping by and wanted to bring me food. Since they were in Chinatown, I asked if they could grab some items from Delicious Dim Sum. They brought me take out for my late lunch on Saturday, February 10th around 2:45pm.

*Shrimp Dumpling
*Pork Dumpling
*Sticky Rice Ball
*Shrimp Noodle Roll
*Sticky Rice with Pork Wrapped in Lotus Leaf
*Black Bean Sauce Chicken Feet

The lo mai gai (sticky rice in lotus leaf) was huge! And a good amount of filling. This was one of my favorite items. The ha cheung (shrimp noodle roll) was silky and stuffed with large shrimp. I just wished they gave us a side of the seasoned soy sauce so I could eat it with that. The feng zhao (chicken feet) was a big serving as I guess they only sell it by the carton? The chicken feet were nice and meaty though. I had to split dish with my mom since the box came with so many. The ha gow (shrimp dimpling) and siu mai (pork dumpling) were average. I liked the har gow more though as the shu mai was just meh. Not much savory meaty flavor. And I thought it was weird that I got two of each. Normally an order is three? The rice ball was the disappointing item. Lots of rice and not much else. I like more meat and dried shrimp in my rice balls. I had also asked for pai gwut (black bean sauce spareribs), but I guess they had run out.

Not sure how much the total was as my mom bought everything, but for take out dim sum, everything was fine. I believe this spot is cash only, so make sure to bring some dollar dollar bills!
author: Elena N.

description: This place is a little hole in the wall in the middle of Chinatown. As far as I am concerned there was really nothing that blew me away or impressed me. Your typical dim sum selection is available like many reviewers before me have said and it's far better to visit early in the morning when the items are fresh and plentiful. I did go at a much later time in the day so perhaps that's why I really didn't get the flavor that I come to expect of dim sum places. This is not my first time at a Chinatown nor will it be my last, but I as I have visited other Chinese enclaves in different places throughout, I was expecting far better dim sum here in San Francisco. Don't get me wrong, it still hit the spot for that craving that I had and as always it was super affordable. So, all-in-all I wouldn't discount this place as providing a dim sum experience. But relative to other competitions in the area I would agree with the following statement to describe a two-star review: "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Dexter V.

description: Love the concept of takeout dim sum, but the execution here was just ok. Grabbed the shrimp cheung fan, siu mai (my go to), and those crystal dumplings (see pic) for around $7. Overall, the quality is decent but don't expect the same as a sit down place. The biggest advantage of these takeout places is quickness and saving a bit of money. You don't have to wait for a table or for carts to come around or food to come out. You also don't have to pay for tea or tip. Get this for all those reasons, but this won't ever substitute sitting down in front of some bamboo steamers with friends and family.
author: Jay F.

description:
This place is a hit, if you're lucky enough to be in the area you need to go. Keep in mind it's cash only but I got a box full of dim sum for... $3.50! There's no place to sit so be prepared to walk & eat, or enjoy the small parks around the area. 

I highly recommend 
* cilantro & shrimp dumpling
* pork shumai
* potstickers 
* there's another dumpling that is fried on the outside, but the bread on the inside is soft & sweet. It is filled with pork. I cannot remember so if you do, feel free to DM me and I can edit this!

Only disappointment was bbq pork bun had very little meat and all bun, but you will find a ton other dumplings to replace it with
author: Angella G.

description: DDS lives up to its name! Bring cash and buy everrryyythinnnggggg. Trust me, you will finish them all. Eat and walk around Chinatown and be happy :)
author: Claire W.

description:
SO GOOD!  We were looking for a sit down place, saw the take out style, and thought about passing it up.  Luckily we found a single table in the back that was occupied by two friendly looking people and we decided to join them and immediately get along fabulously over how awesome the food was here.  

Their pork bun was on point, Shumai so fine, but the star of the show, and they are nice enough to let you know (even if they usually can't make them fast enough) was the cilantro/celery/pork rice paper dumpling.  So fresh and so unique, it was mind blowing even right there next to some of the best dimsum I've had.  Would have passed over it except the woman working there was nice enough to insist we try it.  We ended up waiting an extra 15 minutes for them to make more after we were done eating cause we had to have more, even on full stomaches. 

Throw on getting full on AWESOME food for under $10 per person, and this hole in the wall makes me want to move to SF chinatown all by itself.
author: Matt C.

description:
Point your finger at what you want and they will bag it for you. No need to speak Chinese. 

This place is a raw hole in a wall, typical authentic to go dim sum joint. These type of places  doesn't usually cater to non Chinese speaking Americans. But this place is different. Chinese guy there is very nice and accommodating. Tip: you must come early for BBQ baked buns and BBQ steam buns.
author: Zombie L.

description:
We decided to try this place based on all the Yelp reviews. It was DEFINITELY worth going!!
It was much smaller than expected - basically it's a take-out hole in the wall with only one small table at the back..... BUT the DIM SUM!!! So very good!
Their prices are super cheap and portion sizes were very large and very tasty.
For a 3 piece order it was like $2.30 - super affordable.
My wife and I have eaten at a lot of Dim Sum places and this ranks right up there - in fact the Shrimp Hargow at this place is her favourite of all time.
The funny thing is at least 2 other people that were ordering food there also came based on the Yelp reviews and also very much enjoyed it.
Don't expect a spotless clean and shiny upscale environment - that's not what this place is about.
It's just super tasty, inexpensive, big portion Dim Sum and that's it.

The walk through Chinatown to get there is a blast too. 
The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is if here was more seating available. We got lucky and got the table just as a family was leaving, but without the table, you're standing up to eat somewhere.
author: Shawn L.

description:
I'm gonna have to say, I thought this place did a better job of being light and delicate in dim sum vs. Good Mong Kok Bakery. I stopped by for lunch and got a shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, chive dumpling, and a daikon cake.

The shrimp dumpling had a thin enough skin (still not restaurant quality, but I didn't expect it to be). Good flavor, though it was quite light. 3.5/5. The pork dumpling was the weaker of the items I tried-- a bit salted, and the pork was somewhat tougher. 3.25/5. The chive dumpling stood out as being pretty good-- chock full of chives that were finely grated, and perfectly pan fried. 3.75/5. I love daikon cake but this could have used some more toppings! The Chinese sausage in this was in tiny slivers, and there were no mushrooms or dried shrimp (okay, alright, maybe I'm asking for too much here...). The daikon was finely mashed, but I prefer a style that has little bits here and there. Good texture overall. 3.3/5.

A $3 lunch that fills you up is hard to beat!
author: Nicole H.

description:
Must be an off day as they certainly get a lot of clientele and reviews have been great. 

Tried a few dumplings including the har gow, prawn and coriander and another with chives. All of them were lukewarm, hard and the skin was way too chewy. 

Good selection of dim sum and some for vegetarians too.  

Small place. Only seats 6 so most people get takeaway.
author: Carmen P.

description:
Amazing dim sum that you would never tatse. We had chives/shrimp,  cilantro/shrimp, shu mai are must..... we ordered 12 orderders and paid about $30 which is super cheap.
They close at 6pm and you want to go early to try with variety selection.
author: Christine L.

description: Loved this spot. Got a sampling of everything they had left right before closing and it all was fresh and delicious. Great price and great flavors. Shrimp and pork items were amazing!
author: Awmber M.

description:
The people who work here did not seem friendly. When we got there we saw the two cooks arguing. 

This is a Togo place only. Cannot dine in. Btw the chicken feet are huge. 

The dim sum here was okay. The prices are affordable.
author: Diem N.

description: We ordered Xiao long bao, shrimp siu mai and, har gow. The har gow was great, the shrimp siu mai was really good, but the xiao long bao was big, hard, and didn't taste too great.There wasn't even any liquid in it. I was disappointed on how there is only one table in the restaurant (it is really small). A few concerns I had were that I saw a bug on a batch of har gow. I also smelled someone smoking in the kitchen, but other than that I would say that this restaurant is great and you should order a batch of dim sum from here (plus you can get food to go).
author: Luam W.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum is a cheap stop for lunch to-go on a budget. The customer service is typical for a Chinese restaurant which can be rude. I asked for 10 dumplings at the rate of $2.10/3 but the old lady kept insisting I buy 12 dumplings so she can calculate the price easier. When I refused, she still packaged 12 dumplings into the to-go box and said she'll sell it to me at the discounted price of $9.11. Confused at the math, I asked her to explain how was that a discount? She explained that including tax, the rate of the dumplings are $2.28/3. The discount she gave me was 1 cent. I wasn't about to start a scene over pennies and dimes but the whole situation was pretty insultingly humorous to me.  
 
Asian ladies are strong headed and cheap when it comes to business. Not too sure if I would recommend considering the overload of other dim sum places available. 
 
TLDR:
Food- 4
Service- 1
CASH ONLY
author: Sheila H.

description:
Fancy? Not at all. 
Delicious? Why, yes. 
Affordable? You bet. 

This place is wonderful. I ordered 20 orders (not pieces, but orders), and each order is about $1.80 for 3 pieces. Definitely a great deal, and they are dishing out orders as quick as you can get in there and tell them what you want. 

There was a line out the door when we arrived, and it's to-go only - with exception of ONE table and about 6 chairs that you can use if you get lucky. Remember, I said there was a LINE OUT THE DOOR... But we're soo blessed because by the time it was our turn, the table had just become available, so we actually got to sit and enjoy our hot dim sum instead of having to take it to-go or eat it outside standing up, like other people did. 

You're paying for the affordability factor, and the authenticity of dim sum in Chinatown, so don't expect frills here. They don't have noodles, chow mein, egg custard, or other things you might expect from larger dim sum places with a more extensive menu. 

They do have your Siu mai, har gow, pork bun, dumplings, so there's definitely a lot to choose from and you will get full, but like I said don't expect your fancy schmancy desert or deep fried dim sum dishes. 

All in all, definitely delicious. Fed our family of five for $35 while we logged out to our hearts delight and still left with a box Togo, so will definitely be back. I love bargains.
author: Joraine C.

description:
Amazing dim sum
No cheating out on protein
Flavors are amazing
Herbs in the dumplings were even so fresh
Cash only
The people were friendly too
author: prianka M.

description:
I came here to pick up dim sum with coworkers because it has slightly more variety than MongKok and I wanted to try it out.  Typical asian ladies working that wants to get you out of there as soon as possible. 

I ordered a myriad of items: 
11 har gow
2 sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf 
8 shu mai
1 shrimp rice rolls

It totaled to $23. Looking back now and thinking of their prices, I was probably overcharged by a bit but who knows.

Taste wise, it was okay. The sticky rice was okay, fairly typical, nothing to write home about. The har gow (shrimp dumpling) had a very sticky and soft wrapper. The shu mai was ... meh. Not the best. And the shrimp rice roll (cheung fun) had only 2-3 pieces of shrimp in it. I might come back just because they have more variety and they sell chicken feet ($5.50 a lb) but otherwise I might go elsewhere.
author: Judy H.

description: This was a fun place to get a quick lunch that was very authentic. Tried several of the potstickers, buns, shu mai, and so much more. Went back in for seconds. Got a TON of food, and the total cost was $17 for two of us! Yum!
author: Cindy C.

description:
Fresh transplant to SF here! Hello! And of course i had to check out what the nation's oldest and largest china town was all about. A little about me is that I'm obsessed with dimsum. When a dim sum craving hits I won't stop thinking about it till it's in my mouth. So of course one of my first days in SF I was rabidly scavenging through yelp for the perfect dim sum place...

Food is as promising as the name seems! Me and my s.o. came here, luckily scored the 1 table, which we shared with a cute chinese grandma, and had a grand time. We went for one round of food, then another, all for $16 enough to make us feel supppper full. Just for reference he's 6'4 and me, well I'm just a fatty. The funniest part of our experience was realizing this place is like dim sum roulette, ya don't know what you're gona get. I say this cus we ordered some of the same things the 2nd time around, and got new dishes. Aaaamazing. Usually I'd be upset by this but everything was so good and dim sum gets everyone in an adventurous mood sooo, why not!

ZE FOOD
- We ate so many things but a quick review. The Turnip Cakes are meh, but still satisfy the craving. 
- The Beef Rolled Dumpling is so good here! Boyfriend wasn't that about it but I was because there's usually a slight fishy taste to these but this one didn't have that whatsoever.
- The Shumai was amazing, just order it.
- Soup dumplings were good, but don't expect a DTF or Nan Xiang XLB level here. I'm obsessed with them so I still ordered them and stuffed myself. 
- Pork bun is also pretty good but it ain't no Tim Ho Wan. 
- Chive Dumpling was so so good here! Perfect crisp and texture and a lot of veggies yumyum

Other things, i can't speak to but I will upload photos of so you can try and match them... lmao

TIPS
- Cash only
- Take out (only 1 table)
- You may get some random things, but they all taste great - promise :)
- My fave dishes were mainly all the dumplings. But we got other stuff b.c. we have cravings and gotta satisfy.

TL;DR
Service (3/5) 
quick, that's what I like!
Ambiance (2/5) 
it is what it is. Sticky tables make me meh
Value (5/5)
Food (5/5)
author: Sara S.

description:
What DELICIOUS DIM SUM!

I had a severe craving for dim sum and couldn't get myself to actually sit down in a restaurant, and wait for carts to pass by, and be overcharged.

Fortunately, we made it right before the horrendous line. For being such a small establishment, they had a good amount of dim sum items. 

We had...

Pan-Fried Chive Dumplings
Steamed Shrimp Dumplings (Ha Gow)
Steamed Shrimp & Chive Dumplings
Pot Stickers
Steamed Shrimp & Cilantro Dumplings
Chive Noodle Crepe
Turnip Cake
Steamed Crabmeat & Shrimp Dumpling
Sesame Ball

We ordered enough to feed a family for four. And our total was around $17.  So reasonable!

Everything was hot, fresh and DELICIOUS.

Service is good. They aren't the friendliest but they aren't super rude either. Some of the dumplings we ordered were in the back steaming, so once they were ready they brought it to us promptly! This is the best service you are going to get in a Chinatown hole in the wall, let's be real. I have no complaints!

They have a small dining area in the back. Probably only fits like 5-6 people. We got lucky and were able to snag a table. There's soy sauce and hot sauce available as well when dining in!
author: Natasha S.

description: The most authentic and delicious dim sum and dumplings I've ever had outside of China. I used to live in China and these are the most authentic I've found in all of the USA. It's so so delicious. I got a couple of the shrimp and cilantro and just picked any other ones that sounded good and they were all incredible. Try this place!!!!!!!!
author: Nora H.

description: Ok so I was very skeptical when my cousin told me about this place just because um very picky on cleanliness but let me tell you the food I'd DELICIOUS!!! I loved it!!! The Cilantro one is amazing!!!
author: Gina G.

description: We tried a variety as suggested. It didn't disappoint. Every item she gave us was super yummy. It's just a small mom & pop spot. There isn't really any sitting inside, so plan to get it to go.
author: Kelly H.

description: In the middle of Chinatown. Good pricing. Fabulous taste for original and authentic HK Dim Sum. Very recommended!
author: Ziyue M.

description:
My coworkers and I have been making "Dim Sum Fridays" a thing as of late, and this has become our go-to spot for to-go dim sum. I think it beats Good Mong Kok Bakery in pretty much every category for flavor and texture (my only "meh" was their sticky rice).

The usual suspects are all solid and their standouts to me are their steamed shrimp and chive dumplings and any of their rice noodle rolls (particularly the beef). The service has been consistently efficient and friendly and when you can be stuffed like a Thanksgiving Turkey for under $10 life is good.
author: Irene B.

description: Yummy!!! I really enjoyed my first Dim Sum. It was hard to decide what to get since I've never had it- and there's a ton of options! Regardless I tried a lot! Only $7 worth but my money went far. It was nice. I especially liked the dumplings and cilantro pork.
author: Ashley A.

description:
Tiny cash only place with delicious, authentic and cheap dim sum.
Shrimp dumplings, sticky rice and ppt stickers are huge and delicious. 3 dumplings for $2.10!!! I bought $10 with of food and it was way too much for one person.
author: Martin K.

description:
This place is more of a to go place unless you're lucky enough to get a seat at the one table that they have in the back. We came here for some quick orders of dim sum and they have a decent selection. My Chinese is horrible so I just pointed to all the things I wanted and luckily the Chinese lady behind the counter knew what I meant. I got sui mai, har gow, pan fried chive dumplings and pork dumplings. All were super greasy, but pretty good and definitely satisfied our dim sum craving. Some hot sauce would have hit the spot though. We took it to a park and ate it there and it was kind of nice.

Overall, it's a decent place to get quick to-go dim sum. Note that it's cash only though.
author: Sophia Y.

description: When I think about shrimp dumplings this is the place to stop by. They are a take out only dim sum place but this a great place to pick up snacks or even stuff for a picnic. The price are reasonable but I would expect a wait if you come here. The skins of the dumpling wasn't thick like most places and there was a decent amount of shrimp in it.
author: Jackie N.

description: There usually a line here.  You have two locations to get amazing dim sum best part is that they are across the street from each other.
author: Jose R.

description:
If you're strolling through China Town and looking to pick up some grab-and-go Dim Sum, this is your spot! It really does live up to it's name and is VERY delicious! :) 

They have a variety of different buns, sweet breads, potstickers, and more. {So sorry, i'm not good with the authentic names!} We were headed to a full-on Dim Sum brunch so I just chose a few items to sample but the dumplings, potstickers, and steamed buns were amazing! They have a huge variety of fillings like pork, shrimp, cilantro, chives, etc. 

I will absolutely be back the next time i'm strolling through! I couldn't believe how inexpensive it was. Hard to beat for the authenticity!
author: Hailey P.

description:
Stopped by this place randomly while walking through Chinatown. They had solid dim sum. Got lucky and was able to be seated at the one table they had.

The shu-mai and shrimp dumpling was pretty good. The BBQ pork buns were not as good as I've at other places. Too much breading and pork didn't seem fresh, rather frozen. We ordered a few other dishes, everything else was okay. Good place for an "express" dim sum.
author: Prashant J.

description:
PROTIP 1:  Do NOT arrive hangry.

Because then you will order all the things.

PROTIP 2:  Do NOT forget your cash!

Why? 

Because if you ordered all the things, you may end up being a couple quarters short. *facepalm*

Because if you are a couple quarters short, you will find yourself standing awkwardly while watching some serious behind-the-counter debating and aggressive calculator button pushing.

Because eventually two dumplings will be removed from your overzealously ordered pile of dim sum.

#SoThatHappened

PROTIP 3: Skip the clumpy, burned taro cake. 

Because life is too short for bad dim sum y'all.
author: Amy C.

description: Excellent dim sum place, there was a minor communication barrier here or there but that's perfectly understandable when you're in Chinatown and don't speak Chinese.  They have a lot of options including spinach dumplings and their egg rolls are great as well.
author: Zach G.

description:
I thought this dim sum place was mediocre for San Francisco. I ordered pork siu mai, beef noodle, and a sesame ball. The pork siu mai was tasty at first, but I kept finding bits of hard cartilage or bone and had to spit hefty amounts of that out. I don't remember ever eating siu mai with bones in it. Next, the beef noodle was just ok. I love rice noodle wrapped around pretty much anything, but this rice noodle tasted funny and unfamiliar. Last, the sesame ball was just fine. Nothing memorable to report. 

I would definitely opt for a different dim sum place next time I'm in the area.
author: Kristy F.

description: From Hawaii we have our own style of dim sum so I had to try San Francisco style, this spot isAmazing dim sum! Some of the best I've had! The beef shumai is my favorite. Little hole in the wall, order to go or sit in the back, overwhelming selection and it's all SUPER tasty
author: Kekoa P.

description: Four stars mostly for the price.. although I have to say I haven't been to TOO many dim sum places in SF. The cilantro shrimp dumplings were the best I'd say and the pot stickers were HUGE! I knocked off one star because some of the dim sum were barely warm wish made them a little gross. We went at about 11 am. So maybe if you go earlier they'd be better. Also, the older lady seemed to get bothered that my sister and I ordered separately but sat together. I dunno!
author: R G.

description: This place was well well worth the trip. Lucky I went there when there was no line and I got to think a bit. The dim sum was hot and yummy and tasty. I can not wait to go back.
author: Tina L.

description:
I love this place. The best dumpling is the shrimp and chive one, hands down. Plus it's cheap! Cash only (as is the rest of Chinatown).

Yes, it's a bit dirty/grimy/you question what the health score is. No, you don't really want to eat there (definitely a pick up and leave place). But my god, the shrimp and chive ones are my favorite. They just cook it so well where the skin is just the right amount of softness and the filling is the perfect amount (they ratio to filling to skin is excellent imo)
author: Mimi T.

description:
Best tasting dimsum I've had in my life!!! The store name really speaks for itself. And it's super affordable! We got 10 different kinds (3 pcs. each) of dimsum all for $33.

We also have a Chinatown in Los Angeles, but the dimsum there doesn't taste as delicious as the ones from this store.

I highly recommend this place. PARKING is terrible, though. Because they are in a small, busy street... they share parking with all the other stores along that street.
author: Gels P.

description: It was raining and I rushed to this place just before they were closing . They had almost finished lot of options by then . I ordered cilantro prawn momo, pork Momo, chives prawn Momo and plain prawns momo . The prawns tasted fresh and were huge . The momo wrapping were thin and transparent and was delicious. The filling for cilantro prawns momo and Clive and prawn momo were remarkable . I'm definitely going back to try more options . The staff at the counter was a bit irritable probably because I landed at her closing time . But nevertheless service can be more friendly.4 for food . 3 for service.
author: Suria S.

description: This place was recommended by a local. There is a line outside the door. Tiny place, take out only. Reminded me of Seinfeld's NO Soup for you! Dim sum was good. Ladies working behind the counter are a bit intimidating if you don't know what exactly to order. There's a few extra sweets you can get but not many choices for food.
author: Barbara D.

description: I love this place. Beef shu mai are some of the biggest I've found in SF. I love how theirs always comes out medium, they don't overcook it until it's rubbery like 99% of dim sum spots. Their shrimp & chive dumplings are great, but since their not keep in a steamer, get dry quick! Shrimp cheung fun is incredibly with large chunks of shrimp. That and the beef shu mai are my go-tos here. Way better than good Mong Kim with 1/10 the line.
author: Sammy A.

description: There is a reason this place has high ratings. The dim sum is delicious. Super fast service. The place is pretty small, but they have lots of options. I didn't have one thing I didn't like.
author: Alex L.

description:
BEST place for Dim Sum.. LARGE portions and prices are great.. my parents have been coming here for years and years.. as far as I can remember. Prices have gone up in the years.. but place is still very cheap. The best thing is that the women here speak english!

The only thing I do not recommend are the chinese doughnuts.. they are not that great as they are very cold and feel a little stale.. 

However things that I do recommend are the 

Shrimp Dumplings ***** THE BEST
Shrimp and Chive Dumplings ***** THE SECOND BEST
Sticky rice in lotus leaf 
Pork Shu mai 
Steamed BBQ pork bao
Turnip Cake 
Sesame Ball w/ red bean paste
author: Eleana H.

description:
It's was good, but the skin was too think for me. 
Line to so long, and you're in and out so fast. Ugh.
author: Diana A.

description: The name says it. It's darn good Dim Sum! I am by no means a Dim Sum expert, but we got a bit of everything and it was great. Some of the meat was borderline mystery meat, but that's expected when I have no idea what I'm eating! The staff was friendly, but somewhat unhelpful due to language barriers. I'd come back in a heartbeat on my next trip to SF.
author: Luke S.

description:
Great authentic chinese food. This was my first venture away from the typical American take on Chinese food. My family and friends rave about China town, restaurants like this one, peppered throughout the area are what make San Francisco one the best cities to live in or visit.

BBQ pork dumplings, pot stickers, shrimp dim sum and sesame cakes are just a few of their amazing items you must try.
author: Chris M.

description: This place is a must when in the bay. It's a hole in the wall  place tucked in china town bay has some of the best dim sum you'll ever have. The store isn't very clean and the customer service isnt the greatest but that's how you know the food is gonna be freaking bomb! The actual dim sum is huuuuge and the prices are cheap! If I could eat here every day I would. Sponsor me please delicious dim sum and make my dream to move to the bay come true. Ilysm
author: Brandon L.

description:
This place is awesome. I loved being able to get take out dim sum and not have to sit and wait for the carts to come by. We walked in a little before 12:00 for lunch on a Friday and were the next people in line. 

A few other Yelpers mentioned rude owners, but that was not my experience at all. The women working were very pleasant and didn't treat us rudely at all even though we were speaking English.

Since all the items come in threes - you should think about going as a group of three! Hubby and I had a hard time deciding who got the leftover item for each thing we ordered (shrimp dumplings, fried pork + vegetable dumplings, BBQ pork buns, and potstickers). Yum!

Despite the prices being super cheap ($9ish for the two of us) - everything still tasted great and there were no stomach disturbances to boot! 

Great food + great price + short walk to office = new de facto dim sum spot.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Due to the fabulous street parking, we ended up here after the fortune cookie factory. We had the shrimp and chive pan fried dumpling and it was served hot and oh so delish! The pork and shrimp shumai was food too but the steamed char siu bai had a little too much bun and not enough filling. 
Har gao was light and airy and we could have eaten more of these. 

Sadly they did not have egg custard tarts which is what we were really looking for as Golden Gate Bakery was closed for vacation. 

Can't beat these prices and there was a line out the door to reinforce their value. I love this place over Good Mong Kok and will definitely be back!!
author: Carlyn C.

description: Delicious dim sum served by elderly Cantonese cooks. There is a queue but only 1 table and 8 chairs. The shrimp dimsum like har kau, chives dumpling and cilantro kau were of good quality. The pan fried turnip cake could be better with less flour. The sweet pastries with beans were not remarkable. The old lady will kindly show you the way to the park nearby for your dimsum picnic.
author: Stephen O.

description:
The siu mai is really really good here! Everything else is just okay, but everything was definitely worth the price. 
This is a perfect place to go if you're just looking to pick up some dim sum to eat real quick!
author: Cynthia D.

description: If you just want to enjoy dim sum, but see a long line at other dim sum places, this store would be a good stop ! They spoke good enough english to understand what we wanted. We ordered few dumplings and chicken feet. They were all bomb !
author: Theresa Y.

description: Very cheap, very fast, very tasty, but the spot is a bit dingy. We ordered the full order of pork shumais, shrimp dumplings, turnip cakes, sesame balls, pork buns, fried meat buns, shrimp & cilantro dumplings, and a few other things. The lady running the shop only spoke Chinese, so it was hard to fully communicate everything and she seemed pretty annoyed when we ordered the food to go but asked to eat at their lone table (we wanted the bag for to-go bc we had ordered some dishes to bring home with us). Anyway, we were fully stuffed after paying less than $20. There's another spot just across the narrow street called House of Dim Sum that serves more hot dishes beyond dim sum. The prices seem to be cheaper there, but I didn't order any food there so I don't know if the portions are smaller.
author: Justin Y.

description: Very fresh and fast service. Authentic and well worth it. The menu was in English as well so easy to order. I highly recommend coming here it won't let you down!
author: Josh B.

description: Stopped by for a quick bite while walking by and it was delicious, we loved the shrimp dumplings!
author: Jordan Z.

description:
This place is okay for hargow but for the siumai, it definitely needs improvements. The hargow is definitely a take because of how much shrimp there is inside while the hargow is wrapped juicy and flavorful. You can even see the shrimp when you order it inside the wrappings of the shrimp! Haha! The siumai though needs to have more meat. Every time I order, their meat is so small and it's always dry. Overall, I'd come for the hargow for sure! 

Overall:

- SiuMai 3.5/5

- Hargow 5/5

- Customer Service 4.5/5

Update: 5/11/17, they ripped me off. They charged me 90 cents for 1 har gow/1 siu mai. On the prices, it says 60 cents. Sorry, no going back after being ripped off.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: If something has 'Delicious' in the title, you better believe it! Busy little carry-out with a fresh selection of dim-sum. I didn't really know what I wanted and didn't want to hold up the line, so I just pointed at a few things. That's kind of my general M.O. in life, and I'm not dead yet. This is a great, cheap place to grab a snack. I highly recommend the shrimp and cilantro dumpling.
author: Ha D.

description:
Yum. Yum yum yum. Yum. Yummy. Yummers. Oh yeah, yum. 

Seriously, this place is great. Affordable and tasty. My wife and I shared the pork bun (yum), the shrimp dumpling, beef and noodle soup, a spring roll, and a sesame roll (all super yum), a water and Sunkist for $14.00. 

Go. Go more than once. Go as many times as you can.
author: Jen G.

description: 3 har how, 1 large char siu bow, and 1 beef cheong fun was about 5.30 including tax. The har gow was the best tasting of the lot-they were large in size and had good flavor but could have been hotter temperature wise. The char siu bow had a relatively small amount of BBQ pork compared to the hefty amount of surrounding bun. Since the bun was a little dry, I discarded it once I finished the pork. The beef wrapped in rice noodle was tender, but, again, the carb exterior was overwhelming in quantity. I'd definitely go back for the har gow. Today, it was a bit better than Mong Kok. Yup, you better believe I tried the har gow at Mong Kok 15 minutes later.
author: Suzanna L.

description: Didn't like it that much. Maybe because I have tried in many countries. Apprx 10 USD for 3 recipe'.. Cheap, but will not return again.
author: Masarus T.

description: Found this little gem along with my friends a couple of years ago. Actually more like a hole in the wall but man oh man do they deliver. Delicious Dim Sum...delicious indeed!!! Definitely a must try. Prices and variety is great. You will not be disappointed.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
This is a little hole in the wall shop.  I got the shrimp dumplings and the shark fin dumplings. One order came with 3 pieces. Everything written on the walls was in Chinese so I asked for an English menu. 

So 6 pieces came out to only $4.50. Both type of dumplings were really good.
author: Vincent C.

description: When I first came here last year, there was never a line, I would walk in and ask for a dozen or two of the shrimp and chives dumplings.  Now, when I want my favorite item here, there's a line out the door.  My secret place has been found out.  The food here is always consistent and it's just as good as the other place that you see lines around the block.  If you're looking for good dim sum, put this place down as one of your go to places.  The price is also similar to the other places.  Cash only.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Confused and limping in San Francisco (I had just slipped -- rain + metal flooring + clumsy me is not a good combo), we grabbed an assorted variety of dumplings, buns, and fried things. Most of the staff doesn't speak much English- which was no problem, pointing worked great. 

The four of us grabbed the (only) small table in the corner and sat down, excited to eat! To our disappointment, the food was cold and greasy, another not so great combo. To its credit, it was flavorful and obviously made that morning, but a far cry from the steaming hot dim sum I'm used to.

The restaurant doesn't appear to be particularly clean, and mid-way through the meal, somebody knocked over a tray of dumplings - the metal pan hit the tiled floor with a jarring loud thud. The (fellow) clumsy person got yelled at for a few minutes, adding to the interesting ambiance of our meal. 

A cool experience, in a weird way, but I won't be back.
author: Misha S.

description:
The dim sum here is $2.10 plus tax for 3 pieces and it's Cash only! For three pieces, what I enjoyed about this place was that you can mix and match dim sum, something very uncommon in other dim sum places that you try. The line up isn't too bad - I also went during the day of Chinese New Year celebration, so it probably had more people than usual. The menu isn't super clear as to how much everything is, so it's recommended that you ask before you purchase! 

We tried their har gow, siu mai, custard bun, BBQ pork bun, ChaoZhou dumpling (the pork and chives dumpling), radish cake and taro cake. The dumplings such as the har gow, siu mai and Chao Zhou dumpling were a little oily. The Chao Zhou dumpling was large, though the skin of the dumpling was too thick. I think the most delicious item was the custard bun! It's not too sweet and only slightly runny! One of my favourite items in this store!
author: Kristy N.

description: The prices are very reasonable... worth it if you take it to go or squeeze in the very small space to eat.  Har Gow and all the seafood options are amazing. I think they should try to reduce plastic usage for eat in customers or even to go.
author: Mike P.

description:
This place is pretty darn good! Love that the line is shorter but it is a bit of a trip to walk there from my work place.


Food is fresh, plentiful and best of all, pretty cheap! Wish the dumplings and the noodle rolls were better regarding the dough/sticky flour part. But would go again if I had the chance.
author: amy n.

description: I keep recommending this place to people, and they have all loved it. It's delicious and cheap. We always stop here when we come to town. It's a little intimidating because you have to really think quickly and the ladies there didn't speak english, which is fine but I wanted to ask what was in a Bao. It was cheap enough so I just took a chance lol. Everything here is delicious!
author: Karen L.

description: Don't recommend.  Walked in on a Thursday. Place was empty. Got the beef shu mai, shrimp and cilantro, and hakao shrimp dumpling.  The beef shu mai tasted like a grainy paste and I didn't even finish it. My friends also did not want to eat it. The shrimp hakao dumpling was chewy and tough.  I should've known it wasn't going to be good because literally no one was in line.  Never again!
author: Nghia T.

description: This was a spur of the moment lunch stop that did not disappoint, we overlooked the cash only sign but there was an ATM not far away. Great authentic Dim Sum but be careful, your eyes are always bigger than your stomach with good Dim Sum. Highly recommended.
author: Michael H.

description:
I love the concept of grab-n-go dim sum because you can enjoy a ton of different pieces while going solo, you don't have to wait around for a cart pusher and it's hella cheap.  However, the downside is that some pre-made items don't keep well when made in advance; the crispy stuff gets soft and the soup dumplings lose their soupiness.  Also, things can get difficult if trying to setup a dipping sauce while outside on a park bench.   There was no English menu in sight, just a bunch of Chinese written above the counter.  So look at the Yelp photos ahead of time to get the names of things that look good to you (or just call out your usual dim sum favorites).  All things considered, still a tasty and cheap lunch option if it's a nice enough day to enjoy some dumplings outside in Portsmouth Square Plaza.

Xiao Long Bao: Tasty and tender pork filling (much more so than the pork shumai), but no soup inside.  But that's what happens when your xiao long bao sits around for a bit.

Pan Fried Shrimp & Chive Dumpling: Tasty filling, but not the fried side was not that crispy.  Probably got soggy sitting around all its steamy neighbors.

Pork Shumai: A coarser mince than the pork in the xiao long bao.  One of them had an unpleasantly gristly component.

Steamed Pork Bun: Tasty roast pork and sauce instead.  A little too much bread-to-meat for my tastes.

Shrimp Rice Noodle Roll: Bleh.  Too much rice noodle roll compared to filling.  In fact, the only filling consisted of 4 small shrimp.
author: Adam B.

description:
Two workers, of course it was a little slower but they were kind and did exactly what they were supposed to. A good visit to china town. 

We had six sesame balls, pork shu mais, a sticky rice wrapped in banana leaf, a few taro balls, and two fluffy banh baos.
author: Victoria T.

description: I love that fact this place is a completely take out place for dim sum. It's good dim sum although I was so disappointed as I went there twice and twice they gave me the wrong soy sauce for the beef funn roll crepe dish. Everybody knows who eats beef funn rolls or any thing with meat and rice noodle wrapped around it comes with the sweet soy sauce! Their food is amazing the haw gow ( shrimp dumpling) was to die for. The shrimp was bouncy and the skin was thin and tasty. I loved their potstickers the skin was fresh the filling was filled with pork and ginger just the way I love it. Better than what I can get in Chicago. I really wish they had gotten my soy sauce right. I would come back  her to try their other dim sum items it's cheap and there's a long line for this place meaning it's hopping good!
author: Jaci Y.

description:
Going to San Fran you have to have dumplings. I went to 2 shops to compare the difference. This one did not line and was in and out in no time. I would say between the 2 shops there's not much of a difference. They both are great. You don't need to speak Chinese to order. I just said what I wanted and it was fine.


I ordered bbq pork bao and sesame balls. They were the perfect little snack we had for our trip to Alcatraz. I wish I had ordered more.

Super cheap and delicious. I would bring cash for fast handling!
author: Sandy T.

description:
This was my first but not my last time eating Dim Sum.

I had a very bad misconception as to what Diim Sum was.

The food here was very fresh and flavorful. It was so good that no soy sauce or chili sauce was needed.

Get ready DFW I will be in search for Dim Sum when I get home.
author: TC A.

description: Randomly picked this place because the food looked good and it was so cheap! It's cash only but didn't really mind because it was a good price. I highly recommend the shrimp dumplings they were the best I've ever had! It was really small though, there's not really a place to sit and eat.
author: Samantha T.

description:
I was literally craving for dim sum, and because I'm traveling alone, I'm not fond of eating along.  Call me crazy or whatever, but that's just me. 

After yelping where a highly rated dim sum (to go) place in SF, I came to conclusion they this place seems to be the hot spot. 

When I arrived here, there was a bit of a line.  That's usually a good sign.  

Walked in, ordered 5 shumai, 2 pot stickers, and 3 har-gow for lunch.  Wow--all three items are to die for, and supremely delicious.  It's also a huge plus for all those items, I walked out paying $6.20.

Not only is it a bargain, but fills me up for so little money.  Definitely coming back again. 

Overall grade: A
author: Bobby K.

description: I went here with family and was abmw to select 2 containers worth of items to bring back to our hotel and try. Everything was delicious and we only spent $21!!! I highly recommend everyone out of town to find a way to go to this shop for at least 1 meal.
author: Rachael C.

description: I had the sesame roll, lotus bean bun, and egg custard bun and they were all amazing! Be prepared because it's cash only and the space is small so it really is meant to be to go dim sum. Overall, highly recommend!
author: Jenna L.

description:
Great take-out dim sum! A good dim sum experience doesn't necessarily have to require a full sit-down service or an expansive menu, and Delicious Dim Sum proves it. The available selection is rather limited to a handful of steamed classic dishes like shrimp dumplings and each order of 3 is $2.10.

Kinda weird order portion since I am used to the order of 4, but no doubt the shrimp dumplings were one of the best I had! Stuffed with shrimp, the juiciness of the dumplings cannot be denied and the flavor was so good that I actually went back to pick up a second batch before I left SF because I finished the first batch within minutes! 

Only one table is available so don't expect to dine here. Don't let that deter you though: the dim sum here is worth eating while walking! The service may be a little rude but hey, you are dealing with them for only a bit for perhaps the best dim sum you'll ever had.

Cash only by the way

---
tl;dr version:
1) Limited seating and menu with only steamed items at $2.10 per order of 3
2) REALLY REALLY GET THAT SHRIMP DUMPLINGS!
3) Cash only, don't expect good attitude or available seating
author: Jay Y.

description:
Incredible dim sum! HIGHLY recommend. We weren't sure if we wanted to eat here because there's wasn't a sit down area, but we snagged the one table that they had in the back and then ordered a bunch of food on the menu, which is in both English and Chinese. The woman we ordered with was very friendly and wasn't bothered by our complicated order.

Our favorite by far was the pan fried chive dumpling! We devoured them and ordered some more. The pork shumai was pretty dry which was a bit of a disappointment and the tapioca cake was decent, but all the other food was delicious. You can't go wrong with any of the dumplings and the shrimp and chive dumplings were probably our favorites, and if you visit, you must get the egg rolls too. To top it off, we ended with the sesame balls with red bean paste inside. They were great but we were so full, so we took them to go and ate them on the road.

Highly recommend!! There's so much to try on the menu, and they handled our order very quickly!
author: Rebecca L.

description: Great dim sum & really quick. Definitely try shrimp/cilantro and the Shanghai dumpling :D
author: Mary H.

description:
The name of this place speaks for itself! It's delicious!

This isn't your typical sit-down dim sum restaurant where they roll around carts and you pick and choose what you want. It's a little hole-in-the-wall place where you order at the counter and receive your food immediately - hot and fresh! Seating is extremely limited and it's actually better if you order take-out because that's what I've seen every other customer do. They only accept cash as payment, but fear not, you can get your moneys worth with just a couple of bucks because it's so cheap and you don't tip!

The shrimp dumplings (Har Gow) is a must get here. It's probably the best I've had in a while. The shrimp itself is very flavorful and juicy. You can definitely tell that the shrimp is fresh too. I want some right now just thinking about it! I would also order the Pork and Shrimp dumplings (Sei Mai). It's also pretty good here. I ordered four of each and it hit the spot! Make sure you remember to ask for Soy Sauce and Chop Sticks!

It helps if you speak Cantonese, but that's definitely not required.

-CASH ONLY
-BEST FOR TAKE-OUT, NOT DINE IN
author: Danny L.

description: SO GOOD! They have variety and the dim sum was made freshhhh! It's hard to communicate with the workers, but who cares. The dim sum is really good and the price is right. I got the first 4 options, 3 each. That would definitely get you going for 2 meals a day. I wish this place had more space though, but hey it's san fran, what canya do. 5 stars!
author: Kevin B.

description:
What's not to love about a lil' dimmy summy for the tummy?!   Love everything about San Francisco - every  borough with China Town  and North Beach top favs. 

Delicious Dim  Sum lives up to its name and reputation.   Artfully prepared and quick and easy to grab and go.

While the 2 working over the steam pots were all business - they lit up when I shared I discovered them via Yelp.

HarGow,, Chives Gow, PotSticker and Shumai were very memorable with the potsticker being the fav - thick ala dente dough covering and ginger leaving our chops wishing for more ..  Pace yourselves ... Pace yourselves
author: Karyn K.

description:
The three star rating is more for the food as for the service it's more like a one star. My friend and I decided to stop by here to get our Dim Sum fix. 

Like most to go Dim Sum places around China Town it's small hence why you would take it on the go. There's only one table inside that seats four and then a few more chairs along the side for you to sit as well. 

We ordered the ha gao (shrimp dumplings) shu mai and this other shrimp dumpling. 

The ha gao was authentic for my friend and I since we are very picky with our Dim Sum. That we approved of, as for the shu mai it was just not tasty in my opinion. The meat was very bland. 

As for the service it was not great at all. The elder lady was nice with assisting us with our order then when we paid it was another lady with an attitude. We ordered a good amount of Dim Sum and she gave us one thing of soy sauce so we decided to ask for another one. She then proceeds to ask if we were going to eat here or take it to go. I told her we would eat here maybe. She then responds by saying there's already soy sauce on the table which is fine but then she decides to take the soy sauce inside our box out and put it back in the fridge. I don't know if it's just me but I found that really rude. If you're down for some decent Dim Sum fix this could be an option but there are plenty more options up the hill.
author: Yinja L.

description: The food is poor quality. Meat seems to be the lowest grade. Dumplings not fully cooked. Also they are not polite when you order...beyond the typical apathy you find at places like this. It seems to be mostly tourists who go here. I won't be back.
author: Ashley N.

description: Delicious, affordable dim sum in pleasant environment, in the heart of Chinatown, with few good vegan offerings.
author: Ben R.

description: Loved loved this place. It's cheap and the food was great. My favorite one was the pot sticker looking Gouza one  by the window facing the street. I have no idea what it was becuz English is limited. The signs are in English tho but not next to the items so it can get a little confusing. Also the shrimp and chives were great to. Overall a good experience. I would return.
author: Lika G.

description: Great little spot, food is fresh and delicious. Place is best to grab and go, seating is limited, but for the quality it's worth it
author: Raj K.

description: Outstanding value and the tase was perfect. Waited 10 minutes in line. Fast service, cash only, to go only. Huge box was only $10. Highly recommended.
author: Turkey B.

description: Dim Sum was just okay and the lady helping us was  very rude. Telling us to hurry up and order but there was anyone in line. Nothing special about this place except very rude service. We didn't let her ruden our morning with her bad attitude.
author: James K.

description: I think this is the best dim-sum I've ever had truly!! Shrimp and cilantro and shrimp in garlic were divine
author: Lisa u.

description:
09.27.16

Is it possible to have high expectations after reading Yelp reviews, temper your expectations after walking in to the venue with no customers, and still come out satisfied?

Yes, yes it is.

I was craving dim sum but didn't walk the overpriced and lower quality restaurants in FiDi. 12 minutes and a stroll up to Chinatown got me these: https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/delicious-dim-sum-san-francisco?select=fPI7_QSfQELcXeOuhx6qVQ&userid=tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ

Total damage: $4.79
author: Jenny L.

description: Excellent dim sum. Could not beat the price! Took it with us and ate it in our hotel room and then wished we had bought more.
author: Gail E.

description: Best in SF, and I've tried most of them. Eat it while it's hot, and it won't stay hot more than 5 minutes in their containers. Shrimp dumplings out of this world!
author: Shoshi D.

description:
The best of the bunch were their siu mai.
The deep fried dumplings had really tasty filling, but the dough was too thick and therefore a bit undercooked, which gave it a slightly pasty flavor.
The har gow was average at best,
author: Lewis C.

description: har gao is my fave! love this place. I wish they were open everyday though. :)
author: Michelle R.

description:
CHEAP! I got a box full of dim sum, all varieties, for less than $10.

Though it might not be the best dim sum I've ever had, but for something that you can grab and go within 2 minutes, that's not bad at all. 

Cash Only and very limited seating! The inside table only seats like 6 people max, so you'll have to get it to go and enjoy it elsewhere. My best tip? Find a public/open rooftop area in the FiDi area to snack on these goodies :)
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Looooooooove! Such good quality and great prices. Come earlier for the best selection - but still plenty of options even in the afternoon. I think they're cash only but you likely won't be spending more than $5 for each person to eat plenty.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Maybe I'm blind or maybe I'm just more forgiving, but whatever the reason, I can't agree with my Yelper pals on this one, and I've still gotta give lots of love to Delicious Dim Sum. 

Anytime we visit SF, this is the last stop I make before heading to the airport or hitting the road. It's a tradition my wife and I started, and one adapted and carried on with a good Yelp friend a few years ago. This tradition has gotten so popular in fact that this year we attracted other awesome people from around the globe to share in the experience! This year we even found a sweet park where we could sit and enjoy them while watching morning Tai Chi!

We come to Delicious Dim Sum for dumplings. Steamed or fried. Rice skin or wheat dough. It doesn't matter as long as it's a dumpling. My favorites include thd shrimp and chive, hargow (shrimp in rice skin), beef shumai, shark fin (which I'm not sure actually has the namesake ingredient and is more pork and shrimp), and the smaller round ones filled with Chinese green vegetables. I always get enough to enjoy in the spot and then enough to bring home to share with the wife and freeze for a later date. You can get 1 of this and one of that, and it's so affordable it's a joke. About 40-50 pieces topped the charts at $32!

To the uninitiated, Chinese dumplings may all seem the same, and to be honest, I never really knew why these were the best either, but this year it all came together. I got my usual order, and then picked up some dumplings at another shop as well. Comparing the two was night and day. The skins on the dumplings at Delicious are so thin and delicate that you can see right through them. They're barely holding all of the delectable fillings in, which means with each bite you're tasting mainly what's inside. It also shows a level of skill in how they're made, which you can see if you glance into the kitchen. The ones from the other shop... thick, opaque, and definitely more chewy.

Now one of my friends mentioned questionable food handling and holding they observed, specifically flies molesting some of the delicious buns. My response... Thats all part of the authentic Chinatown experience! Just glance around any of the small markets in the area and you'll see plenty of things that make you scratch your head, but It's the uncertainty and unknown aspects that make the experience! 

Another friend mentioned a greasy red bean sesame ball. My response... PRO-TIP: Delicious Dim Sum is all about the dumplings. Steer clear of anything not in a steamer tray at this spot because better can be had very nearby. Even the "potstickers" are quite doughy and not that great, but when you go you'll notice they're not in the steamer ;) 

Overall, Delicious is still my spot and if you stick to my list and tips, you'll love it too. I highly recommend finding the park to sit in. It adds to the overall experience. Don't feed the pigeons though. It'll be like a scene out of a Hitchcock film.
author: Michael T.

description:
Came by for some take out the other day and it was okay. Unlike Good Mongkok, there was no line and the staff was efficient.

Dim Sum orders were $2 for 3 pieces.

Shiu Mai was okay and the pan-fried chives dumpling was also okay. Pot stickers were passable.

Cash only.

...not sure how 3 orders come up to $6.2 though...
author: Derek S.

description:
I don't want to write this review update, but I feel the need to warn others about Delicious Dim Sum.

Every year, my homeboy/ CM of Reno and I journey to this establishment before dipping out to SFO. We've made it a tradition, and it used to be a good one. Unfortunately, during our most recent visit, I witnessed some incredibly worrisome ish there: fruit flies and houseflies. 

Like many other times, I watched the staff there load har gow, shu mai, shrimp and chive dumplings, and others into a tiny plastic container. After paying, I stepped to the left to watch my homie get his noms and noticed that the display of baked goods (like BBQ pork buns and whatnot) was inundated with fruit flies. Not one. Not two. But ten or twenty! (ICK!) Not to mention, there was an entire crate full of BBQ buns covered in flies underneath a table! (So freaking terrifying!)

Believe it or not, I tried eating on one of the four chairs inside, but I felt terribly ill especially after a fly landed on my arm. I then recommended to Michael that we dip out and head to a park to eat our dim sum.

So sad! I loved this place during our first couple visits there, but I don't think I'll ever return. It's truly a health hazard, and I hope they improve. 

*Note: For context, this is the first time I've ever rated something from five to two stars. Also, out of 515 reviews, I've only written 32 two-stars. Delicious Dim Sum will be the 33rd. I'm truly sad about this experience. =(

Feel free to check this place out yourself, but you have been warned. I recommend Good Mong Kok Bakery up the hill, for cheap dim sum.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Cheap, dependable dim sum of the take-out variety. There's little to no room for eating inside, so you line up, point to (or ask) for what's being offered, pay, and go. 

The dim sum isn't the best out there, and some of it has been sitting there steaming for hours, but you could do far worse for the price and portions. Simply a good, convenient, no-frills option for a fast dim sum fix.
author: Vincent L.

description: I've had better. They could put more meat on their pork sticky bun. Their pot sticker was really good. Flavorful. The sticky rice with meat wrapped in lotus leaf was ok...the fried taro was ok as well. Definitely our favorite was the pot sticker. They were stingy on the sauce as well. I asked if we could get some sauce and they give us 1 shoyu and 1 Sriracha sauce. Really?! You know there's 2 of us and you can only spare 1 of each?! What's up with people being so stingy with chili sauce? Geez...such as life! Moving on!
author: Anne M.

description:
(Cash Only) One of the best cheap lunches in SF i've found yet. $5-8 should cover most peoples needs. The restaurant is a little tricky as the "menu" on the wall simply states the names of dishes but no pricing, and the display of foods below hide many of the goodies stacked under the giant metal tins. The ladies working there were patient, nice, and the wait was zero at 12:30pm on a Tuesday.

The shumai and peanut/pork dumplings were excellent, the steamed bun a little dry but very large and still tasty. 

Well worth the trip for lunch on a budget
author: Alexander Z.

description:
