It's a take-out counter with one small table in the back.  It looked like there was a line outside but the shop is so small, it was quick.  

A Chinese friend told me that the Chinese food in the San Gabriel Valley is better than in San Francisco and I agree.  

The best of the three items we tried was the shrimp/cilantro dumpling.  The potsticker had a lot of cabbage in the filling and less meat than I like.  Of course you can't compare the Xiao long bao to Din Tai Fung but it was fine and a great snack.
author: Carol N.

description: We tried 2 other venders before finding Delicious Dim Sum and by far the best!!  Must try the shrimp and chive dumplings.
author: Sanaz A.

description: Rude lady, price not clearly marked. Dim is okay, not that fresh. Go to Good Mong Kwok instead. Not recommend.
author: Christy T.

description: Very cheap and taste is not bad at all, especially considering the price. I end up spending only ~$6/person and we have our fill
author: Ali B.

description: I look up reviews prior to going to most of the restaurants. This place was rated pretty high but I didn't see anything special about it. I didn't know that it was an on the go type of place I was hoping that I can sit and relax, eat, and have hot tea but it turns out it only had one table very uncomfortable and not so clean. Very disappointing since we are tourists, we have been traveling and walking, I just expected a little better. The dim sum itself was decent. There dim sim homemade and fresh which is great.
author: Chau Q.

description: Yes, please! This Dim Sum was delicious and I hope to come here again when I'm in the area.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: We came here yesterday and had some yummy treats. The shrimp and cilantro dumplings were my favorite but the shrimp and chive dumplings were good too. The beef shumai was good as well as the beef and vegetable buns. For dessert was sesame balls with bean paste which wasn't too sweet. Pretty good! There is limited seating(one table can fit four people) and a few extra chairs to take a load off from perusing the busy Chinatown streets but it's a tiny space so eat and move on for the next folks to sit!
author: Nikki W.

description: China Town. authentic Dim Sum experience. Highly recommend it to all my foodie friends. {Sesame balls w/ red bean paste, Har Gau, Chive dumplings, Siu mai, Xiao long bao soup dumpling, pot stickers, & egg rolls}
author: Trang Ashley P.

description: SO GOOD!! and incredibly affordable. we tried the cilantro shrimp dumplings by suggestion of the woman helping us and they were amazing. we also had the regular shrimp dumplings, pork soup, and steamed pork buns. we got the food to go, but once we got back to our hotel we were so sad that we hadn't ordered more.
author: Alex D.

description: I have to give the food top stars, but a couple other things made it 4 instead of 5. Food was awesome at amazing prices. But a couple workers were eating by me and throwing bones across the small room aiming for the trash can. And they missed sometimes...So if you're a germophob you may want to get it to go.
author: Garni S.

description: If you are looking for hole in the wall dim sum to go, look no further. Delicious Dim Sum was great and the har gow was perfect. You can tell a lot about a dim sum establishment by how well their har gow holds up during a Togo order. When I got and order of har gow and shu mai, they were piping hot and not over done in anyway. No need for soy sauce as it was seasoned very well. I spent 4.50$ for this yummy breakfast.
author: Greg C.

description: Dim sum is one of my favorites and this place did not disappoint. The portions are good and you get your money's worth.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Workers here are rude and their bbq pork barely had any meat inside. The prices here are a bit pricey for the quality. I wouldn't recommend this place as it is a take out place only and there are no seating available inside. I wouldn't return if I had to because their name is so misleading...

THEIR DIMSUM IS NOT DELICIOUS.
author: Noelle Y.

description:
So looks like Yelp just alerted me to the poor food safety here. But at some point who cares. The food was good and dirt cheap. Not sure if I should still recommend given the review coming in this month, but when I went in January - this place was pretty solid. We ordered the yutou gao, shumai, shrimp dumplings, xiaolongbao, rice balls, and chashao bao.

It's very much take out/grab-n-go. There is only two small tables in the back. The staff mostly speaks Chinese but feel free to point and nod.
author: Judy S.

description:
Wednesday morning and about to head home from a long weekend visit with no dim sum yet.  Had to fix that.  Yelp reviews were positive so I took a chance on this gritty-looking hole-in-the wall shop down the hill from Stockton Street.

Line was short.  Ordered two shrimp dumplings, two vegetable dumplings, a steamed sticky rice with pork, and a fried radish cake.  None were as hot as I would have liked, but all were tasty and filling.

There was one small table in the back which I shared with two other tourists already eating there.  This place is no frills, but fine for what I wanted.

Most of the customers were ordering take-out, and I would too if I knew a nice nearby park.
author: John S.

description: Simply amazing! We walked in just as they were closing up - lights already off. When I asked if they were done for the day (it was 6:00!) the lady ushered us in, turned on the lights and was ready to help us in any way. We got the shrimp dumplings and the shrimp w cilantro. Both good but I would push my mama off a cable car for more shrimp dumplings. After ringing us up she turned out the lights, locked up behind us, and she was gone.
author: G S.

description: I've been here twice. Quality is excellent and the price can't be beat. You can eat like a king for around $10/person here.
author: Jasper P.

description:
Pretty good and cheap dim sum. We got 2 of the chive dumplings, 3 of the shrimp dumplings, one bbq pork bun, and 2 fried pork potstickers (pan fried dumplings) for only $7!!!! My favorite was definitely the chive dumplings. The shrimp dumplings were also pretty tasty. I highly recommend both. I was sad they ran out of the bun with eggs and settled with the bbq pork bun. It was just ok. Not much complex flavor to it. Same with the pork potstickers. 

We took it to go and it all heated up well in a steamer pot (no microwave in our AirBnb) for breakfast the next day. It was filling split in half for me and my husband. 

My only complaint is that the ladies there weren't exactly friendly and helpful. When asked a question, it was brisk, and dare-I-say, begrudgingly answered. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Lan K.

description: This place has very affordable dim sum. Workers are polite. No where to sit except one table and some chairs up against the wall. One container of chili sauce on that one table (you would think there would be little containers ready to go). The shrimp dumplings were at the same level as other places, the pork dumplings were very plain, the chive dumpling was good.
author: Beth M.

description:
When in Chinatown, eat Chinese food! My little brother lives within walking distance of Chinatown and we found Delicious Dim Sum randomly as we were walking and we ended up coming back here twice during our short stay in San Francisco. This was my first time eating dimsum at a to-go place. I had my doubts but they were blown away. To-Go is just as good as dining in at a fancy dim sum restaurant! Because we didn't speak Chinese, we opted for the point and eat technique which worked out just fine for us. 

Their pork steamed buns are absolutely delicious. Just the right amount of filling and seasoned just right. Shrimp haw gow. So good! Shrimp was fresh, plump and tender. Shu Mai. Again, very good. It didn't even need any dipping sauce. It had a ton of flavor that we just ate ours without any soy sauce or hot mustard. The things that were just average were the xia long bao (soup dumplings) and the cha siu bao (bbq pork buns). There wasn't enough soup inside the dumplings and the skin was way too thick. As for the bbq pork buns, i found the whole thing to be too sweet. Besides that, our meal was very affordable and kept us full for until lunch time. I'll definitely be back in the area and this place has inspired me to look for more to-go dim sum spots in LA county! 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description:
Cheap to go dim sum that is pretty tasty! Our office always orders this on random fridays and we just call in advance with our big order and pick it up. They usually have it ready unless it is really busy that day. We ordered from them often enough for them to remember my name =X 

We get the usuals like pork siu mai, ha gow, lo ma gai (banana leaf wrapped rice), some fried goodies, rice noodle rolls, chive dumplings, etc. All very good at a good price! We usually order about 80 dollars worth of stuff for 15 people! woo!!! that is a good deal! 

We'll be back =P
author: Judy W.

description:
I'm not sure how this place got so many good reviews. Walked in and only one old lady was moving dumplings around. Just stood there for a while as she continued to move dumplings, ignoring me. She then asked what I wanted in Cantonese. I'm not sure how someone who doesn't speak the language would fare very well. I'm sure if you started speaking in English, they'd be able to understand. I just continued to order in Cantonese so it would be easier for her. 

I would recommend telling her all that you want to order at one time. I was telling her my order as she was getting my items and she got upset with me because she had to rearrange things in my to go box. Honestly, not sure what the big deal was. I only ordered 6 items and they all fit comfortably into the small container she started prepping them in. She didn't even have to move from a small to a large. And she rudely grumbled that I should have just told her all at once from the beginning. Just really really rude!!! 

As for food: it was pretty tasty. Though I ordered the beef cheong fun and it didn't come with the black sauce I normally see it with. Because of this, the noodle was just so so DRY and unbelievably chewy. I had a hard time eating it without the sauce to wet and flavor it, that I ended up giving up after a few bites. The har gow, sui mai, and char sui bow were fairly tasty. It would have been nice if they had some hot sauce available because I normally don't eat dim sum without a lot of hot sauce.
author: S. S.

description: A tiny little place, glad we didn't miss it.  Went back a second time while we were in town.  Inexpensive, good portion size, menu also in English but no photos.  Shrimp cilantro dumpling was excellent.  Only complaint was hard cartilage bits in bbq pork buns and shu mai but they were both excellent otherwise.  The potstickers could be better flavored but were still decent.  Soup dumplings were excellent, Shrimp noodle and shrimp chive dumplings were good too.
author: Lurley L.

description:
A friend and I came here during Memorial Day weekend because why not get some good dim sum while in SF near China town?

Glad we stopped in here. If you're looking for sit down dim sum with the carts, then don't go here. It's a small place in which you pick and choose what you want. And they put it into a plastic to go container. 

Because we were craving so much We ordered a little bit of everything :) I'd have to say that their shumai and shrimp dumplings were quite larger than I expected, which was even better for me because it was also really good!  

As for seating, Sorry, there's only one table inside there, so it's best to go find some seats by the park a couple blocks away! It's more of a walk in, order, and eat outside type of place. :) 

****
If you get nervous when it comes to communication, you may be a bit nervous here. They pretty much speak more Chinese than English, but pointing and picking out what you want is easy! 

It does not look as clean as most places, but most really good authentic foods get that. I did see a couple days ago, after heading here To eat that they got a poor food rating. I think it may be from their floors or food storage of refrigerated/frozen meats. Maybe. Not sure. I say go in and see how you feel about it :)
author: Krystal B.

description:
Dim sum here is excellent! One of the few dim sum places in Chinatown that i always go to. My favorite is the chives dumpling.

The buns can come on the dry side at times but it is still good.

The place itself doesn't look very fancy but it shouldnt be a concern since it isn't a place for dining in.

One complaint is that they always never give us forks. Im not sure if they actually forget, expects us to eat with our hands, or if they are just cheap.

**I'm not sure why there are pictures posted on here that says $5.99 for all-you-can eat. I'm pretty sure this place doesn't have that deal and it is posted for a different place.
author: Allie Y.

description: I found a long, black hair in my sticky rice. It was the last thing I had to eat, and it made me regret the whole meal.
author: Julia N.

description:
Nothing more satisfying than getting great dim sum at a SUPER CHEAP price! This is a no frills place with some tables in the back.

There was a short line when I got there at noon but the line moves really fast. The lady that took my order spoke English. She was really patient while I picked out my dim sum too and saying what some of things were when we pointed to it.

We ordered a TON of food that was stuffed in a plastic container - steamed shrimp dumplings (my favorite!), shumai, sticky rice, fried dumplings with chives, barbecue pork buns, and sesame seed ball with red bean inside. We were so full and it all came out to only $11.50!

Definitely check out Delicious Dim Sum if you are in Chinatown! Just as good as Good Mong Kok Bakery without the long line.
author: Linda X.

description:
I was visiting SF with a friend who swears by this place.  We took the 15 minute walk to Chinatown, and found this nondescript dim sum shop.

The two staff members that helped us were both very friendly and spoke great English making our transaction much easier!  My friend and I bought several boxes of dim sum for under $30.  They had a huge variety, and no wait.  My friend and I ate a few pieces on the spot, and traveled back to Nevada with our remaining dim sum and ate it that night for dinner after reheating it.  

Clean shop, friendly staff, great dim sum.  I'll be back!
author: Kathryn R.

description:
Great dim sum, great price too!  Shrimp and Cilantro was the best.

Limited seating, most people were doing take away.
author: David S.

description:
Hands down the best takeout dim sum place in SF. 

It's siu mai has a better ratio of shrimp to pork and mixed more evenly compared to other dim sum places siu mais.

I'd say its siu mais are on par with HK lounge I and better than HK lounge II. 


The only downside is it's variety but you can easily cross the street and grab the others here.
author: Vi T.

description: There is only one desk for eating so prepare to take food away. The chicken feet is really delicious! The service is OK. Food matches the price.
author: Tianjia C.

description:
Taking advice from Yelp has its ups and downs. This was a down moment. 

Decided to try this place out during my rare stop in Chinatown. Waited in a short line and being hungry (damn you stomach!), put in an order for four pieces of every steamed dim sum item they had available that morning. Don't be shocked: it didn't turn out to be that much. The server was able to fit everything into two take out containers. All the items were jammed in there together willy-nilly, but I don't mind, it's the Chinese take out way. However, those two containers cost $35!! That's a lot of money for take out dim sum! I buy all the time from Oakland Chinatown and I know that same amount would not have not cost me more than $25 at my usual place in Oakland. I guess rent is more expensive in SF so...

After arriving home, I was excited to give everything a try but first bite into the veggie rice roll (sorry, I don't know what the name is in English), I was immediately disappointed. The roll was mushy with no bounce-back or "chewiness" that a good roll should have. That was pretty evident when I saw it breaking apart as she was lifting it. The Har Gow (shrimp dumpling) was not bad. It was filled with actual chunks of shrimp instead of ground up or minced bits like other places so that made it a notch better than a lot of places. All the rest of the dumplings were all mediocre- not bad but not anything memorable either. 

With the amount of choices in Chinatown, I'm definitely not going back and trying my luck somewhere else next time.
author: Consumer X.

description:
Delicious dim sum is as good as its name. Truly authentic, no English, no menu, very affordable  (downright cheap), very good taste, variety, etc. Great to see what others get while in line to broaden your horizons.

 I had been on a search for good dim sum that was also affordable and this was the best of the 6 places I have been in the China Town neighborhood. 

No seating all takeout.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I've been coming here for years now, and this place isn't as good as it used to be. Perhaps the lady who served me didn't understand me, but when I asked her for vegetable/ vegetarian bun in Chinese, she said sure. After she gave me the buns, my mom asked for pork buns and the server said the buns in my hand was vegetable and pork buns. 

I gave the buns to my mom instead since I didn't want any meat in my buns. When we got our change back, the lady put the coins on the glass counter for us to reach. Basically service here is just really bad.

Pros:
- Short line

Cons:
- Quality went down
- Horrible service
author: Nicole S.

description: Legit authentic dim sum. And the prices are incredible! So glad someone turned us on to this place. It is truly a hidden gem.
author: Aaron V.

description: Another great option for din sum on the run.  Came here with a group of friends, hiked SF's many steep hills!  Powered our way back to the Lyon Street Steps.
author: Em J.

description:
It's take-out dim sum and it's good.

It's near where I work and when I craving a snack after work, sometimes I find myself here.  At the end of the day when the options are more limited, the dim sum isn't quite as good as earlier in the day but it's still pretty satisfying.

I would recommend any of the traditional dim sum options.  It's flavorful and done well here.
author: Phillip N.

description:
Cheap, fast, and yummy! I cant even name the items I got because I don't know chinese so I just pointed what I wanted to the lady who worked there. 

Everythin sooo good. My friend and I sat down in their only table with no shame lol literally sat down next to the workers while they eat and chat in chinese. I love the chili sauce that they have there too.
author: Debbie D.

description: Be prepared to use ONLY cash. There was no sign saying cash only. The food was good but ask for more than one paper plate! The soy sauce soaks right through and the plate ends up ripping! The plastic forks are very flimsy so makes it hard to eat. Customer service was not that good either. Very bummed.
author: Jaymie A.

description:
Not that delicious. Here's why. 

You order at the counter up front. They pile your selections ona couple of (plastic) plates. Then they hand you PAPER plates for eating. By the time you sit down, 30 seconds later, everything is cold. Then you put your soy and chili sauce on your paper plate, and your plate wets out. Then you eat your cold dim sum on your soggy plate. Sound appetizing? It's not. 

Now, if one got this stuff for takeout and reheated it, it might be a completely different story.
author: Allison W.

description:
Dim sum is one of those things that I have just recently been introduced to. Who would have ever thought that I would be caught dead eating chicken feet?

I recently came to this dim sum place by recommendation of one of my best friends. The best way to do any kind of dim sum is to go with a big group of people and have someone who knows what theyre doing order.

We ordered:

- Shumai (DELICIOUS...SO GOOD. These are breakfast like pork dumplings)
- Chicken feet (a little too boney but very delicious!)
- Rice wrapped in seaweed (tasty!)
- A little chicken stew thing with chillis. Really good as well


Overall we were stuffed by the time we left and yet our bill came to a little under 11 dollars each.
author: Alba C.

description:
Pathetic Dismally Tiny Selection with one lonely table in the far back.

Ordinary...not delicious. Highly overrated by Yelpers & for me, a near useless hole-in-the-wall.

If you are dim enough to want to reheat cold Dim Sum home, you are dim enough to shop here.....unless you can score the one spot in the back & are just in the mood for what they 
have on hand.

Fresh...yes.

..tasty....not really.  

Cheap.... so what?   I want variety!

I took a long gander based on the ridiculous overrated Yelp reviews & headed
straight across the street where they had amazing fresh Taisonese style Chic feet

plus lots of other fresh choices...all for a few bucks.

Why this hole gets 4 stars & the better one only 2 is beyond me....

Obviously the real Chinese crowd is not Yelping, since they neither speak English, nor Yelp.

This place is for Bananas & Tourists.

If I am going to dine in a hole in the wall....I got to have a seat, variety, tasty treats.....

PASS & LOOK AROUND!
author: Paul M.

description:
Now I will admit, my first impression of the place on the outside was that it looked kind of janky on the outside...so the food might not be good. But, being San Francisco, you have to make use of a small space. This is not a place you can sit down in (no joke there's only one dinner table in the whole building). 

I was happily surprised by the cheap prices and the good quality of Dim Sum. My girlfriend and I agreed that this was some of the best Dim Sum that we have tasted. We tried the Shrimp Balls, Pork Balls, Veggie Balls, Pork Buns, and Sesame Balls. They were so good that we had to get seconds (we waited in line again, by the way).

If you stumble upon this small place in San Francisco's Chinatown, try it!
author: Charith S.

description:
I woke up and the thought kept nagging at me like a child repeatedly chanting for a cookie: We had to get dim sum today.

I surfed Yelp and headed to Chinatown.

A few blocks in, I smacked my forehead, realizing Saturday is market day, I should know better but we were committed (and hopefully *I* wouldn't be committed after searching for parking in the very heart of Chinatown).

It only took 4 times around the block which, given the primetime food shopping day, I considered a stroke of unbelievable good luck. My child has amazing parking karma!

All the signage was in Cantonese. And a line quickly forming outside the door, everyone was Asian. Good sign.

We bought a surfeit of things, an embarrassment, really: 2 orders each ha gao, shrimp with chives, shrimp with veggies, 1 order each BBQ pork buns, shanghai dumplings and 2 sesame balls and 3 orders of shu mai and one of this gelatinous noodle thing which after one bite, I'm still not sure what it is and what it's filled with.

The unsmiling lady behind the counter produced her trusty, scotch-taped, broken screen calculator as I readied a couple of $20 bills. 

I was stunned when she said, "$18.46."

Are you KIDDING me? I was wondering if that little calculator was truly broken and not just suffering from a cracked screen. Less than $20 for all of that?

Some wrappers -especially on the Shanghai dumplings - were a little thick and chewy, the BBQ pork puns (steamed only, no baked) the bun too sticky and flavorless but oh, the filling inside was savory and incredible. 

All the flavors were fantastic and each dumpling, generously overstuffed with big chunks of shrimp, lots of spinach, heaping portions of of succulent minced pork and ginger. 

And the SIZE of these dumplings, oh my goodness! Any dim sum you've ever seen? Double the size. The sesame ball, for example, was nearly the size of a tennis ball (my little boy ate both, but I had a taste and it was fantastic).

There was no seating, just a utility table at the back of the place that appears to be used for packing up "to-go" orders. I thought seating was limited but no, it's non-existent.

No matter, we were just as happy headed home to tuck into our buffet of delicious dim sum. I'd definitely go back but not on market day.

Even after we shared a generous plate with a neighbor, my little boy and I still have enough for a light lunch or dinner. 

I think this place might be cash only. 

Food: 3.75 stars
Value: 5 stars
Service: 2.5 stars
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I love Dim Sum, and when I found this place on Yelp, quickly decided to go pick up some food on a Saturday morning. Expecting there to be a line, I called my order ahead. Now, when I ordered, I thought that saying 1 sui mai = 1 dumpling, and so on. Nope- if you look at more recent pictures of the menu (they have no website), a lot of the dumplings and stuff come in 3. 

So I ended up with a ridiculous amount of dim sum-almost 3x what I was trying to order! But this place is so cheap that this crazy amoun of food (good enough for 3-4 meals probably) was about $20! Mind blown!

Random stuff: The crowd was actually not too crazy on a Saturday morning, so calling ahead didn't make a huge difference but I guess that on days it is busier, it's a good idea. You can eat there too as they have a few tables. It is cash only so make sure you stop at an ATM before hand. Parking is busy in the area, but not impossible. Cars seem to leave fairly often so you can find parking at a meter; I got parking pretty easily (just went around the block once and then found parking right out front).

The food? It is good- not the best dim sum I have had, but solid. The har gow, sui mai, and pork buns have very generous amounts of meat and shrimp in them which is awesome. They don't have the most extensive menu- I missed the rice noodles which are one of my favorite things to order in particular and not too many veggie options either. The baked pork buns were only ok- I like them to be a little crispier, but the filling was quite good. Out of the stuff I tried, the sui mai was probably my favorite. The taro cake (which I didn't originally order on the phone but added once I got to the store) was really great also.

Consensus: Pretty good dim sum at an awesome price. No real waiter service or anything, and cash only, but I would definitely come back here in the future.
author: Seema U.

description: Cannot confirm completely but I believe this place is CLOSED. There was grafitti on the window and it looked abandoned. I really wanted to try this place but it was closed and yelp didn't even know. Unless they were just closed for today.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
We had no idea how lucky we were to snag the one and only table in the entire place until a family that looked like they were straight out of a National Lampoon's Vacation movie mad dogged us until we left. Or were we really lucky? I just don't know. In our defense, we were the only people in this joint when we walked through the door, which didn't last long - the place was quickly swarmed. 

Be aware, there is absolutely no English anywhere in this place. Not on the menu board and certainly not exchanged when placing your order - this is a point and smile kind of place where you hope for the best. Well, we got some good, some alright, and some that were just kind of blah. The saving grace would have to be the small jar of homemade chili paste that our table devoured and could make just about anything taste tolerable. Unfortunately we plowed through this paste so quickly that I ate my final few bites without exposing it for what it really was... average. 

Don't look at the health score, you'll freak. *cough, cough, 82* 

I'm with Melanio, 3.5 and you can't beat the price for three people - $15.00.
author: Brad B.

description:
Great selection of take-out dim sum. We had the Shumai (which was very fresh and full of flavour), the shrimp/ vegetables (my favourite!) as well as a pork bun and sticky rice balls. 
We were so full, and the lot cost us only $10.50. Bargain! Make sure you top it off with an egg tart from the bakery a couple of doors down. 

Side note- the is only one table, plus a couple of extra chairs-- I wouldn't recommend coming in with a group expecting to sit down, or you might be disappointed.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
I had never had dim sum before and while visiting San Francisco it was on my list of things to do. 

Went here and was impressed. Won't lie there is like stated before no seating area. My daughter and I did find a chair and say there any ways. I'm sure it helps to know what you want when going here because there is NO menu in English. I just pointed to things that I had seen on Yelp pictures. 

Yelpers did not disappoint everything was so so good and yes very cheap.
author: Jessica B.

description: Great Dim Sum!  The shrimp dumplings and sticky rice were awesome!  You may have to fight over the one table, but it is totally worth it!  Staff was friendly.
author: Stuart R.

description:
So here's the deal - my first exposure to Dim Sum was at the mecca of all that is dim sum in this word: Din Tai Fung (http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-seattle?hrid=Ztw__27dPCffBrItC2UWRg&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)). I'm a firm believer, having visited Din Tai Fung locations in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seattle, that it will never be topped, but Delicious Dim Sum provides a (very) cheap and tasty alternative. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

No frills here, let alone any chairs! English menu? Forget about it. Need some time to decide? Step aside friend there are hungry folks in line! My visit to Delicious Dim Sum was probably about as close as I've ever come to recreating my experiences during a stint in some seedy Shanghai dumpling establishments, but know that that's not necessarily a bad thing. Above all else, Delicious Dim Sum is authentic in their atmosphere, their pricing, and their product. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

Goodness me. To be honest? I have a suspicion that they make up their (very affordable) pricing on the fly. I opted for six pork dumplings and a bbq pork bun, and after a very quick evaluation, the woman behind the counter asked me for $5. Five dollars! This was at the very least a decent sized meal given the fact that dumplings expand after you've eaten them, and I couldn't believe it only cost me a fiver in San Francisco no less. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Was it the best I've ever had? It wasn't, but it sure as heck wasn't bad. The pork dumplings were delicious, and while they lacked the soupy liquid that's common in XiaoLongBao elsewhere, the flavor was there, and it was good. The bbq pork bun was a bit subpar in that it was pretty dry and stuck to the rice paper to a degree that was a bit off-putting, but all in all this was good stuff. Single Star Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

Typically I'd only dish out this star if this was top tier, which I'll argue that Delicious Dim Sum is not, but given the value here, the variety, and the acceptable quality, I'd be lying if I said I wouldn't stop by daily if I could do. Star Granted. 

If I could afford it? Yes - it's better than Blue Bell, and that's not something you hear often from someone who has spent any significant amount of time in Texas. Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: Has been my favorite dim sum place in Chinatown for years.  Granted, you need to know what you are looking for since the ladies behind the counter speak very little english and the pressure to order is on.  But otherwise the dim sum is solid and super cheap.  Essentially no seating inside, save for a dirty 4 seat table, so I always take it to go and eat in Portsmouth Square.
author: Jason S.

description:
At first glance, a hole in the wall and pretty standard dim sum. Not only that, you can't read the menu unless you can speak/read chinese. Once you pay though, you'll be pleasantly surprised at how dirt cheap your order was. I ordered 2 steamed bbq pork buns, 2 shumai, 2 shrimp dumplings, 3 shao long buns, 1 turnip cake, and 2 chicken feet for a mere $10. 

The dim sum itself isn't spectacular but they are very meaty. The shrimp dumplings have huge shrimp and the shumai are enormous; in other words, you will have lots of meat. 

Note that this is not a sit down restaurant, you order and go and I think it's cash only.
author: Derek T.

description: Pretty good dim sum, OK customer service. Not the best dim sum I've had in Chinatown but still good.
author: Joni W.

description: Very bad!  The pork and beef shumai were both terrible!  A lot if bad tasting meat with no delicacy or spice -- just hunks of tough meat and did not seem fully cooked.  Pork and veggie bun was too much bun...but considering that the filling was awful, perhaps that was a good thing.  My husband liked the shrimp and cilantro dumpling.  Not recommended.  Cash only.
author: Domenica P.

description:
Shrimp har gow!!! 

3pcs for $1.90

That is all...
author: Maria C.

description:
Awesome! Full of local Asian people, very typical dim sum. The one with shark and the shrimp one are the best for me! Veeeery cheap 

The place looks dirty! But nothing different compared to the other restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Maria Jose B.

description:
I like this place better than Good Mong Kok. It's way less greasy and didn't make me feel bloated afterwards. 

Shu Mai: 5/5 (best I've had in SF Chinatown)
Har gow: 4.5/5 (huge pieces of shrimp inside)
Chive and shrimp dumplings: 4/5 (would've been 5/5 if they weren't lukewarm)
Taro cakes: 3.5/5 (could be more pork and taro chunks inside, but good flavor)

Next time I'll be back with someone who speaks Cantonese... we couldn't read the menu so I just pointed at what we wanted, but the woman working behind the counter was very patient with us.
author: Selena S.

description: Very good Dim Sum, and very inexpensive.  Lots of dough vs filling ratio (again, this is inexpensive so that's fine, it's just a factor).  Service was needlessly unfriendly so I have taken a point off for that.  We don't expect much in that regard, but it was unpleasant enough to mention it.
author: Paige J.

description:
I have been going to this local family owned dim sum place since I moved here 10+ years ago. The place is very small with only couple of small tables, but great to take  dim sum to go! Normally just get three of each: shrimp dumplings, pork sui mai, beef sui mai, chive dumplings, steamed BBQ pork buns, and tunip cakes are very good and my usuals. Honestly their Shanghai XLB and pot stickers are not great cuz the dough is just too thick and Shanghai XLB is not juicy. So I usually skip these and other places serve better XLB and pot stickers. My whole family loves it too and they usually get dim sum from here if they are around Chinatown. The price is much much cheaper than you would have gone to a regular restaurant for dim sum. So great place for a quick togo order! 

I happened to attend the Foodie Adventure by Chris Milano's tour and this is one of the spots they all go to on their North Beach Chinatown tour. Just on a side note, the tour is not worth it at all for the price paid ($85 per person) because you could totally explore Chinatown North Beach at your own pace and have all the foods they gave for $10 bucks. I know this area well and did the tour because of my husband. 

Anyway, this place is great for quick inexpensive dim sums!!
author: Lena H.

description:
I was so excited about dim sum here and I wish our experience here was different. From the beginning we did not feel welcomed here in the least bit. The place itself seems more conducive for take out but we decided to eat here anyway. The place was dirty and really needed some TLC.

The lady attending the counter was brief and almost rushing us even though we were the only ones there. She barely gave us a chance to fully order.

We ordered the shrimp dumplings and a few other items. EVERYTHING went into the microwave......enough said.
author: Nasha W.

description:
We tried this restaurant because it was recommended to us by our guide from Free Tours By Foot. It's a modest establishment for takeout dim sum. We picked a number of items haphazardly, and ate at the only table in the shop (there were also a few chairs placed against the wall for customers who wanted to sit down).

Our verdict:
   Shrimp with cilantro dumpling -- very good
   Pork soup dumpling -- meh
   Tapioca cake (?) -- good
   Egg custard bao -- meh

We give them 3* for food and 5* for price (thus 4* average) because our total charge for the meal above was less than $7.
author: Trong D.

description:
April 12, 2014 Saturday - lunch 1:45 PM
3 adult

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars 

Background - Michael T, our Reno CM, just reviewed the place and it caught our attention.  Our drive from Reno to San Francisco straight here to have lunch, the beginning of our vacation, got here a little later than expected because the traffic.
 
Atmosphere - Very tiny place, probably can handle 8 to 10 customers in line before they end up out the door.  I was warned about only one table to sit at so we planned on walking and eating.  That one table was covered in trays of food being prepped so definitely not sitting there.  

Food
  Drinks - None, now I think about it I do not even remember seeing that as choice, but I could be wrong.

  Appetizer - none.

  My Main Course - Okay I do not know all the names, I just cared what was inside.  We ordered a variety of dim sum, pork, shrimp and even some sweet pork BBQ buns.  Trust me your want to eat them.      

  Dessert - none.

Service - The place was empty expect for the ladies working hard behind the counter.  Being late for lunch we were not rushed.  I have a feeling that they knew we did not speak Chinese.  I was worried that they would not speak English.  She lifted each tray showing us the dim sum explaining in one or two words such as pork or shrimp.  Then slowly we went through each tray telling her how many we wanted.  That was good enough for us.  Then she started doing some math in head to come up with a number.

Future - $8 to feed three, and so yummy.  I will be back.
author: Paul S.

description: Not quite the dim sum we were expecting but the food was good. The veggie dumplings and the honey walnut shrimp were very, very tasty!  We also ordered a shrimp clay pot but found out too late that it was filled with bok choy and neither my husband nor I like bok choy in the least.
author: Kari H.

description: We must've gone on an off day? Seems like the majority get a good meal here.  But I can't image all the other days having properly cooked meat and not ours. For us, the meat was undercooked, and dry? old?  We felt slightly queasy and did not finish.  It was later in the day (3pm).  Sanitation secondary.  I witnessed the woman behind the counter take swigs from a metal bowl and spit out something green into the trash.  Ugh.  Hope that's not what was in my shu mai.
author: Omar G.

description: Love this place.  I call places like this Dim Sum Deli's.  I stop by this place overtime I'm in the area.  They have been consistent in quality for the last 20 years.
author: David K.

description:
I'm not sure why Delicious Dim Sum has such a solid 4 star rating, when the place is extremely dirty, has little dim sum variety, and poor quality / taste / value for dim sum. They have a few sad deep fried / bakery options, and a handful of take out dim sum items. 

If you order in, they give you a dirty unwashed plastic tray lined with a thin piece of plastic for you to eat on. Sit at the only table in the restaurant. Grab a plastic fork and you can use the condiments (there is one soy sauce in a tea kettle and some red chili paste). 

I could overlook service, cleanliness, and lack of dim sum choice - but the food is just not good. If you're looking for cheap, take-out dim sum, there are a million other places in Chinatown - this place is not so delicious, and I would encourage you try elsewhere.

Some eating guidelines should you forego my advice to avoid this place.
- I would maybe get again: siu mai
- If I was starving I would eat the: shrimp dumpling (har gao), soup dumplings (not soupy at all), green moon shaped dumpling
- I would never order: Shrimp noodles (ha cheung)
author: Jess C.

description: Best shrimp dumplings and shrimp cilantro dumplings hands down. Dim sums are also VERY affordable.
author: Tiffany K.

description: This is a really small place on a side street with limited seating (more upstairs).  We had no idea what we were ordering but all 3 of us had 5 large dumplings each and the whole bill was $14!  And everything was amazing.
author: Stacy C.

description:
A micro counter, steaming and boxing trays of dollar treats for you to take elsewhere. Seriously, it's wee. For those non-versed in omnipresent dim sum selections, the staff will patiently translate the Chinese-only paper menus tacked to the wall, or go basket by basket in describing what's avail.

Now, I'm going do that thing you kinda have to do with grab & go dim sum joints: individual morsel super power rating yes!

Char siu bao (3 stars): steamed only, very doughy with surprisingly little pork. Solid flavor, though. 
Har gow (3): Beautifully textured shrimp wontons; mighty wide lip on the wrapper (understuffed, a la pork buns?)
Shrimp and chive dumplings (4): bright and herbal with potent garlic, ginger and greens. Could have downed a bucket of these.
Potstickers (3): Heartiest of the bunch meatwise with an air-light, delicate flavor. Missed my shot at pairing with the dipping sauce, so shame on me.
Shrimp noodle (2): Waaaaay too gummy; large shrimp lumped the whole shebang within moments.

Just fine eats with no regrets on the trip. The next dim sim pilgrimage will find me seeking other options in Chinatown.
author: Damien S.

description: We tried a bit of everything. The food was decent, restaurant small and kinda dirty, good service and the service was nice to recommend a few things. Overall, a good experience but probably won't be back for more.
author: Susannah H.

description: Everything here is great, a nice hole in the wall dimsum place!
author: Justin C.

description: Best service out of all the dim sum places I've been to in Chinatown. We didn't feel rushed. And they gave us soy sauce and sriracha sauce and forks.
author: Jessica S.

description: Honestly, the dim sum wasn't great. The only comfort was that the counter lady was more patient than the others that can be found in Chinatown (if that's even any comfort, lol). But I have to say, the chili is good, so if you have no other choice than to come here, do heap on lots of it - it'll help.
author: Keni T.

description: This is our go-to spot for a dim sum cafe in San Francisco. Do not expect any carts here. There is one table with a few chairs. If they're not using the table to prepare food or deliveries, you can sit. Price is amazing as well as the taste.
author: Ken H.

description: $5.00 for 3 shrimp dumplings, 3 shau Mai, 1 pork dumpling and 1 Bbq bun! I wish we had something like this is Seattle...or do we? It's nice to be able to just walk in, pick out your order and be on your way... There shrimp dumpling were very tasty!
author: Dana M.

description: A great bargain. Got what we wanted and fed a family of 4 for $13. Including drinks!  Shrimp dumplings were amazing.
author: Bob B.

description:
Food: 5 stars,
Ambiance/Decor: 1 star,
My Yelp star rating: Based on food only. 

As a nearby local, I'm a bit apprehensive about giving this place it's well deserved 5 star rating, as I don't want the lines to get long. But I'll be an altruistic Yelper and say this place is just plain ole great for take out dim sum. They only have a couple tables inside, so its basically a take out joint (I'm lucky to live nearby). Everything they make is at the top of the game, so don't worry about ordering something that doesn't look entirely familiar...don't worry, it'll be tasty. Bring cash and your appetite, and order away!
author: Joe P.

description: This place was yucky. The dim sum I ate I spit out. I Tried the potsticker. Also tried the long rice roll w shrimp.  Was actually disgusting. I wish I could rewind time and not had the "delicious" dim sum.
author: S S.

description: Good dim sum at really cheap prices. It's not the best quality, but 100% worth for what you're paying. I would definitely stop by for a quick snack if you're in the area and craving dim sum!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
The name says it all!!

Located in the heart of Chinatown, this no-frills place offers a variety of tasty dimsum for insanely cheap prices (we got over 20 pieces of dimsum, a sesame rice ball and an almond cookie for $17). If you can't read Chinese, you'll have to ask the ladies behind the counter to describe each item, but trust me and just go with the har gow (juicy bites of shrimp wrapped in a translucent dough), pork shumai, shrimp and chive dumplings, sesame balls with red bean and the buttery almond cookies. Also, don't expect to sit down and dig into your dimsum at the store since there is only ONE table inside. But no worries, you can gobble down your dimsum as you walk around Chinatown! 

As an Asian, I'd have to say the best dimsum ever!! 

Tip: cash only
author: Essie K.

description:
I did a search on yelp for possible Dim Sum joints nearby, it seems like these To-Go dim sum joint are popular in this area.  We picked Delicious Dim Sum as their name suggested, perhaps just the closest walking distance.

Many of the items were out, so we grabbed a bunch of dim sum per the counter lady's recommendation.  Har Gow was delicious, and the skin was not too thick.  Xiaolongbao was meh.  The longer dumpling was ok.  The pan-fried veggie dumpling was quite decent, a bit greasy though.  A solid and quick Dim Sum experience.
author: Tony L.

description:
Words of wisdom from a Hong Kong girl who grew up in 626 -
If you think this is delicious dim sum, then you've never had real dim sum before. 

My parents have long instilled in me that one can determine the authenticity of a dim sum shop by trying their BBQ pork bun. Hence, this was the first item I tried here, and boy was I disappointed. 

A breakdown of the BBQ pork bun (cha siu bao):
- 80% bun, 10% pork, 10% BBQ sauce 
- Dry and tasteless bun. I nearly choked upon taking my second bite ): 

Same review goes for their veggies and pork bun (choy yok bao/cai rou bao). 

Sigh, I guess my hunt for legit dim sum in SF Chinatown continues, while I dream of moist & flavorful cha siu baos from HK and 626.

On the other hand, I'm giving this place two stars because an average meal in SF costs about $15, whereas this meal only cost me $1.40!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Normally I would be edgy of trying any place that calls itself Delicious, but this place is simply beautiful.

The ladies in this store have been doing this forever, as evidenced by the extremely crappy and worn out interior and equipment.  If you look in the back you can see them making the dim sum by hand.

Dim sum here only costs 60c a piece!  You can walk in with $5 and be set for the day.

In true Asian style, the food also comes served in these wonderful plastic bags.

Compared to some of the other takeout dim sum places in this area (see my other reviews), this one seems to be the best one.  By far.  Next time I'm in San Fran, this is definitely on my list.  I'm sniffling away tears as I write this review.
author: Edward L.

description:
It's in the name--Delicious Dim Sum! The only reason it's not 5 stars is because there is no where to eat at this place; you have to take your delicious dim sum to go.

We ordered 6 pieces each of the har gow, Sui Mai, and gow choi; 4 BBQ steam buns and 2 of the shrimp rice noodle...all for under $22! All of it was yum, but my favorite was the shrimp noodle!

We ended up walking just a few blocks to the Portsmouth Square Park Plaza, aka "heart of Chinatown," sat on a bench and enjoyed the sights and sounds as we chowed down; best experience I've had in SF as a tourist!
author: Michelle S.

description: Picked up some shrimp and pork "soup" dumplings to bring home for dinner back at home in Tahoe. Popped them into my new wok steamer I bought in Chinatown,  and had a perfect dinner. Will be buying 3 dozen next time we get to the city! Thanks for the great tips local  Yelpers!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Despite the fact that some of my less-adventurous family members insisted on going to a sit-down dim sum place, I just knew I had to get some of this first. I had it the last time I was in SF, and it was just a divine as I remembered!

You may know exactly what you want, but I don't really. Here's my go-to game plan, you can steal it if you need to:

1. Say some words like "pork & chives" and "shumai" and then point at some other good looking things. The ladies will understand.
2. Get way more than you think you should. Get that weird thing that you've never tried too. Get double of what you know you like.
3. Pay $5-10 (if you got the more than you think you should amount)
4. Try and squirt some of the sauce that's sitting on the only table into your styrofoam containers. 
5. Go somewhere nice, or literally stand in the street like I do, and eat those delicious morsels. 

See? Simple. You don't get to sit down, the service is kind of crazy, the place is tiny, but it's a glorious 5 minute adventure that ends with you getting some amazing dim sum. Worth it in my book.
author: Lesley W.

description: Delicious dim sum and great prices. Steamed BBQ buns were my favorite.  It's purely take out and cash only.
author: Aubry N.

description: Simply cheap and delicious! The BBQ beef buns, shrimp dumplings and pot stickers are amazing. Grab it to go and eat it directly in front to take in the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Stepped in here one lunchtime because there was a line out of the door! Tried the shark fin dumplings and they were delicious (and insanely cheap at $2).
The scallion cake is out of this world. Seriously it's so good (and only $1.50)
I came again with a friend one evening and they were sold out of pretty much everything which was a shame - so make sure you get here early in the day!
author: Ellie B.

description: The best walk up dim sum restaurant in SF, in my humble opinion, better than anything in the avenues. The fillings and especially the skin is superb. Early morning on a Sunday is the best for parking, traffic, crowds, etc.
author: Adrian Z.

description:
Decent, fresh and CHEAP! My friends and I had to grab a quick lunch before the Giants game on a Sunday and we were looking for a quick dim sum place. Delicious Dim Sum hit the spot. Even though they're not a sit down restaurant by any means, you can drop it, order (or point at what you want) and you're OTD (OUT THE DOOR) in like 5 minutes (depending on the crowd). There were a couple of ladies behind the counter both looking annoyed so we (non-Chinese) ordered quick and shy-ed away from being picky.  

The Har Gow, Siu Mai, shrimp rice noodles, BBQ pork bao and fried dumplings were all good. We all thoroughly enjoyed eating the to-go dim sum before the game even though the Giants lost to the Marlins. It was a long drive back to LA!  :(
author: Ticha B.

description:
Disclaimer: I only ate one type of dumpling here,  because I was full from the icky food from a place literally across the street and wanted to wash away the bad food.

The pork dumplings I ate from here tasted good but we're nothing special. 

Practical considerations
This place is just a tiny shop without anywhere to sit,  really.  If you buy enough,  and they haven't run out of plastic containers,  you can take your food elsewhere, or eat your dumplings while standing on the sidewalk,  as many others were doing. Unfortunately for us, the woman working just put ours in a plastic bag. 

The people working may or may not speak English, and the food isn't labeled, which is fine with me,  since I'll eat nearly everything,  but some people have dietary restrictions and/or might find this stressful.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Very cheap and delicious dim sum! I believe it's cash only. This is cafe style, where you purchase it from a counter. But it's much cheaper than the restaurants where a cart comes around and you order off that.
author: Jon P.

description:
Convenience and prices trump everything.  
Any Chinatown local knows there is no shortage of dim sum stores and that certain places are known for certain things. I tried the beef siu mail and beef cheung fun (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) (hoped by bbq pork rice noodle, but only choices were shrimp and beef).  Yes, it was inexpensive at $3.90 for that loaded box.  
Two things that knocked it down a notch for me was a) packaged soy sauce - every dim sum dood (especially Ken K. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA)) knows that the rice noodle should be garnished with a sweet soy sauce and b) the meat color of that beef siu mai (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=XH16hbvuUNKT3BgLD0yz4g), which was a reddish pink and made me question, "Where's the beef?"
For me, the food was a three star experience and I probably should have read Chrerlynn N.'s (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg) review and ordered the Chiu Chow Fun Goh instead.  
Since my parents like their Chinese rice tamales (peanut and green bean, I believe), I will notch it up a half star to 3.5 stars and round up to 4, hoping that my next trip will be better.
author: Mike C.

description:
It's carry out only...and cash only I believe. They have the common dim sum dishes as well as a few baked goods.  The lines go out the door but go pretty quickly. I've seen plenty of non-Chinese speaking people go into the place so I think the employees know enough English to help out those of you who don't know Chinese. 

The food is great! It definitely beats the dim sum at a sit down restaurant in Chicago's Chinatown.
author: Kat A.

description:
The quality of the food was not good. Maybe we should have suspected with the all you can eat for $5.99. Somehow we still spent $20.

Long story short, both my boyfriend and I have spent the past hour puking up the dim sum rolls. 

Didn't even taste good. Do not recommend.
author: Audrey L.

description: Love all the dim sums here. Our hotel was in the NorthWest of San Francisco, but we drove all the way to Chinatown each morning during our stay to buy dim sums for breakfast. It's really worth the drive.
author: Nguyen H.

description: The owner is a character.  The food definitely is not your regular take out chinese.  The flavor profile is not what our palets were used to.  Some if the dishes were very good like the homemade noodle and beef.  However the beef chow mein was dry and had no beef.  The dining area is mixed the space and really makes you wonder.  Food settled well but will never go again.  I would recommend you feed your hunger somewhere else.
author: T R.

description: Small simple place for dim sum carry-out. Had sticky rice and turnip cake. Both outstanding! Open all day. Best dim sum price! Following up with tea tasting at TenRen on Grant just south of Jackson. Great Chinatown experience!
author: Louann T.

description: I went to Delicious Dim Sum after trying Good Mong Kok and wanting to hit up another place nearby. What I had was tasty, the only problem is I have no idea what I had. The menu is all in Chinese so I just kinda pointed to random things here and there.
author: Ryan P.

description: My grandma used to buy dim sum here when I was little, but I don't remember, my cousin told me. There was a long line out the door so my grandma must of been right, that's it's delicious! We bout $28 worth of dim sum and ate it on the street before watching the parade. My favorite was pan fried shrimp chives dumpling and the "shark fin" dumpling
author: Karen T.

description:
For the price, the dim sum here is definitely worth it! We brought back two tray containers stuffed with food for only $20, yay!

The vegetable dumplings were especially good. The only thing that wasn't so good was the rice noodle roll (chang fen in Mandarin) with shrimp, because there was too much rice noodle part and too few shrimp.

The shop itself looks pretty dingy and run-down... But I feel like most of these take-out dim sum places look the same, so oh well. Come here from cheap and yummy dim sum!
author: Ivonnie S.

description:
Food:  4
Service:  1

This was my third time here.  Food is consistently good, especially the Har Gow and the Shu Mai.  I went today specifically to pick up a box of Har Gow.  There were two women working (one older than the other).  The older woman helped me but said I need to wait 5 min while they cooked more Har Gow.  I said no problem so she boxed up the other things that I ordered, rang me up, I paid, and I waited.  Finally she gave me my bag and I walked out.  Not 2 min later, the older woman comes running down the block after me and said I need to come back to the store with her.  She doesn't really speak english so I thought she gave me someone else's bag.  Well, as it turned out, the OTHER worker thought I walked out without paying!  I told her that the older woman who came running after me down the block was the one who rang me up not more than 10 min ago!!!  Really?  The woman couldn't confirm or remember that I paid her?  And they don't give receipts so I couldn't really prove that I paid.  Finally the older woman apologized but it still bothered me.  I was embarrassed because there was a line out front but, more importantly, do not accuse me of being a thief!!  This experience today has really turned me off of this place which is too bad because their food is better than average.  Be forewarned of their poor service.
author: Christine A.

description: My husband went on a hunt for the best dim sum and someone pointed us here and it did not disappoint. Everything tasted, well, delicious! We were in and out quick with a ton of food for two people in a few minutes. Again, very very delicious indeed. We will definitely  be stopping by again when we are in town
author: Katie D.

description:
No frills. You walk in, order, and walk out. There is a small table in the back if you want to eat there, but I wouldn't suggest it.

We got pork buns and shrimp dumplings. Delicious.
author: Leana L.

description: Great dim sum ....incredibly cheap. Staff is efficient, but helpful. Only one table...mostly takeout. A great place to go.
author: Steve J.

description: Very tasty dim sum.  Try the shrimp and cilantro or the shrimp and chive.  One table in the back so better for take out.  Reasonable prices.
author: Tim P.

description:
Fast service. Pick what you want and it's boxed up right away. Pay by cash only. Great selection of traditional dim sum dishes all for cheaper than $1.50 a piece. Not too greasy but a bit on the sweet side leaving a mucus-y feeling in my mouth afterwards that traditionally could be washed down by hot tea. 
The ladies who worked behind the counter kept a straight face the whole time. We tried to make conversation and wish them a happy new year. No response. Sad. Oh well.
author: Eve T.

description:
There are some many choices when you wander through Chinatown however we were with some one who had been here before.

We headed straight to this joint and the distinguishing feature here was the queue of people out of the shop. We had a substantial order including Shrimp Changfen, Shao Long Buns, Shrimp Dumplings, Shrimp & Chive Dumplings and more.....and it was wonderful. It was as though one was eating in Asia, maybe even in Shanghai. We had heard about the Pork Buns however so had those before us - sadly they were all gone. 

It is all take out.....and it is such good value. We would not have spent $20 and we dined like kings. Fun, real value for money and great Asian food....
author: Mick A.

description:
Not much to choose from the day we stopped in.  All I can say is, fabulous har gow! 

The shrimp was so fresh, so sweet, so plump, and so tender.  

Ignore the smile-challenged lady behind the counter. 

I would double park and risk a parking ticket just to re-live that yummy dumpling!

To go only.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Love this place. It was in the middle of china town and I was so lucky to find parking right outside! Tiny interior, but it's kind of a grab and go thing. Super cheap and great dimsum! Definitely fixed my craving. The ladies behind the counter are super quick too.  

One thing I have as a suggestion though is that nothing on their "menu" is in English. So if it's your first time having dumplings or you don't know Chinese, it might be kind of difficult to order. Lucky for me, I've had dimsum before and I know what I like, but if I hadn't I'd be super confused.
author: Sherise D.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum is a simple and straight forward restaurant, much like its name.  It's tiny - there is only one table inside, so you'll probably be taking your order to-go.  There is usually just one lady at the front, with a second worker coming down periodically to refill the dim sum trays.  There are handwritten menus along the wall, and though they don't have any English menus, the lady at the counter will happily go through her entire dim sum selection and explain what each item is.

As others have mentioned, the food is very cheap.  My girlfriend and I ordered a bunch of food including xiu mai, shrimp dumplings, fried pork dumplings, noodle rolls and pork buns with a drink and the total came to 12 bucks!  That's hard to beat. And the food was delicious.  Everything was fresh and the dumplings were so flavorful.  I'm only slightly ashamed to admit that after stuffing myself I still ordered a pork bun to go as I was walking out.

If you're in Chinatown I'd definitely recommend checking this place out.  Just don't expect a place to sit!
author: Jay S.

description:
Awesome dim sum for take out. I kinda felt like Elaine on Seinfeld when she didn't know what to order with the soup Nazi. Hilarious episode if you're a Seinfeld fan. To translate, I felt under pressure know exactly what to order because the ladies are not patient. They rush you and stare at you until you tell them what you want. CASH ONLY.

Service aside, come on now, you're in Chinatown. Dim sum was just delicious!
author: Sharon B.

description: I am so happy I discovered this place on Yelp! I had a craving for Dim Sum and since we live on the boarder of Chinatown and North Beach we walked over for a new treat. I honestly have no idea what we ordered since there isn't a menu in English but everything was so good. We had some dim sum balls with chives and shrimp and those were good. There were also some long skinny things with beef that were good but my favorite were the potstickers - and we even went back for 4 more. We must have had like 15 pieces and two sodas and it was only $16!! Keep in mind it's all take out - we just sat on the curb to enjoy them while they were warm! So happy I found this place. Will be back soon!
author: Brittany G.

description:
Reminds me of Taiwan when I was there. Very affordable and amazing flavor. I ate it all and would eat more if I physically could!!!

Off to explore more of this wonderful area of San Fran!
author: Paul B.

description: AMAZING DIM SUM! Way better than NYC Chinatown. Ordered ~20 pieces and 2 sticky rice and it was $22!!!! Amazing. Definitely coming back if I am ever in San Fran again
author: Catherine C.

description: I found this place by accident about 3 years ago and went yesterday. The food is fresh and still so inexpensive. I bought pretty much of everything steamed which was 7 items and it was $21 with tax. Amazing how they can still keep up the tradition. The har gow meat is plentiful my kid ate all 3. The dim sum had great portions of meat.
author: Joy C.

description: Outstanding!  Special...genuine.  Does not get any better!  Family operated. Wide range of delicious dim sum!
author: John J.

description: the xiao long bao's at this spot are super duper delicious, especially for take-out dim sum! i usually get a dozen and have to stop myself from eating them all in 3 minutes!  also, get the shrimp dumplings, turnip cakes, chicken in sticky rice.  the potstickers arent as flavorful as the ones at wing sing, so i usually skip on those.  the old lady who works there is the sweetest!
author: Christina L.

description:
This is only a partial review, but from the small sample I've had the pleasure of trying, my heart has been won over. I ordered an order of the har gaw and the siu mai, two staples dim sum items I use to judge the worth of any dim sum place. 

1st thought: Holy shit, these things are HUGE. 
2nd thought: You only want me to pay $3.60?! For all of that? Are you sure? 
3rd thought: THIS TASTES AMAZING!!!!!!&#*@(!*#&(*!&(@!!!

So like I said before, I haven't gotten a chance to try everything,so maybe my review will change afterwards (I doubt it). But the most important thing you need to know is that Delicious Dim Sum serves amazing dim sum for really really really cheap. End of story.
author: Zi-on C.

description:
I used to be head over heels in love here, but the last time I came there was a little black curly hair on my har gow and the one i did have was real fishy tasting. 
I don't think I'll be coming here again :(
author: Tania S.

description:
Their steamed Dim Sum selections are delectably delicious! 

From steamed pork dumplings (Siu Mai), shrimp dumplings (Ha Gow), shrimp with baby pea sprouts and to the dumplings with chopped peanuts and pieces of pork with small chives, the dim sum is yummy to the tummy here!

This dim sum is not much of a sit down place!  It's more like you grab it and go!

Remember to bring cash!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Dim Sum is Delicious. 

What makes the place Sum +'s:
+ HA GOW shrimp dumplings are $0.60 and stuffed with shrimp. The opaque skin is not thick and just right. So fresh and good!
+ CHA SIU BAO pork steamed buns are tasty too. I know some say it's a great intro for those not accustomed to Chinese food. Is that why it runs out so quickly?
+ CHONG FUN shrimp rice noodles are good in soy sauce. Spice it up if you want.
+ NAI HWANG BAO or custard steamed buns are nice sweet snacks. Made with an egg yolk center, this dim sum hits the sweet tooth spot.
+ Friendly service. 

What makes the place Dim -'s:
- Nothing is in English. I see Chinese characters (and no prices) on the back wall.
- Seating is dismal. There are two tables in the back but most carry out and eat on the street or scurry it home.
- Sometimes not everything (if you can read the characters) on the he board is available.

TIP: Cash only. Ask the service counter to lift all the steaming trays to see what goodies are hidden underneath the first tray.
author: Yiven C.

description:
The main reason we checked this out this place out is the review of our very own San Diego Elite Yelper - Maria C and her friend Tracy.  We did realize, it's a takeout place with a small table if you decide to eat there (Maria said so).  They do have soft drinks avail to drink.

First of all, I would like to apologize to the poor tourist family who was hesitating on coming in because I immediately headed towards the lone table and took it.  You snooze, you lose but this is Chinatown, if we had gotten our food to go, we had nowhere to sit down and eat leisurely.  After we put dibs on the table, we proceeded to order.  

Ordering is another matter, this is one of those small dim sum places more suited for take out for Chinese speaking patrons.  Although they spoke some English, you had to be clear on what you are asking for.  After seeing those steamed and stuffed dumplings, shumais and pot stickers, you really need to ask what is in them.  Only the beef was easy to recognize since it color can be seen through the coating.  We had beef, shrimp, pork (two types).  

With the not too spicy sauce on the table and soy sauce, it was a fairly good meal.  Certainly, not a dim sum experience most would like to have.  After we picked our items, it was placed in front of us in a tray.  Let's just say it's not a sushi style presentation.

All tasted good, I even had a baked bean paste pastry as my dessert.

The stars are more 3.5 rather than 3 but certainly not a 4 stars nor 5 stars.
author: Melanio F.

description: Umm can I just start by saying this place is amazeballs? The size of the dim sum + the quality + the price just can't be beat. Must trys are the chive and seafood dumplings and the gigantic pot stickers. Chung-fen was a bit on the floury side and sticky side so try at your own discretion
author: Grace F.

description:
Hole in the wall. No tables but one (probably for the employee, not the guest), but since no one was there at 11am, we decided to sit and eat everything there. 

SHU MAI 
Pork dumpling is really good. You see the lady in the back making it, rolling everything like a week oiled machine. 

HAR GAO
Shrimp dumplings are really really good, hot and fresh. 

SHRIMP ROLLS
are my favorite dim sum dish with the soy sauce and hot pepper sauce. I love the rolls more than dumpling. 

BAO
Fluffy Bao with

RED BEAN SESAME PASTRY
my friend loved this but it was too much red bean for me. 

SESAME BALL
It wasn't hot anymore but it was still really really good. I love packing this in the city as a walking snack.
author: Debby L.

description:
We were so bummed to come to SF and not get to eat here.  Of course, we didn't check the hours and YES it was a Wednesday!!   Next time Delicious Dim Sum.  We ended going to another place but not the same at all.  :-(

Until next time.
author: Tuyet H.

description:
The name nailed it. 

For $1.95 per three dim sum items. It is easy not to go crazy! 

It's too good not to go. 

Short and easy review. You'd be crazy not to add this to your list. 

Not a lot of seating, as you take your goodies out on the streets of San Francisco to enjoy. Soy sauce etc, are on top of the bakery display... I mixed it in my togo container to marinade with my delicious picks.

I'm still in heaven.
author: Aimee P.

description:
Great place to go to in Chinatown for cheap and delicious (it truly lives upto it's name !) dim sum. I tried the spicy pork and the beef variety which were both great.
The red bean buns (is that what they are called ?, I'm not sure but I was suggested I try them by the super nice lady at the counter who helped me out with the menu as it is not listed in English) are really tasty as well. 
This is a quick go to place with no sit-down options. We paid around 6 dollars for a meal for three ! Talk about value (and great taste) for money !
author: Manish R.

description:
This is indeed delicious dim sum. This is a great place for a quick, cheap and delicious bite.

We got a whole boxful of shumais, shrimp and shrimp and leek.

My personal favorite was the shrimp one.

Our grand total was $8.50. The price and the taste are both awesome!
author: Cynthia J.

description:
Having not been to the many other dim sum stalls in the area (yeah, they're small enough units to be called stalls), I think this place delivered on its promise: delicious dim sum. 

It's a cozy, no frills, take-out only place where you just order what you want, the lady bags it up and you pay. Easy. 

I was particularly hungry so I ordered a bit of everything, fried, steamed, baked. The ratios of filling to wrapper for each dim sum were pretty near perfect. And a jam packed container for less than 5 bucks. WTF. 

I also want to make a special mention about the service: loved it. The lady was so damn nice to me, could be like my 'aunty' in a another city. Maybe it helps if you can speak the lingo? Regardless, heart of gold.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Pretty solid dim sum, and great prices in line with the rest of the other bakeries and dim sum shops around the area. I thought the har gow and shiu mai at Good Mong Kok were better, but the line there was much longer and I felt like there was less selection in the actual dim sum department at Good Mong. 

The chive dumplings were fresh and tasty, and although there's only one table there I'm glad they had soy sauce and chili sauce there for customers to use.
author: Rosie I.

description:
I've loved this place since I was a kid. 

For those who work in FIDI and go to Lees Deli, they provide all their dim sum as well.
author: Y L.

description: We walked in on a Thursday w/o a line. The menu wasn't in English but I just showed her a picture from Yelp of a bunch of different flavors of dim sum and she asked how many. We paid our cash and found a park near by (only one table). It was amazing!! I loved that we had no idea what we were eating until we bit in! Delicious!
author: Lauren W.

description:
Oh Delicious Dim Sum, I wish I were more impressed by you! 

This is a tiny, hole-in-the-wall sort of a place, and when I see this many great reviews that always incites a certain excitement (I secretly love divey holes-in-the-wall!) But I'm afraid this one fell short.

I do love that you can order individual pieces so you can try a bunch of different kinds of dim sum, but the giant steamers did not easily reveal what was inside! I stated a few of my favourites and ended up with a nice little container filled with dim sum, all for $5! Bargain! 

I couldn't wait to try so I found a bench and got into it. The BBQ pork bun was ok, the dough was fluffy and sweet, but a little heavier than I like and the filling was minimal. Shrimp and chive dumplings are usually my favourite so I got two - unfortunately these were oily, chewy, and overloaded with chive and little balance. The har gow was easily my favourite as the shrimp was very tender and flavourful, however the wrapper was very thick so I ended up eating the filling right out of it. My sesame ball was very, very greasy (I always expect at least a little) so although the filling was tasty it was hard to appreciate because my mouth filled with grease on each bite.

I can see that this would be fine for a grab and go if you're not too fussy, but perhaps I've been spoiled as this wasn't my favourite dim sum I've ever had, that's for sure!
author: Ayla C.

description: Small little hole in the wall in Chinatown . I ordered the shrimp , shrimp and chive ,shrimp and crab dumplings, also pork shumai . I have to say the shumai was my favorite , but all were delicious . Only down side to this joint is it is basically takeout only ( no place to dine inside)
author: Greg E.

description: Very yummy dim sum dishes at less than $2 per order.  Each order comes with three pieces and is freshly made.  Since this place is popular, the food turnover is excellent.  The staff doesn't really speak English and the place is cash only, no dine in.  Those are the only downsides, but for a quick breakfast for on the go, this is a great place for some quality dim sum!  We ended up buying the food and walking a few blocks over to eat at the Transamerica building/park.
author: Loretta C.

description:
The dim sum here is OH SO FRESH. 

They were wrapping some dim sum when my friend and I walked in, which definitely speaks to how fresh the dim sum is. 

I usually get dim sum at the other place on stockton, except my friend wanted to try here and I don't regret it at all! We just got the har gow  and it was less than $2 for 3.  They have everything else here as well shumai, gau choi gau, cha siu bao, nai wong bao, etc. 

Prices are so affordable and the ladies here were nice and friendly. 

You should try this place out if you don't feel like waiting in line at that other dim sum place on Stockton.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: We got the pork, shrimp, beef and pork at around 11am on a Sunday. While the store interior is nothing exciting--a crowded room with nothing but a single table for customers who'd like to immediately get into their food--it didn't stop us from enjoying every bite. They have plastic boxes and utensils for those who'd like to eat on the go as well.
author: Colten H.

description: Cheap and super good! I felt like it was above average as far as dim sum goes. Prices were decent. I'd def go back if I am in area
author: stephanie i.

description: What a fantastic Dim Sum Shop! This particular shop has over 30 selections ranging from your traditional Shao Mai, Shrimp Dumplings, Pork Steam Buns, etc. Prices are fair and quality is superb. If you are around the busy streets of Chinatown, best to visit during open and peak hours as the dumplings will be fresh. Service was swift even thou there was a line forming at Delicious Dim Sum. Order quick, loud and you'll have what I think was an incredibly satisfying dim sum experience. Happy Eating!
author: Jacob J.

description: All the hype!? Why? I went from building to building trying dim sum. I got a banh bad, pork dumpling, taro cake and a rice wrapped in banana leaves. They all look like they should have been hot but they were lukewarm. I definitely didn't enjoy it.
author: Kim N.

description:
This place exceeded my expectations for a to-go dim sum place. Definitely looking forward to coming back soon.  

+ Good quality food. Was in the store for 5-10 minutes and at least three trays of food was brought from the back of the store to the window displays for refill. They brought out the food as fast as people ordered, so my assumption is that the food is pretty fresh when ordered instead of just sitting around for more than a few minutes
+ Good service. The people there were helpful and not rude, which is a big plus to me (non-Chinese speaker). Have encountered my fair share of lacking customer service but did not notice it here. Changed my order a few times, asked to have some food items separated in packing (sesame balls away from sticky rice), and did not at all feel rushed.
+ Good prices. Girlfriend and I were stuffed and had small leftovers for under $20.
author: John H.

description: shrimp and chive dumplings are the best here. They have both steamed and fried. Try both! Very cheap when you buy in multiple of 3. We spent $4.2 for 6 dumplings. Cash only! I have had other items like hakao and thought the skin was too thick to my liking.
author: Norases V.

description:
So I had two meals in SF one consisting of $67 and the other being $5.50. The $5 meal here was three times more memorable and I will definitely return here. 
This establishment represents china town in such a pleasant way, the peeling wallpaper, the absence of any english delegations, the hardworking employees, the large glazed over window peering into the heart of the store, the smells and of course , the tastes. So savory and steamy.

I've been to many dim sum places, this is one of the better ones. One comes to know what to expect in the world of dim sum, but these succulent and individually sold gems have emphasis to them.
