I love the cheap plastic translucent container they give you, I ended up standing  directly outside the store not caring about what the rest of my day entails anymore. All I could think about was how great the dim sum was. Thank you 

Cheers,
author: Rj S.

description: Seriously not all that my fellow Yelpers have hyped up to be. Sure it was about 30mins prior to close... Man oh man, was the lady working pissed as all heck when I was ordering. She opened the containers which had the dim sum rudely and smirked. Got annoyed when I kept asking for more dim sum. The way it's laid out is you just point, pick, and choose... It goes into a box. You pay and you're done. I told her keep the change from what I paid and she smiled and thanked me. Rough day? Or has never received a tip due to her attitude? Who knows. And I know it's not a language, ethnicity, or race issue cause it is known that some Chinese can just be stern.
author: Rheanne C.

description:
what i ordered... sesame seed ball and pot stickers

i can't believe i still haven't reviewed this place. this is the best place for sesame seed ball and my stars solely belongs to this item..... freshly fried, soft and sweetened to perfection. pot stickers on the other hand was awful.....looked good but had a thick wrapping and tasteless fillings.

ambiance... bad 
service... ok (be fast and don't let any locals push you around)
cost... $- (inexpensive)
author: Gors P.

description:
I went here wanting to look for some authentic dim sum.   The reviews were mostly positive on Yelp so thought I'd check this out.    With a name like "DELICIOUS", you can't go wrong, right?  Well...I was disappointed to see how tiny the place was...only one table and then there's a back area with staff.   Not much in terms of ambiance but it made up in authenticity since I was in Chinatown.    I decided on two shrimp dumplings, tofu, and one potsticker, which only set me back $2.50.  Not bad at all.    I was hoping they'd have the mini golden egg custard tarts that I've eaten at a couple larger dim sum places, but they didn't have it (or she didn't understand me...*LOL*).  I didn't see it though so I'm thinking they didn't have it.  

So the one table freed up.  I sat down and quickly went to town on my meal.   The shrimp dumplings were out of this world.   Very tasty and plenty of shrimp.   The beef dumpling was fine.   The tofu was okay until I nearly broke a tooth chewing on some piece of shell or rock (I don't know what it was) that was baked in it.   It turned me off from eating the rest of it.    I would definitely go back for the shrimp dumplings...that might be all I order.   That part lived up to the delicious name..the rest, meh.
author: Eric G.

description:
This is a no frills dim sum take out spot run by a few Chinese ladies whom I'm sure could care less what their Yelp score is.  The line seemed to be comprised of mostly locals with some tourists here and there.  The dim sum was fresh, reasonably priced, and delicious, living up to its name.

The only semi awkward thing is you need to ask them to lift up all of the steamers in order to even see what they have, unless you're one of those that can ask specifically for what you want without the need to point.  Also, it is quite cramped with barely enough room for a single file line.  A lady came in with a stroller and the whole line had to back out of the place in order for her to exit.

Great place to stop in for a snack or a full meal for under $10 bucks.  Highly recommend.
author: Alex M.

description:
Cheap place for take out dim sum!
I was just randomly in town for a day, and Yelped this place quickly. I was pretty surprised to come here and see that it's primarily just a Take Out store! My bad for not reading Yelp reviews beforehand! lol

There is only one table in the store in case people really did want to eat there. Gotta ask for chopsticks and soy sauce too in that case!
author: Julie N.

description:
Best. Dim. Sum. Ever.  

And the pork dumplings were the BEST I have ever had too.  Seriously, they were also twice as big as any of the restaurant style "appetizer" orders that I am used to.

Did I mention that this was my first time here?  So while that may be a bit short sided, it truly was awesome, a simple little ball that tasted so good.  

The BEST part?  That they are about $0.60 a piece.  Seriously?  I was pulling out a few bills to pay for our order, and I was amazed on the prices. I had to stop at two, only since we were actually headed to dinner and wanted to just have our appetizer here before we had our big meal later.

OK, so there is multiple BEST's.  They really do taste that good, and they really are that cheap.  When you go in, unless you speak the language, just point and you will have yummy samplings of legit Chinatown food.  They have a small table in the back that has soy sauce and chili paste, so you may have to share.

 Either way, I am not sure that I will have as delicious Dim Sum as here.
author: Humberto G.

description: I feel bad giving this place two stars cause I love to support the hole in the wall small business, but I just don't like being served cold food, nonetheless cold dimsum. I suppose I could just time it so I come right when things are just brought out, or I could find a microwave, but the thing I love most about dim sum is it coming to me piping hot from a cart. It loses its charm when it's been sitting out on trays for hours covered in saran wrap.
author: Nina S.

description: Great take out place! I like the zongzi from here (peanuts, meat, and they are huge)...along with the dimsum take out and buns. I do recommend seeing all the different varieties since the steamers are piled up so you might miss something. The staff is super friendly here! The hai gow/shrimp dumplings are great (not too oily) and also the cilantro filled buns and dumplings were great. We got a huge assortment of food for 2 (which we had leftovers) for $10. Menus are in chinese and the pricing is not visible.
author: Lily P.

description:
Could be one of the smallest restaurants in China Town.  You basically stand at the counter, point at what you want as they pile your selection into a to-go container.  If you need soy sauce, chop sticks or something else, you might want to bring your own because its not guaranteed you will get it from them.

Once you get your food, you have the option of securing the only table they have, or to hit the street, but the dim sum is great and cheap, something like fifty cents per piece.
author: Ronald D.

description:
I have probably eaten dim sum at least a hundred times in SF Chinatown due to my close proximity living in North Beach, and have tried dim sum from at least a dozen places. Delicious Dim Sum is by far my most frequent spot. Can't go wrong with the har gow, siu mai, and har cheong fun. Very tasty, very cheap. Best of all, it's just as good as Good Mong Kok Bakery, but without the line! If you go there often enough they will start to recognize you as a regular and even have your order memorized. Happy to continue giving them my business. There are a couple tables in there but just take your food to go like everyone else and walk to Washington Square Park or similar and eat it there.

Also, I speak Cantonese, but if you don't, they all seem to know enough English to get you what you want as well.
author: Sean J.

description:
This place gets three and a half stars
you get here through navigating through shops and bars
in the thick of SF chinatown
Is where you'll find this treasure to be found
Their food is OK, but what's amazing is their price
For SF, to get full on $5 is really really nice

I found this place on yelp and it's nice walking all the way from SOMA to get here.  Nice walk, cheap food, and decent.  The food here isn't amazing, but it's good enough to walk 20 minutes once a month, thus the 3.5 stars.  Their Shalom Bao (steamed soup dumplings) have skin that's a little too thick and there's not much soup (b/c it's absorbed into the skin/meat) but it's OK.  Dumplings are the same as anywhere else, and their shumai is actually not bad (I always get these).  There are two types of lotus leaf sticky rice thingies, not sure which one is the one that I like (the one with meat as opposed to the one with egg), but need to figure that and might sway me to give it .5 more stars.
author: Dennis K.

description:
For me, dim sum generally tastes pretty similar from place to place, but Delicious Dim Sum is a standout. 

It's definitely a hole in the wall, and sure the menu is all in calligraphic Chinese, but the workers try to be helpful and can speak English, Cantonese, and Mandarin. There's not really room to sit save for one table in the back, but who needs table service when the prices are so cheap?

We got 4 BBQ pork buns, 4 xiao long bao, 4 steamed chive dumplings, 14 shrimp dumplings, 10 shu mai for $24.30. And [SPOILER ALERT] it was delicious.
author: Wendy W.

description: Delicious used to be our go-to spot for quick and easy dim sum, but lately, the dumplings have been pretty hit or miss. Sadly, you're more likely to be given a bag of cold/lukewarm dumplings than warm, fresh ones. The dumplings are also no longer as reliable in terms of quality as they used to be. The only dumplings that I can always count on are the potstickers, but it's kind of hard to mess those up. The siu mai and ha gow can range from delicious to gross, and you never know what you're going to get. The women who work behind the counter are working hard, but they also seem like they could care less. I'm also unsure as to how they price everything out, seeing as our typical selection of dumplings ranges in total price every time we go. I would never think to stay and eat, as the restaurant could certainly use a good cleaning, but at least they offer relatively good dumplings at a reasonable price.
author: Regina L.

description:
I came here because I wanted some quick dim sum where I didn't have to sit down and waste time. I just wanted to order, grab the goods, and eat it on the spot. Yes the dim sum is cheap so I got whatever I wanted. I got some har gow, sesame ball, and potstickers. The shrimp dumplings were pretty big but the skin was too thick so that made it mediocre. The potsticker was average but pretty massive. I would just say this place is average but if you want good cheap quick dim sum, just come here. Don't expect bomb food. 

**TIPS**
1) Cash only.
2) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
My first time visiting SF, my first time being in Chinatown and my first time eating Dim Sum.  Even after having studied Dim Sum and read countless reviews I was still in no way prepared for the deliciousness that is Dim Sum.  If you don't know you better ask somebody! 
I savored every morsel of my shrimp dumpling.  There is nothing like in the Western world.  The dumpling is so ingenuitive and makes for the perfect on the go meal.  My highest praise goes to Delicious Dim Sum the dumplings are great and hot! And for desert we had an egg custard bun it was to die for.
author: Lucretiz C.

description:
Hai Gaw, Sui Mia...? Nope, it's ALL about the CHIU CHOW FUN GOH at Delicious Dim Sum!

As much as I love the standard hai gow (shrimp dumplings) and sui mai (pork dumplings), the ones at Delicious Dim Sum are mediocre and dry. The thing to get is their Chiu Chow Fun Goh, a steamed dumpling with a thick wrapper filled with ground pork, chestnuts, chopped peanuts and chives. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Fo5Wscbb9rwcLuaO-sc2zQ?select=89kN8gmvhVwnPI8US7WWqw 

The wrapper is thick yet soft with a gelatinous bite and is generously filled with savory pork with a nice crisp contrast from the chestnuts and the nutty peanuts. At $.50 a piece, several is enough to cheaply fill your tummy with savory nutty deliciousness as its store namesake states!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Hell yes. Classic Chinatown dumpling shop. Cheap, fast, and easy. And of course--delicious. Try one of everything! Eat on the street!
author: Laura E.

description: I'm usually wary of places that call themselves "delicious", but in this case it's true! Lots of different authentic dim sum at a VERY reasonable price (I'm talking snack for under $5, stuff your face for less than $10). Great!
author: Philipp A.

description:
Tried Delicious Dim Sum for the first time and it did not disappoint.  The space itself pretty much a hole in the wall.  People are usually grabbing things to go.  

We tried the shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chives dumpling, potstickers, and shumai.  Everything was pretty tasty, however, I didn't care much for the potstickers since the wrapping was pretty thick.  We basically got 1 order of everything (3 pieces each) and paid about $7.  Super cheap prices for delicious food!  We were in and out immediatly.  

What a steal!  I'm definitely happy I tried this place out.  Although their signs aren't in English, the woman helping me opened up each dim sum container to let me see what she had.  If you've ever ordered dim sum before and know what you want, then you're good to go.  I will definitely return whenever in Chinatown.
author: Christine D.

description: the dim sum is not bad, comparing to Good Mong Kok Bakery, even the price $2.10 for 3 pieces, is the same. I read the review and I wanted to try what other yelpers recommended.  this is my first time so I was not very familiar what to order so I was little hesitated.  It was not a lot of people inside, just me only.  The lady who served me already showed her impatient and a cold face.  I tried not to pay attention, so I ordered each pieces (Shrimp dumpling, chive/shrimp dumping, beef Sui Mai, pork bun, taro cake and pot stickers).  later I went to my office and discovered chive dumpling was missing.  If the place was full of customers, I can understand why she forgot but only one customer, me, and still did not do it right?  the staffs must be really unhappy working there.
author: P Y.

description:
Get the shrimp chang feng and shumai

+ really lives up to its name, *delicious*
+ next to FIDI, which happens to be where I work
+ friendly staff
+ really really cheap
- cash only, but Chase and HSBC banks 1 block away
author: Martin Q.

description: Best Har gow in San Francisco. This Fast food style dim sum is my family's favorite for over 10 years. Their food is consistent and always fresh. Great if you're on a budget.
author: Y T.

description:
Cheap, quick, delicious.

Being one to generally be skeptical of these types of hole in the walls, Chinatown is a great place for hole in the wall chinese food.  This is a dim sum place that I frequently go to to order siu mai, har gow, guw choi gow, and ham suay gok.  If you don't know what those are, just walk up, attempt to read off my recommendation, pay for your order, and happily devour your "delicious dim sum".

Basically be super full under $5-6 if even that much. Enjoy!
author: Samuel Y.

description: Gummy dim sum. Place was not great. It shouldn't be this hard.
author: Sean C.

description:
My first time in SF and was excited to try some places out in Chinatown.  Thanks to yelp, found this little spot.  We really wanted to just grab some quick bites on the go and not do too much sitting and more walking.  So if that is your plan, this spot is a perfect take out place.  Freshly made dim sum.  I savored every bit of my shrimp and shrimp and cilantro dim sum.  

oh!  Cash only!
author: Luarnie B.

description: Great little dim sum place! Its more of a to go place as there really isn't anywhere to sit inside. The food is fresh and they have clive dumplings (steamed & pan fried). My boyfriend liked the dumplings so much he went back to buy more. Definitely stopping by again the next time we're in SF!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Delicious dim sum was, in fact, delicious! Maybe one of the best I've had in a while. We were on a mission to try out different dim sum places in Chinatown on a Sunday morning. This was our first stop and we were extremely satisfied. I got 2 har gow (shrimp dumplings), 2 siu mai (pork dumplings), and 1 shrimp/cilantro dumpling all for under $4!! So cheap!! It was very good, all but the shrimp/cilantro one. That's my fault though because I don't like cilantro and thought there was something else inside the dumpling. Dim sum was very warm and I saw that people who don't even know what these things are called had no problem doing the pointing method to order their food.

There's only one table inside the restaurant but who cares, this is meant for take out. Eat it while you stroll through town.

Parking is HORRENDOUS though.
author: Wendy H.

description:
This is really the epitome of a "hole in the wall" restaurant worth trying. Great, fresh dim sum that tasted hand-crafted and authentic. Better than some of the random dim sum I had in Hong Kong during my many travels in my younger days.

If I lived in SF, I would be stop by here for takeout.
author: Jeff J.

description: Super cheap paid 10 bucks.. the only thing they didn't have was the crab balls. :( over all its good can't complain but it's better to eat with two people.. you can always try more
author: Patterson N.

description:
Straightforward. 
Oh my goodness. 
You want shumai + dumplings? Go here. 

There ain't no seats - unless you are old + Asian + know the owners since there were all of 2 chairs inside. Supa dupa cheap. 

I was so apprehensive going in cause you know Asians have RBF - but she was accommodating and told us what's in each dumpling. If I'm in town and have a killer craving, I would make a visit. But I don't consider it a destination spot. Regardless, I enjoyed it.
author: Tania P.

description:
Very tasty and inexpensive.  There is no English menue (or if there is, I missed it.)  But if know what you like, you can ask for it.  Or there is always the time honored, pointing.  
  Parking is tough, but that is true for most of San Fran.
This place is not fancy, but I really like the food and you can't beat the price.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Pros: great prices, quick service. 

Cons: noodles are 80% of the dish (limited fillings), NO veggie selection at all, dump inside, no sit down allowed, shrimp were old, and below average quality vs NY or LA Dim Sum but maybe the best in SF?? So sad that such a big Chinatown has such poor food. Tried another place and it had just as bad of noodles and ice cold egg rolls that were two days old.
author: Matt H.

description:
I was looking for some dim sum for my family and my in-laws and came across this place from all the yelp reviews. Usually my wife orders the dim sum cause she can speak Chinese but it was my turn and this guy can't speak Chinese. English only type of guy. 

There are two ladies who serves you and thank goodness they can speak English. When they started to running out of something then they yell to the back to refill. You can see some of those workers. So this food is very fresh. 

We ordered the shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, beef roll, shrimp roll, sesame balls, steamed pork buns and a few other things that I don't know what they are. Everything was very good for a take-out dim sum place. We had three containers of food for only $30 which is really good price. 

The food is great and there are a lot of Chinese locals getting food so it must be pretty good.  Try it and enjoy while you walk around Chinatown.
author: Doug T.

description:
Just as I was about to give up on my search for the holy dumpling in San Francisco, I walked into Delicious Dim Sum. Normally, I would not walk into a place with such an Americanized name but the restaurant was clean and the staff was friendly. Plus their dumplings looked amazing.

This restaurant was carryout only which greatly limited the amount of dumplings I ordered but ended up getting four har how, two shrimp and chive dumplings, two pork dumplings and one bbq pork bun. The had how was the best I've ever had. A thin and moist wrapper which pulled apart easily and was stuffed chock full o' scrimps. The BBQ pork bun was light and fluffy and had the perfect ratio of meat to carb. The pork dumping and chive dumpling was super tasty as well. 

The total damage? $5.20.  I am going back again today...and possibly tomorrow as well.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
OMG! I love this hole in the wall place! We truly had a great food experience. Although the line was a bit long, their dim-sum made up for it and the price was fairly decent compared to a regular chinese/dim-sum restaurant!

You need to go try this place if you're ever around SF Chinatown! The only downfall is the parking! It's quite challenging to find one! :(
author: MJ M.

description:
I was near Chinatown. So I yelped for a dim sum place to quench my craving.

This is what I got:
1 beef churng fun - beef noodle roll
1 regular churn fun - noodle roll with cilantro and dried shrimp
2 har gow - shrimp dumpling
4 gow choi gow - pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling
2 fun go - minced meat dumpling with peanuts
2 law bak go - turnip cake
for a total of $8.60

Dim sum is all about the filling and the wrapper.  

beef churng fun: The noodle portion was soft and smooth and not too thick.  The beef filling was fresh and tasty.  This was good. 

regular churng fun:  Same soft, fresh rice noodle.  The cilantro gave it lots of flavor but the dried shrimp was ok. It had a bunch of crunchy shrimp shell bits mixed in.  This was ok.

har gow: I'm not a har gow kinda girl but I ordered some based on the yelp reviews.  I agree.  They are very good.  The wrapper was perfect (not too thick and not too thin so the filling falls out). The filling is packed with fresh shrimp that was yummy and not overcooked.  The shrimp had that nice crunch to it.

gow choi gow: This is one of my fave dim sum items to order.  The wrapper was nice and thin (easily torn).  The filling was packed with chives and had a decent piece of shrimp.  It was delicious.

fun go:  This was bad.  The filling definitely tasted off like it was going bad.  Plus the wrapper was thick and the top of the dumpling hard, could not eat.

law bak gow:  This tasted good.  The cake is soft. It didn't have much stuff in it except a few small pieces of Chinese sausage.  Plus you can tell it didn't have much turnip in it, mostly filler.

I was happy to find this place.  It has good food at good prices. I would actually give this place a 3.5 star for the bad dumplings tho.
author: Judy K.

description:
Service was extremely rude, and this is coming from someone who goes to asian places so much and have encountered so many scenarios with an asian being rude!! So, this wasn't directly towards me, but a middle aged chinese speaking lady walks in to this place asking if there was any of what she wanted left, but the lady behind the counter answers to be patient in a super rude tone. Like geez!! Customers are just trying to buy food and bring you service. No body has to come here and buy food from you especially since your food is disgusting. Shrimp and beef rice noodles literally tasted like flour with no filling, shrimp dumpling literally had nothing but the skin, and chicken feet was seasonless but super salty unlike other chicken feet elsewhere. 

All in all, with horrible service and horrible tasting food skip this place and rather wait in the long line at good mong kok!!!
author: Wendy T.

description:
- Locale Destination - 
It's on Jackson St and Stockton St in Chinatown, SF. 

It's very small like any other fast food dim sum places - nothing fancy, very narrow walkway. No chair, No table. The service is quick and the line isn't long like "Good Mong Kok Bakery". Cash only. The menu is in Chinese and I really don't know how much each item is. They don't speak much but I should say they could understand your "pointing finger" and "counting in English" skills. They might rip you off, though everything is very cheap ;p 



- Gluttony Expedition - 
FYI: They don't give you a soy sauce package. Even without it, they are tasty. 

Shrimp dumplings:  Awesome! Whatever shrimp in it was yummy. 
Pork shumai: Good sweetness and flavors. I like it!
Shrimp shumai: Good!
Chive dumplings:  Awesome! Great seasonings and flavors. 
Big flat rice cake:  They put chives, green onions etc. in the thin rice cake. It's very big and bland in flavor. I didn't like it.



- Conqueror's Deduction - 
I could finally find a good dim sum place in SF Chinatown!!
Whatever dim sum with shrimp and chives was awesome! The line isn't long despite of the fact that they do offer tasty dim sum. Great find!
author: Akiko I.

description:
Grab and go! This is not a restaurant. 

You won't find all the usual items but this place is great for the price. Everything is fresh. 3 pcs for $1.90!!! You just can't beat the price! 

******Visitors tip******
San Francisco charges .10 cents if you want a bag. Be sure to bring your own totes and plastic bags.
author: Jenn R.

description:
We had shrimp dumplings. They were so good and had just been made. 
Not a sit in place. Is only for takeout. Can get crowded and it's hard to communicate but still really good place. 6 dumplings for $4.
author: Maria M.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall storefront that sells mouthwatering dim sum.  This is the spot you go to when all you are looking for is dim sum.  No indoor/outdoor seating, no fussy packaging, no servers, simply fresh quality dim sum.

They're insanely INexpensive with pricing as well. An order of their dried shrimp rice roll was only $0.80.  Probably one of the best rice rolls I've ever had too.  Delicious Dim Sum is the perfect place to go if you don't know what to bring for a potluck.  It won't break the wallet, you can get a TON of food and as long as you add in some of your own work and skill to make it look presentable, all's good in the 'hood!
author: Crystine W.

description:
Good shumai, leek and shrimp fried dumplings.
XLB is not soup filled as other prior reviews stated.  The dough used in XLB was too thick and not flavorful.
Its better than most take out dim sum places in Chinatown, but not the greatest dim sum.
Passable and cheap if you are hungry.
author: David H.

description: Although I already had dim sum brunch plans at a sit down restaurant, I didn't want to pass up this dim sum shop with the rave reviews so my friends and I decided to stop by for a couple bites as a pre-breakfast breakfast :). We're so glad we did! The turnip cake was thick and delicious, the shrimp in the dim sums were huge and perfectly steamed. We felt no shame eating out of a plastic container on the sidewalk of Chinatown!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Dim sum was alright, not the best but not the worst.

We got:
Shrimp Dumplings- A-ok 
Cilantro Dumpling- The skin was too thick.
Chive dumplings- Tasty but rather on the small side
Turnip cake- Nothing special
Shrimp Cheong Fun
Sui Mai
Pork bun- A-ok which is why I still give them a pass, you can't be a dim sum place and get pork buns wrong 
Sesame Ball -Best thing here
Chicken feet- Good flavor but still kinda on the dry side 
 

And you better make sure they don't over charge you if you have a large order. Also, they tend not to give soy sauce unless you ask even on large order. Don't expect service with a smile, this is Chinatown.

This place does an order for $2 I've seen other takeouts that do 1.70, 1.90
That being said, take out dimsum is still cheap. 

Conclusion: Don't go out of your way but give it a try if you happen to be in the area.
author: Jessica C.

description: Lunch yesterday was fantastic!  Prices are great, best dim sum in all SF!!!!  Making this my usual stop when I'm flying this route.  We got the shumai, trunip cake, potstickers &  har gow for 3 hungry guys - spent under $20 & we were all full.  The taste was exactly as it should be.  As long as you know what you like, ordering is easy - the menu is chinese.  But they are very helpful for folks that aren't sure.
author: Steve H.

description:
Delicious doesn't do it justice. Went here for lunch with a couple of coworkers and it was amaze-sesame seed balls never tastes so good zing. It's pretty much order and take out only, but well worth it. Just enjoy it at the park next door.

I got 8 items (4 shu mai, 1 cha siu bao, pork dumpling, a sesame seed ball and a can of Sprite) for $5.30. You can't beat that.

Pros - Great, extremely cheap, fresh Dim Sum

Cons - Cash only, not many seats inside, no egg custards :/
author: Johnny V.

description: BEST POTSTICKERS EVER!!!  We go out of our way to stop here and get pot stickers.  I make it a point to get here anytime I'm in SF.
author: Carey D.

description:
Alright, so the key to enjoying this place is all about expectations. This is NOT a restaurant. Rather it is a take-out dim sum place with perhaps the best dim sum I've had in San Francisco. This is little more than a deli counter with no visible menus (and definitely not in english) where you point and ask for what you want. While they will probably understand if you order in English, your best bets are to order in Chinese or by pointing and holding up your fingers. Unfortunately not everything is always visible, so if you don't see what you want (and it's standard dim sum) ask them anyway just in case. 

Despite all this, the food is excellent. Definitely deserving of 5 stars for the food alone.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Prices are super cheap and reasonable - my boyfriend and I can get full off of about $12 worth of dim sum here! 

However, I thought the food was just mediocre. Definitely good for the price and each piece of shrimp dumpling, for example, was huge, but there was also a huge wad of the wrapping at the top of all the dumplings that I would never eat. They use wrappers that are huge and filling that doesn't fill it up all the way, leaving lots of wrapper left (and who wants to just dip a chunk of floury stuff into soy sauce?). 

They also did not have lotus wrapped sticky rice that day (or maybe in general?) which is a staple for us when we go out to eat dim sum.
author: Jenny M.

description:
This place lives up to it's title, it is in fact delicious dim sum. It's also cheap which is a huge win, especially for dim sum in china town. 

NOTE: There is really no seating in this place. There is essentially one table in the back with 4 chairs, or however many needed to squeeze people in who want to eat there. It didn't bother me any because we were able to sit at the table, but if it had been taken it might have been a bummer. Best to take it to go if you can.

PS. they hide the chicken feet and dont offer them to the white people, ask for them, they are delicious.
author: Emma F.

description: They had all of my favorites and and it was all good.  Plus it is always fun to swing through China town.
author: John B.

description:
I was hesitant to eat here because I'm used to sit down dim sum but decided to just try some. BEST DECISION EVER. Probably some of the best Dim Sum outside of HK I've ever had. There's one table and some chairs loosely scattered. 

The women behind the counter seem a bit intimidating at first but don't be scared. They are pleasant to deal with. You can see people in the back making fresh dim sum too.

Do yourself a favor and give this place a try. You won't regret it.
author: Paul C.

description:
Great dim sum at an even better price. I went in with two other people and we basically pointed to a bunch of different items and said how many we wanted. The total cost (for all three of us) was $9. We took it back to our hotel and couldnt even finish it all.

The menu is entirely in Chinese so go in there an ask for the more "Americanized" dim sum options if you need some guidance.
author: Erica S.

description: Amazing. I got a huge helping of freshly made delicious dumplings, a sticky bun, and shumai for $7.50. Can't beat the price and convenience, and the quality was excellent.
author: Ramesh D.

description: My favorite dim sum take out. Low cost and very good. Love their steamed shrimp dumplings and shrimp and chive dumplings.
author: David T.

description:
This place is a tiny walk up for authentic take out dim sum. While the other shops on the street have seating, they are geared for tourists. This places is clearly for the locals who live in Chinatown. There are no English signs, but the workers speak English, and the dim sum was delicious. They are large, flavorful, and really good. Exactly what I looking for in Chinatown. We had shumai, shrimp, shrimp with chives, char siu bao, and red bean balls. Shumai and Shimp with chives were the best. Char siu bao needed a bit more meat to balance the "bread". The red bean balls for dessert were so yummy and perfect. 

Next time I'm in SF, I'll stop by again. And I did I mention this place is super inexpensive!!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Love this place! I came upon this place while searching on Yelp for some quick, delicious dim sum. This place fit the bill perfectly. It's an unassuming and small place. There is usually a line, but it moves quickly as people get their orders and get out of there. There is a table or 2 but no one usually eats there, it's more of a to-go type place. This place always has fresh, hot, good quality dim sum at a fantastic price. You can get stuffed while enjoying every bite, for a cheap price. 

Side note, I think one of the other reviewers actually reviewed a different place mistakenly thinking it's Delicious Dim Sum. She's talking about a $5.99 AYCE dim sum, but that place is actually 2 shops down. (I've been there, too, and it is pretty terrible). Delicious Dim Sum doesn't have an AYCE option. Disregard her review for the wrong location...
author: Mary N.

description: Their pork potstickers were amazing! Their savory pork buns were also good. The red bean cake was dry, 5 years old, and WTF? That's why I took a star off, but other than that, good stuff and very cheap prices!
author: Bhavi A.

description:
The best shu mai I've ever had. Take it from someone who loves shu mai enough to have named a childhood stuffed animal after it!

Ha gow was also quite notable.
author: G P.

description:
We were spontaneous as always and decided to make a trip with the family to SF. Originally we wanted to do the pier but decided hey why not dim sum in China Town?! Stumbled upon this whole in the wall (no seating) place and it's the best dim sum I've ever had!! My mom agrees too! I'm so happy my fiancé insisted on getting the food here. I wanted a sit down place but thank goodness I was persuaded here :) 

The customer service isn't great but hey the dim sum is worth it!!! Very authentic compares to other dim sum I've had. 
I will be back. Yay!
author: HappyMommy ..

description:
For a quick dim sum fix, this place is the place to go. There's one counter with a decent variety. You just point at what you want, tell them how many you want, and in seconds they're packaged up in a box & you're sent on your way. We picked up about 2 of everything (around 15 pieces all together) & some sticky rice for $10.50. Whether or not they were charging me the right price was beyond me, as there are no signs as to how much anything costs. The lady also only gave me one packet of soy sauce, super stingy!

And since this is a take out place, there really isn't much room to sit. There was one table in the back with seating for about 6 people, but of course on a Saturday at noon it was full. So we took our goodies over to the park & had a nice picnic. Good thing it was sunny!

The food itself was pretty good for the price. Each of the pieces were stuffed full with pork, shrimp, or beef. I always hate when the dim sum wrap is super thick & the filling is measly, but this dim sum was a good ratio or skin to filling. And they are substantial pieces of dim sum, much larger than restaurant sizes. My favorite is the shrimp & chive ones :) I'd definitely recommend checking this place out for a quick dim sum fix, just remember to bring your own soy sauce...
author: Lori N.

description:
Wow.

Not to put too fine a point on it, but I just got a small mountain of mind-blowing dim sum for four dollars. FOUR DOLLARS. You can't walk out of Starbucks with a coffee for less than that these days.

It's an unassuming little shop; to me, this undoubtedly adds to the effect. To look at it, the only hint you'll get that something special is going on might be the queue out the door. There's only one table inside to eat at -- and even that was being used to store some pork buns when I was there.

But you're not here for the decor. You're here for the best dim sum this side of Hong Kong's city hall. That's what these guys do.
author: James A.

description: A friend who grew up in Hong Kong recommended this place for their shrimp and cilantro dumplings ($1.80 for a plate of three). One taste and I was hooked and have been back about a half dozen times since, always ordering the shrimp and cilantro dumpling which is called herng say gow (香茜餃) in Cantonese. It's not all cilantro. According to one of the workers there the filling also includes chopped amaranth greens (han choy).  This is one of the best dim sum items I've ever had. I bought three dozen of these for a family gathering, and it was a big hit. This is a group that grew up eating Chinese food and dim sum, so this is a very significant recommendation. They make lots of other standard dim sum items. I especially like the rolled fun (called cherng fun) with dried shrimp. There's very little seating here. This is mostly a take-out place.
author: Roger F.

description:
De-li-cious indeed!  I paid a visit here twice during my 3 days visit in SF. I would have gone for another time if I was not pressed for time to catch my flight. This place is small and easy to miss. Thank goodness for Iphone navigation I found it with minimal trouble. The store specialises (as the name states) mainly in dimsum. This establishment opens early (7am) and closes late (6pm). A word of caution: dont come here to sit and enjoy your food. They have one table with 2-3 chair and thats all. Be ready to walk out quickly with you purchase and enjoy it elsewhere. 

As for my choices, I had the shumai and the green onion with shrimp dim sum. Both were really excellent. They were sized generously for very good price. I had 6 shumai's and 4 of the green onion and shrimp dim sum all for $6.40! Wow! I was also happy by the service I received here. I did not feel rushed or treated rudely. I highly recommend checking out this store if you fancy a dim sum whilst in San Francisco.
author: Riza R.

description: My go-to when I'm craving Chasiu Bao, but don't get there too early in the day or the bao won't be ready yet. The red-bean-sesame-ball things are also pretty clutch
author: K.K. W.

description: Their shrimp dumplings are so delicious!! Amazingly cheap price and good food. If you want to avoid lines and still get decent cheap food, come here!
author: Songhee H.

description:
terrible - a hole in the wall, poor service, even worse tasting food.
never again.
author: DJ K.

description:
I was ecstatic at the prospect of dim sum without the hour-long Sunday brunch wait-- but after digging into my $5.99 takeout box, I was less than thrilled. Every single food item was COLD! 

I got about 8 items in my box. The siu mai and char siu bao were the best items on the menu (good but not the best I've ever had). Definitely cheap and quick so if you're in the area and need a fast meal this is the place. No seating except a tiny table in the back for 4. 

It's definitely no fancy ambience like Yank Sing, just a small hole in the wall. If the food were hot I'd definitely bump up my review.
author: Emily C.

description: Less crowded than mongkok up the street. Dim sum is ok if you catch them coming right from the steamer
author: Lisa C.

description: It makes honor to its name. I would rather name it "Delicious dirt cheap dim sum". I've been here every single time I visit SF
author: Roger C.

description: Truly lives up to its name, it's definitely made fresh and delicious.. best of all is the price and short wait time. Will definitely visit again when  I'm in the bay area. The only downside is that it's cash only.
author: Andrew V.

description: Clean and friendly staff.... pots tickers and hot and sour soup were amazing... wanted to try the XLB but the chef was out for the day.  Waiter suggested authentic dumplings, we were not disappointed. Small portions for lunch but plenty if ordered with an appetizer... service was slow but it was lunch time.
author: Donya M.

description:
While on a trip down to the city, we decided to spend an afternoon wandering around Chinatown walking the shops, taking in the sights and sounds. After a couple hours you realize just how hungry all this has made you and food becomes a priority!

Looking for some great authentic lunch, I turned to yelp searching for that place to explore. We decided we wanted some great dim sum - and we found it here.

As we approached, there was a line and people were coming and going quickly - I felt sure we had found the spot we were looking for - this is a very small shop with counter service only. So be prepared to walk with your food... 

Just as the name says delicious is absolutely right - we ordered 3-4 different fillings and all our dim sum was just plain fresh and yummy - we each got our boxes and off we went! Happy, walking, eating and generally having a good day.

00002
author: Ray F.

description: Perfection in a steam basket! Loved everything we tried and we tried it all. We found this place on Yelp and were so happy. Total hit even wit our 1 and 2 year old
author: Chanelle M.

description: Oh my gosh.  This was delicious.  I followed the reviews on Yelp and it proved correct.  Im not a dim sum expert by any means but I know what tastes good.  Yumm.  And the pork buns are what a pork bun should be: full of meat and a fluffy, light bun. And there's no sitting around and pondering what you should get.  It's fast paced, no room, and you order and get your dim sum and scram.
author: HOLLY P.

description: First dim sum.  Don't be scared.  Just point to what you want.  No line when I went. Only do to-go's as the family occupied the only table there.  Doubt they give a fuck what yelp says.  Paid $5 and my tummy was full.
author: Julie B.

description: Great food, super affordable, doesn't look the part from the street, but don't miss out on this place!
author: Curtis W.

description: Well my family and I decided to eat at a reetuarant...but there were no tables.  However, we were too hungry to find another place so we decided to rider here.  The stores appearance wasn't the best, but the food more than made up for it.  I really enjoyed the dimsums and all the other dumplings that I have no clue what they were.
author: Anthony N.

description: As far as flavor and price, this is probably the best destination in SF Chinatown for Dim Sum.  Come early, as they run out of items later in the day.
author: George A.

description:
As the name suggest, this place is pretty delicious. This place is also cheap for a quick fix. We ordered the following for $19: 6 Sui mei, 6 haw gow, 3 chive dumpling, 3 bbq steam bao, order of shrimp noodles and a 7up.

The haw gow here is a little bland and I would recommend Good Mong Kok. The skin was thick and a little chewy, it was not as tender as this dish usually is. It is filled with shrimp but didn;t have a lot of flavor.

The sui mei was large, it took more than two bites to eat (and I have a big mouth, I usually inhale them in one bite). It was seasoned well and was not gristley with cheap cuts of meat. 

My all time favorite was the chive dumpling, filled with water crest and chives. The chives gave it a wonderful fresh taste and added some crisp to the dumpling. Giving it wonderful texture, it wasn't bland and was season well.

The shrimp noodle was mediocre. the noodle was thinker than I expected that made it a little hard to eat and not as silky as other ones I have had. It felt like it has been sitting out a little longer than the other dishes we had. It was still decent and I will try it again.

The bbq pork bao was also bland and not as big nor fluffy as Good Mong Kok.

I would recommend this place for the sui mei and chive dumplings. I will go back and try other things they have. They def have more options than Good Mong Kok, but Good Mong Kok wins in the bao and haw gow category for me.
author: Vay V.

description: This is a to go place , they don't have place to sit . Also they don't have a menu in English . The dim sum tasted good . I will update the review again after a day in case I have any upset stomach
author: Keerthi G.

description:
Randomly discovered this place as I was looking for some shumai on the go. Didn't realize it was Yelp legit until a few visits after... really doesn't look like much on the outside and the name seemed suspect.

However, I can confirm, that Delicious Dim Sum does indeed sell delicious dim sum. I always make it a point to stop by if I'm in the area. The price is always right, it's just a matter of how much cash I can scrounge up. (Yes, it's cash only.)
author: Diana K.

description: That's inexpensive. But the temperature isn't ideal.
author: ゆみ U.

description: Great dim sum! Got to try the shrimp cilantro dim sum, one of their tastier offerings. Wil be back again before heading back to  socal.
author: Jon L.

description: I love the things with pork sausage in them...but I had to keep spitting out pieces of joint that got cut up into the meat...had to leave without eating any more.
author: Dee R.

description: Absolutely delicious. Was out first stop here when we got into San Francisco and my oh my did we enjoy it!! The dim sums are stuffed with whatever meat/filling it includes so you get a bang for your buck!! Sesame seed balls were just delightful. Had to round 2 right away because we couldn't get enough!!!
author: Remi K.

description:
As the name says - absolutely delicious!

We were here for the Foodie food tour and we got to taste the shrimp dim sum, the pork bun, sesame sweet bun, beef dim sum.

The shrimp dumpling/dim sum was full of just shrimp and nothing else added = aamaazzing. I am still salivating over it!

The pork bun was the fluffiest, lightest fun with meat I have ever had. Perfect balance between the soft bun, flavor and meat.

The sesame bun was very sweet on the inside, the dough was veeeeryyy soft almost too soggy.
author: Nataliya A.

description:
There food is tasty but here's the thing there costumer service is terrible and they ripped me and my family off more than once. So my family loves dim sum, and we always switch people to get dim sum because we always thought they didn't like one of us but we acted like we didn't know each other and get the food but when we got it they ripped us off by short changing us by a few dollars or giving us less dim sum. Also they talked to us as if they were buying stuff from me. They were all like "stop talking your giving me an headache" in Chinese another is when they said "I don't wanna deal with you right now I am really busy" and we were just asking can they package it in box instead of plastic baggies.
Also gave us unfresh stuff
author: Elaine K.

description:
Great go-to for good dim sum. It's take-out only unless you score the one table in the back. Plenty of shrimp-based choices on top of classics like the pork steamed buns and pork soup dumplings. 

My mom, the authentic Chinese-food critic, thought it deserved less of a rave review since the food was cold. But we came at an off-hour and the servers were helpful in explaining all the items, so I give it a thumbs up.

I'd recommend the peanut-pork one. Definitely delish!
author: Aileen L.

description: Went a little late in the evening on a Sunday, so it's no surprise that most things are no longer available. I got the Ha gow with peanut congee, both were pretty good for its price. Will be back to check out more of the menu items!
author: Ivy W.

description: This place is outstanding      best dim sum ive had in the states           shrimp and pork were both out of this world
author: David B.

description: Fresh, plump dim sum for bargain prices. The har gow is delicious and so are the chive dumplings in the translucent wrappers. I think they oil the dumplings so they won't stick together but it leaves a slick film on the lips. The sticky rice wrapped in banana leaf is fragrant and hearty but also too oily for my taste. Take out only.
author: Esther H.

description: Customer service sucks, but the dim sum is better than other part of Chinatown. 3 stars because the woman who works there dropped a tong on the floor then she reused it.
author: Mila N.

description:
Wow this place was delicious!

For less than 6 dollars, my girlfriend and I a light afternoon meal. Things were fresh and tasted as good as any other dim sum joint we've been to in Chicago.

My complaint is that it's kind of hard to get what you want.  Many people in front of us decided to get 20 of item A, 30 of item B or all of item C, so by the time we could order, we either had to wait for what we wanted to order something else.

There was also only one table at the back of the store which was already occupied by a family.  So I ended up just standing and snuggled up to a couple of inventory boxes as my girlfriend and I had our meal.  (Actually an interesting experience this first time, but not something to be done on a regular basis.)
author: Tom Q.

description:
'Delicious Dim Sim' isn't just a braggadocios name, it's a literal one as well! 

While there isn't much in the ambiance department, what with the single table and all... They more than make up with the titular Dim Sum. 

Now, because the menu is in a different language, I'm not entirely sure what I ate but it was awesome. Luckily, the lady was patient enough to help me pick out enough to feed two people. 

Total cost for a box of whatever I ate and two drinks = $8 Dollars. 

Be sure to try the pork(?)... or was it chicken?
author: Michael P.

description:
When we first got into C-town, there were so many places we just went to Yelp, and this was a star. 

The shrimp dumplings (shumai) were good, the vegetable dumplings as well. I really liked the pork wrapped in the yellow skin too (shumai). Char siu bao had very little filling, but I didn't mind too much because the bread was effin' delicios.

It's a little pricier than a lot of other shops though, and there is definitely no room to sit. We shared a table with another tourist group.... all in all, I think they have the best shumai of every dim sum place we visited (tasted fresh, almost sweet).
author: Cindy W.

description:
I remember coming here one time and thinking my brother and dad were stupid for going someplace named Delicious Dim Sum. 

Little did I know, their dim sum actually is pretty delish! I work in North Beach, so I quite often frequent Delicious Dim Sum during my lunch break. 

Standard go-to's, shu mai, har gow, etc. I tried their XLB's and they were decent (I've only seen them once, so I think they go fast!). 

Well worth it, and a hidden gem, IMO. Be careful, I was behind this one dude and he bought all ALL of the shu mai's. Super bummer!
author: Alison N.

description:
Not sure what we got, but it was amazing and super cheap.

Go with a grab bag of whatever you see. You can fill yourself up here for 5 bucks. The chicken feet were not what I was expecting (I've had them crispy before, these were stewed... Not my taste).

Better than Good Mong Kok in my opinion.
author: Tom L.

description:
I walked forty minutes from the Caltrain just to get some Delicious Dim Sum! These perfect little dumplings are flavorful, cheap and has a lot of filling. My favorite dumpling is the shrimp and cilantro dumpling followed by the shrimp dumpling and pork dumpling. For about $7, I got 7 dumplings, 2 eggrolls, 1 potsticker and a sesame ball! Don't forget the soy sauce and chili paste that you can find on the tiny dining table in the back. Sure there's nowhere to sit if the one table is taken. Just eat outside standing up. Once you eat these delicious dumplings, you won't even care anymore!

Bring cash.
author: Jane P.

description: The soup dumplings were pretty good but the other dishes not so much. Staff could not elaborate on the menu and staff felt disconnected. No repeat for us.
author: Sal C.

description:
Stopped in on the way to the office since I have a short day and need to make the most of my time at work with no lunch hour out.  Spending my time in the useful occupation of yelping, then.  

Bought a huge lunch for myself, 3 har gao, 2 shumai, 3 potstickers and 1 shrimp and cilantro dumpling to taste.  $5.40!  

I needed a mid-morning snack and am posting because I cannot believe in all seriousness how incredible the shrimp and cilantro dumpling is.  OMG, I should have bought 3 of them, I will be craving all the rest of the day!  It is the best dumpling I have ever had in my mouth.
author: Donna H.

description: Finally a restaurant that lives up to its name.  The shu mai did not need any soy sauce, the ha gow was super fresh.  Will go again but might have to bring my own chairs and table to enjoy everything!
author: Anthony C.

description:
You can score a good meal of takeout dim sum for under $5. If you don't speak or read Chinese (the menu is in Chinese only), pointing works well. An order ranges from $1.50 to $1.70. I didn't see any buns. They only have two tables (it's a typical looking no frills takeout dim sum shop) so plan on taking it to go. 

* Har gow: impressed with the amount of shrimp, quite good
* Chiu chow peanut dumplings: glutinous rice shell, savory filling was very nice, with ground pork, peanuts and lots of other things
* Shrimp rice roll: they used big shrimp, yum

I like how the dumplings have plenty of tasty fillings and aren't as greasy as some other places. However, the skins tend to be too thick.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
This is a small and unassuming place, but it had some very good and cheap dim sum.  I got four pieces for only $2.30!

San Francisco dim sum certainly doesn't vary much in flavor from the dim sum in L.A.  Therefore, if you miss eating dim sum in S.F., no need to worry...
author: Julie F.

description: Excellent dim sum from this hole in the wall in Chinatown. Dingy? Yes? But the dim sum is made with care and is easily some of the best you'll ever have. The shumai and har gow are both incredible and cheap.
author: Karim P.

description: After going to Wing Sing Dim Sum place just to buy one of my favorite thing to eat and that would be the Sticky rice with the lotus leaf!!! After that I wanted to try some of the dim sum items which is at the Delicious Dim Sum place!!! Before coming here I was reading some of the great yelp reviews from some my yelp friends who had yelped this place before... And so finally on a nice sunday afternoon at the San Francisco Chinatown area which was yesterday... I finally went over to the Delicious Dim Sum place and bought some dim sum items for myself to eat as a late afternoon snack!!! This place isn't that bad at all and the prices of the dim sum items of this place is not  that expensive and its really cheap!!!
author: William B.

description: Delicious, delicious, delicious!  Yep, I know why they named their restaurant that. The Dim Sum was so crazy yummy.  We couldn't read any of the menu as it was in Chinese but the lady behind the counter was extremely helpful and in the end we walked out of there with a variety carton of scrumptious dim sum, enough for 3 people, for $8.00.  I will definitely go back here every time I am in San Francisco.
author: Michelle S.

description: Gritty, Authentic and Perfection. It does not matter if you are an experienced Dim Sum eater or a first timer... no way to go wrong. We felt comfortable enough to try new things and everything was delicious!
author: Veronica W.

description: No fuss, no muss. This place isn't going to win any awards for decor or customer service (or seating for that manner; it's a hole in the wall with no tables), but they come through where it counts - it's cheap and good.  I got a char siu bao and 8 other assorted pieces to go for under $7. All of it was legit, save for the bao actually, which was on the dryer side. As long as your expectations are set accordingly, you won't be disappointed.  I would definitely come back if I'm craving a couple of bites of chives and shu mai to go.
author: Alan W.

description: I was introduced to this place in 2000. I've been going here since(even driving from Concord). They raised their prices now like the restaurants, which is not good coz it's a small place where you can't sit down and eat. It was nice when it was small and cheap, imagine .75 cents/order! Inflation drove it up to $2.30/order. Yikes!
author: Louise T.

description: Ordered $53 worth--lots of dim sum! I don't see what the great reviews are all about. Maybe SF doesn't have good dim sum so this is considered their best? The 2 ladies working there RUDE--they wanna shove as much dim sum on 1 plate possible, so when I asked for 1 extra small plate, they scuffed and spoke (I could tell what they were saying was not nice) as they grabbed 1 for me  (mind u I had 3 kids and 2 adults in my party). There is only 1 table in the back that seats 4, and a few chairs.
author: Lynn L.

description:
So this place is prolly my favorite takeout dimsum place yet! :) Everything tastes so fresh and authentic, and I always bolt out supersuper excited to run back home and eat. Everything is really affordable too!

My favorites:
- sticky rice wrapped in leaf
- pork shumai
- beef shumai
- shrimp hargow
- shrimp and chive dimsum

Avoid:
- shanghai soup dumplings - no soup and dry:(
author: Cheri K.

description:
Go early for best selection.  I went on a weekday after 4pm and slim pickings.  I picked up some dumplings about $2 for a bunch.

Across the street is House of Dumplings, and on Ross Alley the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie.  Do it all in Chinatown!
author: Ann L.

description: I love this take out place where they made fresh dumplings. We sat down to the only table and I watched them bring large pans of fresh steam dumplings out of the steamer. So much yummy goodness. This place is more take out and go home and enjoy kind of thing. They make the yummy dim sum for English and Chinese speaking. Awesome.
author: Diane L.

description:
This is easily one of the best dim sum places you'll find in Chinatown. It's located pretty far from where I work, but trust me when I say that the food is worth the walk. My staples are usually their har gow, siu mai, and shrimp and chives dumping. Although they don't have a huge variety of dim sum, the quality of each one more than makes up for it. The har gow is extremely juicy, and the siu mai is always very flavorful. They also have a variety of sweet dim sum located near the counter. As well, their portion sizes are as large if not larger than neighboring restaurants that serve dim sum. 

Although the servers don't speak much English, I appreciate how patient they are when I ask them what kinds of dim sum they have. There is maybe one table in the restaurant so don't plan on eating there. They don't compromise quality despite how low they price their food. They also only take cash so go prepared!

Overall, one of my favorite places to get some quick dim sum. I would highly recommend anyone in the area to stop by and give it a try.
author: Sunny H.

description: For a quick place to get dim sum for cheaper prices this is the place to go. Their skin isn't thick for their Siu Mai, Har Gow, and Shrimp and chive dumpling (my favorite). By the end of the day, the selections are limited so be sure to go earlier. The people behind me also got xlbs, which looked cold but still held their shape. If you're in the area, give this place a chance! I would go somewhere else if you're looking for steamed buns though.
author: Angela L.

description: It's alright. Not much effort on the service part at all, but on a positive note, it made me feel like I was back in China! My group of 3 ordered all our food together and the total was around $13, so the prices are great. Standard dishes like shrimp dumpling, pork buns, sticky rice, taro, shumai, etc..
author: Mio W.

description: Verrry small place. Only one table for eat in. Mainly for eat out. Had the typical hargow, siu mai, and dumpling. They were all fairly standard. Nothing really standing out. Still pretty good.
author: Patrick T.

description: Dim sum is to go here only, there are no seats (well, there are a couple seats technically but they were occupied), tables or carts that go by - but the dim sum is good, tasty and very reasonably priced!  So grab your dumplings, noodles and rice to go and enjoy!
author: Maile N.

description:
I'm lucky that nobody called the SFPD on me, because at these prices I kinda feel like I stole from this place in broad daylight!

I headed towards Chinatown on the hunt for some dim sum, and I wanted it to-go.  Since I was solo, I had no desire to sit down by myself and order off carts that came by.  Lucky for me, there were several to-go places, so I went here.

I got 2 shumai, 1 cha siu bao, 2 har gow, and 2 spinach & shrimp dumplings, all for $4.90! That's right, that's less than most meals you can get anywhere.  I probably would've paid twice that, had they asked for more.  It's not like I could read anything in this place, so I didn't know ahead what it'd cost.  However, I was able to effectively verbally communicate what I wanted, and even told the lady what else I wanted (when I didn't see it).  She indicated there were not any ready now, but all I had to do was wait 5 minutes.  She didn't say it that clearly of course, but I got the gist of it so agreed.

This place wasn't that busy for a 12:30 on a Friday.  It was some seriously good dim sum, with the exception of the cha siu bao (it was too light on the cha siu).  The har gow was some of the best I've ever had!  I just wish they had a bit more to order from.

Now that I've discovered dim sum to-go places, I'd like someone to open up a dim sum food cart.  Someone (Portland, I'm thinking of you), make it happen.
author: Brandon C.

description: Best take away dimsum in San Francisco hands down! Try the prawn with cilantro and prawn and pork dumplings :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
Decided to brave the Chinatown crowd on a Saturday to satisfy some dim sum cravings. The line wasn't too long, 4-5 people deep with a steady stream coming in. The lady that helped me was surprisingly patient as I struggled to describe what I wanted, great service for Chinatown! 

Have to say I was a bit disappointed about the food. The shumai was decent, rice rolls tasted like it was artificially mixed with some extra gelatin. Shanghai dumplings were big, thick and rough. Everything worked as a craving substitute but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Nattie X.

description:
I love cheap lunches! 

I wasn't starving, but lunch time was calling my name. I wanted to step out of the office as well. It has been a stressful week.  So I took a walk up that Nob Hill "Hill" to get myself a small bun. I got the BBQ pork Steamed Bun. Lord have mercy, it was still nice and warm. The bun itself was so soft. Soft like a fluffy blanket, but there was a bite to it. There were plenty of meat, and meat tasted fresh. Some bakeries use old meat that be a little rough. DDS was perfect! Guess what it was only $1. Filled my craving. Lunch complete!
author: Phuong V.

description: This is a carry out place, no seating. But I love it! I would usually grab a few things after work and eat them at home. Dim sum are around $2.10 per order.Depends what you get. But I can definitely be satisfied under $10. You should have cash. People there are nice, not bad at English. I like their shrimp dumplings, chive pancakes and xiaolongbao. Street parking can be a bit crowded, it's on a busy street in Chinatown. Worth it! Would definately go back!
author: Shirley W.

description:
Just like the name of the shop, its DELICIOUS!!!!!!!! cheap and delectable. its a small take-out shop with only 1 table and a row of chairs of customers who would couldn't wait to chowdown after getting those dimsum (errr... like moi ;p)

I actually use Yelp to look for dimsum place as my friend & I was planning a trip to Chinatown to get something for her mom. Delicious has had good review with both of us was game! It was drizzling and the table was empty. just perfect for us to order & eat there. lots of variety for such a small shop and they taste good.

The place can be overwhelming for some as it is the normal chinese run stall/shop with kinda sticky floor and you eat out of a box lined with plastic sheets. chinese tea comes in styrofoam cups. For good dimsum, I would go anywhere :) They also have tiffin items (rice with steam pork) etc which I contemplate trying but had to give them a pass for now to save room for more dimsum

Too bad its in San Francisco, else I would go there more often. So far, my friend had took her family and friends there. No complaints nor tummy ache so far. Its all good and even greater for the huge amount of dimsum we got. $12 fed both of us a very satisfying meal
author: Sonia F.

description:
I love this place very cheap and excellent food and service.  Every time I am in China town I stop by here for food. I would say for $3 you can be full. 

This restruant is great for a quick pick up always a steady crowd but they do a great job of keeping the lines at bay. They have one table for in-house dining, however it is frequently used. 


Tl;Dr: great, cheap and very fast.
author: Nathan K.

description:
This place isn't bad. I trusted fellow yelpers with this one and decided to come. Dismay is there isn't much seats (one table for four) inside if you wanted to eat there. This is a good take-out place.

I ordered the chive dumpling and it was pretty tasty. The texture of the filling was alright. I was used to the compacted bite and this one basically spilled out after I bite it in half (loose and not as packed). I'm not sure how friendly this place is for non Cantonese/ Mandarin speakers.
author: Amy T.

description:
Bless the little Chinese women who have made this meal for us the past weeks....

Honestly, you can't find a better quality Ha Gow anywhere else in take out dim sum joints as far as I've seen in SF Chinatown....

This place's biggest strength is the taste, and by golly when you have the Ha Gow fresh... It's incredible. Perfect skin to meat ratio, superb shrimp taste, very meaty, etc etc etc...! The list goes on and on... I have dreams about eating their Ha Gow because it's so good...

Honestly, i wouldn't go here for anything else... I am a pescatarian so it's very difficult to sample the entire dim sum fair here (aka you Siu Mai... Bertha misses you!!!).

But i taste things vicariously from my partner, and he says that their pork Siu Mai and chicken pot stickers are phenomenal... , so do try everything here!!!

Honestly, it is really hard to disappoint. They make the basic dim sum the best (for you who don't know... The Siu Mai and Ha Gow of course)!
author: Alberto H.

description: I'm not sure what to make of this place! The dimsum was delicious, amazing, and fresh. But both my boyfriend and I felt like we were knocked out right after we ate there, and had to sit drowsily on a bench for about an hour. Maybe there's too much MSG in the dimsum? As good as it was, I am definitely sure that I won't be back.
author: Autumn Y.

description: Dim Sum prices has went up so much over the years :( but its still good! I always get the Shrimp Dim Sum(Ha Gow) & the Siu Mai! I believe it was over $3.70 for 3 pieces each of the Ha Gow & Siu Mai.
author: Nancy W.

description: I had this 4 times during the 7 days I was in SF. I had the shrimp changfen, shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings, and xiaolongbao. While the shrimp in the dumplings were not as fresh tasting as at hong kong lounge, I definitely enjoyed every last bite.
author: J G.

description: Mofo. This is actually really good takeout dim sum. I have no complaints about the food. The ornery menopausal old lady is to be expected. Cmon this is what communism does to customer service. The zongzi are delicious although I suspected there were cockroach larvae in the filling.... What doesn't kill you. Makes you stronger. But seriously it's pretty gross. CLEAN SOMETHING YOU MEAN crazy LAD(ies). But which one of us lazy, self obsessed people are actually going to call the health department?
author: Chinthrilla M.

description: Walked around Little Italy and Chinatown for a day and looked for the best Dim Sum in the city. Found this place via Yelp and was happy to experience a little "hole in the wall" gem in the city. It only has one small four top table so don't expect to find a seat during touristy seasons. Ladies scooping up the dumplings were nice and very quick to serve you, prices are phenomenal, and the taste was fantastic. Glad we took a moment to walk into this part of the city, because out of a city with a never ending variety of popular foods, the Delicious Dim Sum comes up on top!
author: Miguel G.

description:
Delicious indeed. Me and my boyfriend got a variety of dimsum, the total was only $8, and we were so full we could not finish the platter. I believe everything is 3 for $1.70 or $1.90, awesome deal. They make things fresh since they have really good business. 

Their veggie dumplings and shrimp dumplings were my favorite. They try to sell in 3's, although we really didn't need 3 radish cakes. 

Only 1 table to sit and eat though.
author: Elisa L.

description:
I decided to come here for dim sum one day because the line at Good Mong Kok was a little too long, and I was in a hurry.

So glad I discovered this place because I think it's one of the few places in Chinatown where the workers understand my English! Yeah, I'm Filipino, and sadly, the only things I can order in Cantonese at other dim sum places is Har Gow and Shu Mai. However, this other dim sum that I like looks like it's pan-fried or so, and is filled with chives and shrimp. I like that I can just come here and tell her I want the one with chives and she knows which one I'm referring to.

The prices fare about the same with other dim sum places in the area. But yes, if you want to come to a place with English speakers for your convenience, definitely stop by here.
author: Melissa D.

description: Definitely the best har gow (shrimp bonnet) around the block - though smaller in size.  Skin is thinnier than others and the shrimp is crisp.  Great foundations for a successful har gow.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Based upon fellow Yelpers who raved about this place (including Kimberly, our DC Yelp leader), I had to try this place out in SF.  It did not disappoint.  While it's much easier to know the language and read the small lettering menu, you can simply ask them nicely about what the dumplings are.  

Based upon the price and how quickly they service you (even if there's a line, there were 3-4 people fulfilling orders), it's definitely a great place to go in SF Chinatown.  I don't think it's "more" authentic than other dim sum places, but you can't go wrong getting carryout here.
author: Sam L.

description:
Fast food Dimsum joint.  Cheap- yes.  Fresh- questionable...  I have to admit this is a very standard place.  To go only and they make mass loads of dumplings. My Non Asian friends recommended me to come here and swears its amazing.  My sister and best friend got extremely sick after eating at this place.  
Beware: it may look good but it might not be fresh. Yes its 2 bucks per order but you might pay a higher price later. 
I would not recommend the folks I care about to come here. Sorry.
Parking: Chinatown street parking if horrible. Recommend taking a Uber cab.
author: Ying F.

description: Limited availability on menu items. VERY dirty. Most would not eat here. Not sure if the place is ever cleaned. Now the food was very good. Everything was fresh tasting. The portions were good. I will probably not be eating hear again unless I see others with positive feedback. Good luck with this place.
author: Corey P.

description: I hadn't experienced Dim Sum before and Delicious Dim Sum over delivered on my expectations. Absolutely Delicious Dim Sum!
author: Jaycee R.

description:
If there is a line, it must be good. Came here during the Chinese New Years Parade and it was pretty good. Didn't want to go into a restaurant to wait so came here for some to go food. 

Normally go down a couple stores but heard this place was good also. They have good chicken feet and some dim sum. While not the best, theirs is better than some depending on what one orders.
author: M C.

description:
Excellent quality for Chinese Standard of Dim Sum. I discovered via a food tour and I am really impressed. This will be my go to place.
The dumplings are great. I don't care for the bbq pork buns but overall excellent.
author: Alison W.

description:
Ordered:

fried shrimp and leek dumpling
steamed shrimp and leek dumpling
Steamed bbq pork buns
Har-gow
Shrimp in rice rolls

Received:
Big box of warm-ish dim sum. The fried shrimp an leek dumplings were almost inedible because they were so cold. Items were really lacking in flavor - normally I feel like a walking onion after eating shrimp and leek dumplings, but not here; the bbq pork in the buns was nearly flavorless.

I'll not be returning...
author: Richard H.

description: I love the Dumplings it's really DELICIOUS! Very affordable! Down side, it's just a take out, no seats plus the staff are not friendly. The dumplings are all inside the stacks of aluminum steamer so how can you see and choose. When you ask what's under the face of the staff is grumpy and will say something in Chinese (very impolite). They are always in a hurry. I AM JUST RATING THE FOOD! SERVICE BAD!
author: Jessica F.

description:
Just gonna say that I fed a family of four with less than $8 worth of items from there. Har gow, seseme balls, cilantro dumplings, etc etc... yum! 

I wish there were places to sit around these hole-in-the-wall shops but for this price I paid for food, I'm getting way ahead of myself. 

Nomnomnom
author: Min Ju L.

description: One of my favorite parts of our trip to San Francisco.  If you park a few blocks away you can find street parking for free.  This place is tiny!  I wouldn't plan to eat in the restaurant as there was only one small table that our family of 4 had to share with two other groups while eating there for a quick 15 minutes or so.  We didn't know what we wanted so just asked for a taste of everything and 2 cans of soda.  Ate, enjoyed our food and went to pay the bill.  $11!!!!  I couldn't believe it.  We left feeling full but not stuffed and went to a bakery for dessert.  Everything we tasted was yummy.  Some had pork, some shrimp and some both?
author: Jasmine C.

description: Craving for some delicious, quick, cheap dim sum? Look no further, this is it!  3 har jiao (and most of their items) for just $1.80!  We spent $16 bought enough food for 4 meals!  *seating limited. You may have to stand outside of their store. There's only one table, yes only one, in the entire store.
author: Ting L.

description: Dirt cheap giant dim sum, adequate quality, tourists and non-Asians will love it, people who know good dim sum will turn it down.
author: Andrea H.

description: I have been looking forward to coming to this place for weeks. Finally we did, and I may or may not be coming here every weekend for my very ill-defined sense of breakfast. I was expecting to come in and have to point and hope to get lucky with my choices based on reviews. However, I was able to ask questions and order with no problem. All of our choices were great and so cheap. My only complaint was having to wander the block to find a seat to eat our dim sum because there wasn't much seating.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
my friend brought me dim sum from this place on her road trip to SF. all of the dim sum, except the leek dumpling, still taste good even after a week in the refrigerator. the leek dumpling was already gone bad by the time i ate it. well, its already a week old, so its totally understandable. my favorites are the hargow and egg tart. the hargow was very good with big shrimp pieces inside. very flavorful and huge. the egg tart was also very yummy.. not crispy coz its not fresh but i still love it... yummmm!! the shiumai, however, was one of my least favorites. the smell of pork was way too strong and i really didnt like the aftertaste i had after eating this shiumai. the rest was just ok and not memorable.

i can see why people like this place. i havent tried their fresh dimsum but i already liked the non-fresh one. so i cant imagine how good its gonna be if you have it fresh and warm (especially the egg tart). 

price is cheap, according my friend. i think you paid about $2.50 for 4 hargow. the rest of the dim sum are about the same price.
author: Rachan S.

description:
My friend quickly found this place when waiting for Mama's turned out to be a nightmare, and I saw the shrimp, chive and pork dumpling so I was sold.

I should have ordered 5 of those instead of half a pound of chicken's feet. It took me about 30 minutes with a fork, sitting at a park bench slowly eating and spitting bones out in a bag. The sauce was garlicky and the right taste, but why did they not have chopsticks?! It's so painful eating with a cheap fork that can't hold the chicken's feet all the time. I felt like my fork was weaksauce or something. The phalanges were a bit tougher than I expected, but the rest of it was tender and fall-off-the-bone, like it should be. I don't know, maybe I would have liked it more if I had a microwave and chopsticks. I also felt very thirsty afterwards... MSG or high sodium maybe. 

But I did love their shrimp, pork, and chive dumpling. Tender and juicy, I think I'll come back next time to get a whole bunch for breakfast instead of ordering anything else. Their har gow and chiu chou fun gou looked pretty good, but I'm a happy camper with my dumplings already.
author: Emily C.

description:
While at Golden Gate Bakery, I decided to yelp  the best dim sum near me and I discovered this place.  Glad I yelped it because I enjoyed one of the best chive dumplings ever.  Everything I had here were good.  No need for sauces.  Everything was flavored just right.  To top it off, it's cheap!  On weekdays in the morning, there isn't much of a wait but I hear it's crazy during lunch hours.  Since this place is tiny and has a limited selection, I can imagine it.  I love places that specialize only in a few things because they can make it right all the time and they do it right here. I will definitely come back if I'm in the area.  

I love their shrimp/chive dumpling and hargow.  Their bbq pork bun is pretty good. Don't expect to come for a sit down meal.  There is no room.  Just order it and eat on the go.
author: Kaylin O.

description:
YAY! I am very happy to report that Delicious Dim Sum is not a misnomer--it truly is delicious!

Anyway, all cheesiness aside, my parents and I were pretty much blown away by:

1) The dirt cheap prices...
DID SHE REALLY SAY $11.50 FOR THIS FEAST FOR 3 PEOPLE?!? THAT'S LIKE 2 ORDERS AT THE DIM SUM JOINT AT HOME!!!

2) The deliciousness!
We loved everything (I think we literally got everything that was offered) except the long rice noodle wrap things and the taro dessert piece.
