3) The ghettoness/unfriendliness of the place/staff, respectively.
I mean, it's Chinatown, so thank god we didn't really come in with hygenic expectations, because that would not have gone well. Oh, but the staff: SO unfriendly. Can't speak Chinese? Well, be prepared to be hated. No ounce of the sense that they are happy to have your business, AT ALL. My mom laughed really hard because she asked for 3 paper plates (for our family of 3) and they said we could only get two, with very stern, pissed off faces.

Lawlz.
Anyway, man up and eat here, but get take out. Trust me.
author: Jenn L.

description:
This place makes me wish I either read or could speak Chinese. But I did the point and ooh or grunt and it worked out fine. When I asked what was inside a particular potsticker, I got "potsticker." 

Okay, back to pointing and nodding. Very yummy, quick and damned cheap! What could be better than that? Oh, I know what, I got there just before noon and there was one person in line ahead of me.
author: Thalia F.

description:
After leaving dissatisfied from dim sum at a nearby location I came to delicious dim sum after seeing good reviews and I was not disappointed

I was in and out of delicious dim sum very quickly as I knew what I wanted from looking in the window. I Was A little afraid of ordering because no one was speaking English when they ordered and when they were serving but it was very easy. I got two buns and two dumplings just to see what was there and made it out for 2.80. Super cheap!

I dug into each with my girlfriend and it was incredible! The bun was sweet and fresh on the outside with a really delicious flavor on the inside, and the dumpling just made me wish I had more. 

I would definitely suggest Delicious Dim Sum over most other restaurants in the area.
author: Kieffer W.

description:
There are many dim sum take out places in Chinatown, especially along Jackson street, but don't be fooled. The name says it all. This place really does have delicious dim sum, a dumpling above the rest!

It's perfect if you're by yourself or with one other person because you can get variety without having to eat 2-3 pcs of the same dimsum like you would in a restaurant setting.

Service isn't great (to be expected), but prices are unbeatable!

Tip: Closed Wednesdays!
author: Camille B.

description:
This place is super cheap! But I don't think anyone really speaks English, so you have to do a lot of pointing... And the older lady puts all your food in a bag so I don't think it's very sanitary. But the younger lady will put your food in a togo box. So you should talk to her instead.

I kind of got a stomach ache from coming here too..and I think it was from the chicken sticky rice thing.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
15 har gow (with lots of shrimp), 5 turnip cakes (bits of chinese sausage in there) and 5 pork potstickers for $14.50. It's like half the price I normally pay, except it's even better tasting than most. 

Ladies behind the counter are all business and they speak English pretty well, I'm the one that's going to have to brush up on my language skills. I went around 2pm and there was still a small line and fresh items available. Nowhere really to sit and eat, entirely to-go. Small tip if you're getting turnip cakes - I took mine home and pan fried them a bit more to perfection.
author: Jane L.

description: With so many dining/food options in Chinatown I settled on this and I was not disappointed. I had an assortment of dumplings, pot stickers and I also got some sort of sticky bun with pork in it (everything was delicious). There's only one table in the back - don't be afraid to sit with strangers y'all!
author: J E.

description: Inexpensive and amazing dim sum.  Super small, only one table in the back, easier as to go.  I stop by every time I'm in SF.
author: Steele B.

description: Yes, it does live up to its name! I stopped by Delicious Dim Sum on our way back from Peninsula Restaurant for some dim sum to go for my sisters. The ladies working were absolutely friendly and so sweet; something you don't usually see at fast food to go type places! We ordered shrimp dumplings, pork siu mai, and steamed pork buns all for $8.50, which, in my opinion is SO cheap! All of the dim sum were fantastic and just so good. The only downside is that there's no place to eat your dim sum. I'll be back!
author: Joyce E.

description: Not the best place in China Town my beef and broccoli was gross my broccoli was yellow I asked if I could get my money back and he refused now my stomach hurts and my daughter's throwing up
author: Joanna L.

description: I got the har gow and potstickers. The food was very cheap but wasn't very good. The potstickers had too much flour and the har gow's skin was watery and coming off.
author: Tony J.

description:
Ambiance: It's a tiny place with no room to sit down and eat inside, but the plus side is that you can go in, get your food, and be out in a few minutes. It's easy to miss because it's tiny so look carefully!

Food: They have plenty of different dim sum dishes to choose from, and I would recommend the beef rice noodle roll, har gow, and the chives and shrimp dumplings (which my boyfriend liked even though he didn't know what was inside at first). I didn't like their shao mai as much because the meat inside was a bit mushy. Their food is definitely worth the price, super cheap and suitable for a college student's budget!

Service: The food is all cooked and ready to be packed in the to-go boxes. Not the friendliest workers, but they get the job done promptly.
author: Kailin H.

description: I've never been to a take-out dim sum place before, but I loved it! Our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomach... We got wayyyy too much food but it was all good! All the signs were in Chinese so I didn't know how much I was going to pay for everything. Although I couldn't read anything, the ladies there were super helpful and very patient with us. The har gow is amazing!!  Definitely a place to come back to when we come back to San Francisco!
author: Jenny S.

description: Was dying to try their dumplings based on reviews, but when we arrived it looked so revoltingly unsanitary we couldn't bring ourselves to eat there. If the reviews about the dumplings are true, it is a shame they don't keep their restaurant a little cleaner as I'm sure we can't have been the only people turned off by it's appearance.
author: Alison M.

description: Friendly staff. It's a to-go dim sum place so it's very narrow and small inside. You can fit 2 or 3 people in the back. Their dim sum was delicious and they had very fresh ham sui gok when I went. I will be back!
author: Donna V.

description: Food is OK in this price range, the restaurant is a to-go place and there are a lot of people waiting in the line.
author: Haibo Y.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about here. The dim sum is incredibly cheap ($6 can easily fill someone up), but it's nothing special. 

I came with my girlfriend for take out a little after 5pm, and maybe that was the issue. By 5pm, they were out of all veggie dumplings and were out of sesame balls. 

We ordered shrimp, beef, and two different kinds of pork dumplings. The shrimp was really good, but the beef was barely cooked, and because the place was a little dingy, I didn't feel comfortable eating such raw meat. Also the dough used for the XLB was a little too thick for my liking.
author: Alden Q.

description:
OMG I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! If i lived in s.f I'd probably eat this every morning! its so convenient, fast, and cheap!!! 

I got $2 of the shrimp dumplings....50 cents each and some green shrimp balls thing...it had scallions and shrimp in it. They were all so delicious!! the dumplings had CHUNKS of shrimps in there and I was surprise because it was so cheap!!! I wish I would have bought more. I got tired from walking up and down hills in s.f and too lazy to walk back to buy some more. How do you people do it?? walk up and down those hills everyday....I wanted to die!!!!
author: Cat N.

description: I am kinda picky with Dimsum, but with this cheap price..it is perfect for a quick take-out breakfast or lunch. hey.. no need to wait in line
author: Caroline T.

description: Little hole in the wall, such a great find!  I know limited Chinese so ordering consisted of me pointing and requesting a certain amount.  Their food was so good and so cheap!  Definitely worth a stop while in San Francisco's China Town!
author: Marilyn P.

description: This is really a take out place with only 1 table for customers to sit and eat. Basically, you can choose from a variety of dim sum items and either sit at that one table if available or take it to go. The dim sum is awesome and at an excellent price. Check it out!
author: Vincent D.

description: Delicious pork dumplings and big pot stickers. This place isn't a restaurant but the food is authentic & savory.
author: Rosa W.

description: Love this place! everything was in chinese so the lady just showed us everything and told us in english what was in them. got a good variety of all the dim sum and it was absolutely delicious. We had originally gone to the Good mong kok bakery because the line was long so it must be amazing but didnt think it was worth the wait. Delicious dimsum definitely met my expectations and would be back again. We got 17 pieces for just $11.40! Can't beat the price. Wish I could come here everyday for lunch lol
author: Sara Y.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum gets the job done if you're craving dim sum.  The store front is very modest and the customer service standard.  The siu mai had tough bits of meat in it like many shops do.  The har gow were delicious and worthy of the store's name.  Their sesame seed balls lacked an appropriate amount of filling given their size.  The price is extremely competitive though.  11 pieces of Dim Sum for $7.30, very similar to Dim Sum Express in San Gabriel Valley in Los Angeles, but I'd give a slight edge in quality to Dim Sum Express.  Lastly, the dim sum pieces are a bit smaller than many dim sum store fronts in LA.

Edit: Looking back on my experience, I have to say that I was more disappointed with my visit than I wanted to be.  Heading to SF and reading all the reviews of various dim sum places got me really excited.  Now that I'm back in LA I realize that I wasn't very satisfied with the dim sum I picked up here.  Out of 4 items, I only enjoyed the har gow.  Dropping it to 2-stars.  I'd never go back if this storefront was in San Gabriel Valley.
author: Brian T.

description: The dim sum was very delicious just like their name entitles. We ordered har gow (shrimp) and shaomai (pork), and I believe the cost came out to about $20 to feed all 5 people in my party so it wasn't too pricey. The workers weren't great or bad, they just got the job done just like any other dim sum place in China Town. It is a to go place so there's no seating, only several chairs for when you're waiting.
author: Katie L.

description:
I've always loved coming to this Dim sum spot!

For any tourists in chinatown, don't be fooled by all the other dimsum joints on this street. There are some great ones around chinatown, but as for Jackson street, this is the ONLY legit spot! do not go to the spot down the street with the TV's and all that, they have horrible quality and will get you sick. 

Anyways, their sticky rice is on point and so is the shrimp dumplings. I always get their rice noodles with dried shrimp and green onions! Definitely VERY worth the price that you pay for especially with all the food you will end up with
author: Kenny L.

description: Best dim sum I've had in a long time! Fresh, yummy, and cheap! Loved it...Nom Nom Nom. Thanks to my coworkers for recommending it.
author: Yvette C.

description: The dim sum was good. It was pretty cheap for the amount we got. The wait as we were waiting in line wasn't too bad. Seating inside was very limited, there was only two small tables that were taken at the time. The downside was that it was CASH ONLY.
author: Alan O.

description:
Tons of stuff for 3/$1. Cheap lunch done!

This was quite a find. Prices aren't listed and the woman behind the counter was patient with us as we weren't quite sure what we were ordering. Everything was written in Chinese, and though we don't speak Chinese, I found the point method very useful. 

Portions large too...really small, more for take out/on the go than for dining, which suited our needs perfectly!
author: Leilani K.

description:
I employed the same technique here as at Good Mong Kok - point, receive, pay, eat - all without knowing exactly what I was going to bite into.  Everything got sort of cold after I stopped at House of Dim Sum to pick up a mango boba smoothie, but I take responsibility for that - I know with dim sum the trick is stuff it into your mouth immediately upon receiving it, and I didn't do that, so shame on me!

Despite being cold, though, everything was really good.  The steamed shrimp wrappers were a little thick and chewy, but the filling was to die for - garlicky as all-get-out with fresh vegetables that tasted like they had just been picked.  There was also a sticky rice cake with sweet, chai-ish spice and random things stuck in it that reminded me of fish rice wrap in Indonesia.  It was very nearly a dessert kind of thing.

Their char siu bao - hallelujah, I managed to accidentally point at a char siu bao! - was on the sweet side, with yummy cuts of meat and bright red sauce.  My only complaint was that there was too much bun and not enough delicious filling!

The price for a box stuffed with dim sum enough to feed my boyfriend and I, with more than few pieces left for later lest our stomachs explode?  $7.  Yes, $7.
author: Hannah E.

description: OMG! The best dim sum i ever had!!! I wasnt expecting much as i was passing by and just wanted to eat something real quick, but the xiao long bao and the shrimp dim sum were absolutely amazing.
author: David Y.

description: Just had pork dim sum. It was alright.  This means I need to compare woth others before making that statement
author: amrita b.

description: Just came here for some sesame balls and a steamed bun!   They were fresh and pretty hot!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Wow 2 pork buns, 1 turnip cake, 3 pieces chiu chow fun guo, 6 pieces har gow (wonderful shrimp dumplings) all for $7! I felt like I was getting a half price lunch!

Three ladies working the counter very friendly and efficient. Food was good and would go back again.
author: Jen L.

description: So wondering around chinatown for the first time and checked yelp for help. Found this place and decided to just go for it. I pointed at basically everything and ordered one of each. The price was pretty cheap but cash only. I got a fork and dived in on the street. Everything was awesome. I cant begin to tell you what was in them but savory meat and veggies? Doesnt matter - the experience was awesome. Go do it.
author: rachel m.

description: I have realized that dim sum is pricier in SF chinatown period, in comparison to LA. It's a matter of finding the tastiest dim sum out here. All the prices at the shops are competitive but I would come back here any day. Their dim sum was just piping fresh and delicious like their name! They don't mess around when it comes to their shu mai. I tried the other places around chinatown and some didn't taste good or was just cold and not fresh. I really recommend this place to everyone looking for that good dim sum. Only bad thing is there isn't a place to sit and eat there so better off taking it togo.
author: Xtine L.

description: I am sorry but Delicious Dim Sum is not delicious... Walk couple block down and get Good Mong Pok. It is so much better. Dim Sum at Delicious is smaller, drier, and not as flavorful. We got Xiu Mai, different types of dumplings and they were all bleh. I got this sticky rice with pork, mushroom, and eggs wrapped in leaf. That was pretty good but fatty and so much MSG!!!!!
author: Katie T.

description: I'm not quite sure what I ordered besides potstickers and a pork bun... But it was tasty & cheap!! Highly recommend.
author: Alexis N.

description: Cheap and delious! I ordered some shrimp dumpling and got 15 for like $9! And the taste was great, and the line to get some was getting longer as I walked out. For sure Yelp approved.
author: Tone A.

description:
The Dim Sum and dumplings here are so grand.  I live in Seaside and will travel all the way to San Francisco just to grab 8 or 9 dozen of these.  they are so worth the trip.  

The thing I love is getting them uncooked and bringing them home to steam myself.  I even take them to work and steam them there and enjoy them fresh.    You can't find no place anywhere close to or in Monterey that compares.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Con - Too expensive for the quality I got

Beef noodle roll - Beef itself good and flavorful. The noodle was too soft and mushy, Add soy sauce to it and I was basically eating mush.
author: Welmond C.

description: Best place for take out dim sum ! Super cheap ! Har Gaow and chives dumplings are the best !!!!!!!!!
author: Delphine R.

description: We basically got two of everything for $9.60. The bbq pork steam buns were my favorite. The shui mai were also pretty darn good. Definitely worth the trek and the short walk to a nearby park to eat. The shrimp noodles were pretty good, as was the chive dumplings. Everything was fresh, the service was friendly and helpful, though there's usually a line here. Worth it, though.
author: Erik B.

description:
I was craving dim sum like a mofo so I browsed the reviews on Yelp. I was looking for a cheap to-go spot, and this fit the bill. Again, my fellow Yelpers did not disappoint!

Tips:
- Know what you want to order before you get there. The menus are in Chinese and you can't see all the dim sum because they have it stacked in different steam pots. So browsing isn't really practical. Plus, there's the language barrier.

- Dim sum is ordered by individual pieces. I made the mistake of saying "two orders of pork and shrimp dumpling" and she gave me two dumplings. So there you go.

- Cash only

- Dim sum is around 40 cents a piece and you only need about 6-8 dumplings to get full. They have one small table crammed in the back. So they automatically assume you're ordering to-go unless you tell them you're eating there.

The pork and shrimp dumpling turned out to be shu mai. It was very tasty, filling and not overly greasy. I also got the chive and shrimp dumplings, which turned out to be more chive than shrimp. Lots and lots of chives. Eek. Next time, I'll try the prawn style dumplings or the siu long bao. I finished off my order with a sesame ball for dessert. Tasty!

Grand total: $4.40 for 8 dumplings and a sesame ball. Suck it, Yank Sing. I'll take Chinatown's 40-cent dumplings over yours any day.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Working in the financial district means expensive lunches. This place is literally a hole in the wall. There are a good amount of dim sum takeout spots in Chinatown, and this sometimes translates to food that has been sitting out so long that the dim sum gets hard and dry. Not here. Ladies are friendly and serve up steaming hot dim sum. 

Where else can you get 9 pieces of dim sum and a coke for under $5? Recommend the gau choi gao (chive dumplings).
author: Andy T.

description:
Being able to order dim sum by individual pieces is pretty great.

Bit of a language barrier here. I got lucky as the lady in front of me was fluent in both English and Cantonese so she offered to order for me. 

I picked 2 pieces of har gow, 2 pieces of shrimp & cilantro dumplings and 1 sesame ball. Cost $2.40. NICE!

Dumplings here are BIG. I went at 8am so everything was very fresh. The har gow in particular were the freshest I have ever tasted. The sesame ball was greasylicious too.

It would be nice if you could sit down and eat. Take out dim sum is not as satisfying as eating it in a restaurant, but I did walk over to the park with my takeout box and enjoyed it there.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Small or no line compared to the more popular places like Good Mong Kok Dim Sum. I'm not the biggest fan of shrimp dumpling (har gow) but they definitely make a really good one! 

Their beef shiu mai was okay (pork shiu mai was not available even though I went at 12pm...). 

Pork bun was very lacking in pork. Basically a lot of bread and very little pork.

Sesame ball was quite average - greasy, chewy, and delicious.

This place is strictly for take out, but somehow I managed to get a seat out of a two they had inside the store.
author: Jason T.

description:
Tiny hole in the wall dim sum place.

There was one table and luckily for me and my group of friends no one decided to dine in there, but us so we got that table.

The dim sum is probably the cheapest dim sum Ive had and its huge too! Its not the best dim sum or anything, but its cheap and pretty good! I really liked the pot stickers and har gao.
author: Phuong K.

description:
When they named this place Delicious Dim Sum they weren't kidding. It's pretty damn tasty dim sum. Though I'm sure that name was taken. Still, Delicious Dim Sum is good enough of a name. 

The neat thing about this place is that it's quick, which is nice since the meters around anywhere S.F. are unforgiving and all consuming when it comes to your coinage. You just run in and within a minute you're pretty much out the door - the only limitation is your inability to make a decision. 

Hint; always get the har gow. mmmmm shrimp. 

In a area that has more dim sum places per square inch than you can shake a steamer pot at, this does stand out as one of the better options. The cheap price will get you through the door but the delicious dim sum keep you coming back
author: Javier J.

description:
The "Soup Nazi" came to mind as I was ordering the dim sum....food was great, but friendliness was not at the top of the list. Don't get me wrong - it's more of a compliment than a negative thing! You just need to know what you're ordering and not ask any questions. 
The pork bun and shrimp dumplings were very tasty and the price was right. The shrimp and cilantro dumplings were also pretty good. I didn't care for the rice noodle with the salty mini-shrimp. For the sweet tooth, the sesame ball with sweet black bean filling was very pleasing to the taste buds.
author: Rudy H.

description: Terrible!!! Lost a day's worth of wages due to this place because I couldn't make it to work. Had a few pieces of the har gow, shrimp/cilantro dimsum, and the rice noodle with shrimp. I'm pretty sure I didn't get sick of the soy sauce packet. I know sanitation is not their top priority and i surely paid a hefty price for it. Frequent bathroom trips and vomiting is how I'm spending this Sunday. I do not recommend this place unless you have a stomach made of steel, however even then, please be careful.
author: Mia O.

description: Was going to forego this place because of no seating. But took the advice of another Yelper to eat and walk..  We got the last of their inventory at 4:30 but it was still delicious!!  The cilantro dumplings were especially yummy!!  Definitely recommend..
author: Soo M.

description:
going to keep this review short and simple since everybody already mentioned everything..

-small place.. easy to miss
-a little above average food
-cheap pricing
-no where to sit and eat since there is 1 table and few chairs
-good service
author: Darren F.

description:
The har gow was good - but can't say its anymore outstanding than other places I've gone to in San Gabriel Valley (So Cal).  It is cheap and the staff was  - I guess I got the nice ones.

Order har gow, shu mai and har gow with veggies.
author: Mary M.

description: Their shrimp dumplings are their biggest sellers. Hubs likes the chive dumplings. You can pass on the pan fried turnip cake - too dense.They also have lots of buns and pastries to choose from.
author: Julie L.

description: Delicious indeed! Amazing value. We got the steamed pork buns, the shrimp and chive dumpling, and the pork shumai. All for $3.50! Would definitely recommend this.
author: Brittany G.

description: Really glad I stopped here for lunch. Had the shrimp dumplings, chives dumplings and shrimp rice crepe (dunno what they're called in English) and they were all very good! The shrimp dumplings didn't have any shrimp flavor but that might be because I was so absorbed by the perfection of the skin! I've had dim sum in NYC, Houston, Guangzhou, and HK and I've never tasted dumpling skin so chewy. It didn't fall apart at first bite but it also didn't take too much effort to chew. Love it! The only thing is to not expect too many smiles here. I spoke in Cantonese with a lot of "thank you" and "please" but the employee that was helping me still complained. Lesson learned: tell her everything that you want from the get go otherwise she has to change boxes! Also there was no room to sit so come with a small group or plan out a different place to sit and eat. There was one table (2 chairs) and then several chairs on the side.
author: Laura Y.

description:
In my three days of dim sum breakfasts before work in SF, I've tried three different places - House of Dim Sum, Yummy Dim Sum and Delicious Dim Sum.

This was, by far, the best place. I ordered 2 shrimp dumplings, 2 veggie and shrimp dumplings and a turnip cake. Yes, that's a pretty large breakfast, and yes, I ate it all. 

The dumplings were really fresh and less greasy than other places - the turnip cake was thick and filling and a nice, solid flavor.

I loved it. I wish I lived here so I could eat here all the time.
author: Thao N.

description: i been coming here since the early 2000's and have never been disappointed yet, iam not sure what their hours are but i usually come early in the morning around 7:30 so i dont have to deal with traffic and finding parking because SF Chinatown is pretty much dead that time of morning, i usually order the sil lung bow, nau mai gai and the har gow and i am headed back over the bay bridge
author: James S.

description: Just walk in and let the person at the counter handle your order if this is your first time. When we go back a second time, we'll be having the steamed beef (so yum) and the shrimp/chive dim sums. Don't bother with the sauces - the flavours are right in there.
author: Aditi C.

description: This place is the definition of small business. But for being this small it's absolutely amazing! The service was incredible, the managers happy face put a smile on the rest of ours. The food quality was outstanding for the low price. Speaking of the price, only $5.99 per person for all you can eat dim sum! This is great, would recommend to anyone who is adventurous and looking for some great food.
author: Zack M.

description:
This review isn't based on the dumplings, the location, or the service.

It's based on the sign.

I KNOW they have the right idea as the front window sign is spelled properly, but I have never heard of "Deliclous" before. Why hasn't someone changed it? If they neglect signage, what else could possibly be lacking? Makes me nervous.
author: Kristin F.

description: when i don't want to or can't make it to the inner richmond for dim sum, this is where i go for back up. I've tried other local dim sum fast food joints and they just don't do it for me. Granted i do have quite a few more that i have not had the chance to try, but this one still remains to be the best for me. Will be back as my mom loves to shop in Chinatown.
author: Janet D.

description:
Very good value fresh dim sum. Friendly people. 

Tiny interior but you can sit on the one table or stand and eat at the counter.
author: John M.

description: This used to be good stuff but lately they are cutting costs so the chives dumpling no longer taste fresh. Very disappointed
author: Julie L.

description:
It is unceremonious and you should not expect to sit anywhere, though a table with two chairs exists. What you can say, it is by far the best tasting value dim sum I've had, despite my lack of experience with such places. 

Best is certainly the shrimp and the veggie dumplings, though the shu mai are good as well. Overall, a solid joint for taste and value. Pretty sure all of them were $.60 a piece, across the board. Yum
author: Mike S.

description: Totally authentic and not a word of English in the place. Very nice and we were able to point to what we wanted and give a quantity. Absolutely delicious. We had the shrimp, pork, and shrimp & veggie items and none of them disappointed.
author: Richelle R.

description: We managed to fit our group of six in there for brunch! The ladies were very friendly and pulled out extra chairs for us. It's a little dodgy that they just lay saran wrap on sticky trays and pile the food on, but oh well. I was full to bursting and it only cost me $4.20!  The dim sum pieces are hearty but not greasy. I'd pass on the steamed pork bun, but everything else was indeed delicious. I just wish they had the fried taro ball with the minced pork filling, and the shrimp balls with crispy wonton flakes outside. We also didn't get tea - and beware, the teapot on the one dine-in table is actually soy sauce.
author: Cat N.

description:
SO CHEAP, but so not "DELICIOUS."  First off, it's basically a to-go spot... with only one dirty table in the back to eat at if you're daring enough.  Still, we decided to brave it and ordered a LOT of food for under 15 bucks, maybe even less.  Unfortunately, it tasted as cheap as it cost.

Everything was just okay at best.  Plus, the shrimp crepe didn't come with any of that yummy slightly sweet sauce it's usually served with at a sit-down joint.  As a result, we basically paid for some flat hagow (which we had already ordered)... not to mention the food temp was just barely warm.

To top our experience off, the lady that worked the front was downright rude.  She rolled her eyes at us when we said that we were eating it there and she had already started putting our food in the clear, plastic to-go box.  I guess packaging costs are really that big of a deal to her.  Plus, she came to the table and took back our containers of soy sauce from our bag without saying a word to us (I'm guessing because they have a dispenser at the table... but at least SAY something!).  Lastly, she gave us attitude because we asked for little individual plates to eat from.  Calm down lady!  They're just paper plates!

Really, I'd say the only plus about the place is that it is very affordable for the quantity of food you get as long as you're not looking for quality.
author: Vi T.

description:
Great if you love the xiu mai, as they're huge pieces of meat. I've got friends that don't eat anything except xiu mai, so this worked out pretty well for them. 3 pieces for $1.40. Taste is average, but what they lack in flavor they make up for in sheer size. Can't argue against that.

The other items are kind of whatevers. The dumplings weren't very good, but still run at 3 pieces for a $1.40. Again, they are sizable, but not that tasty. 

Since it's street food, it gives you great flexibility as a customer to buy only what you want to try. I'd strongly recommend trying more than one place in your walk through Chinatown.
author: Warren C.

description: I love that this little hole in the wall place serves up some killer dumplings.  I had no idea what to try so I got a little bit of everything and it ranged from good to great.  The best part was it was 6 bucks.  Definitely going back.
author: Jeremy W.

description: For inexpensive and commonly ordered dim sum, this hole-in-the-wall take out shop fits the bill. There's only one table with four chairs for dine-in. The made-in-house shrimp Cheong Fun was tasty but the wrap on the  dumplings and Har Gow were too thick and doughy. Five orders of different dim sum was around $13. The menu is only in Chinese but the items are visible from the counter.
author: Lana C.

description: This place was very good but not the best dim sum I have ever had. I am from the SGV so I am used to very high standards when it comes to dim sum. Delicious Dim Sum was a good meal but the price was higher than am I used to paying and the quality was a little lower than the norm. The service and ambiance were both excellent.
author: Leonard C.

description: Good for a quick snack and dim sum to go. There is not an area for seating except for a few chairs in front of the counter. To order it is easiest to just point at what you want as this is a real deal Chinese place and the menus are in only Chinese. I tried a variety some with cilantro and veggies, another with shrimp, and one with chicken and vegetables.
author: Lauren K.

description: Glad we followed fellow yelpers. Of all we tried the shrimp cilantro was the best flavor!, very balanced, cheap and delicious! Musicians can't go wrong in this place!
author: Nic H.

description:
(See pic)

Yes the name is exactly what they have plus more-- delicious dim sum and great wrapped sticky rice wtih green beans. They also make the "Lo mai gai" (sticky rice with chicken wrapped in lotus leaves.)

If you look a bit up at that entrance to the kitchen you can see the wrapping action going! Love to know when they make food at the shop. It represents authenticity and freshness.

Service was great and the owner did not even have time to have breakfast as she's busy making and selling at 1pm! 

Only takeout and no sit down which is perfect if you work or live nearby. That's also why after 1 order of prawn style dumpling, 1 order of Siu Long Bao (pork) and 1 order of chives with shrimp dumpling plus the big sticky rice wrap it's only $6.2!!
author: T L.

description:
San Francisco is a great place for those hankering for dim sum without wanting to go to a sit down restaurant. After several searches on Yelp, I stopped by Delicious Dim Sum to see if they would live up to its name. This fast food joint is literally a narrow walkway without an ambiance and the interior is dependent on the natural lighting coming through its large storefront window to keep the place operative. They charge $1.10 on most dim sum items that comes in threes, and the long line out the door tells me something about their turnover rate when it comes to food and the possibility that their dim sum might just be legit.

Pork dumpling: This dumpling came with an exterior that reminded me of xiao long bao without the juicy interior. The thick and tender pork loin and minced scallions was smooth and easy to bite into. It was delicious but the meat was on the fatty side and could be leaner.

Shrimp dumpling: Plump and voluptuous dumpling with enough shrimps to please. It was good!

Shumai: The taste of pork is nicely seasoned without it being redundant from the pork dumpling. As a comparison, the pork had a stiff and chewy texture and it was pretty juicy with every bite. I liked it.

Taro cake: The taro cake wasn't pan fried to render the desired crispy edges but there was a good soft texture that included sufficient amount of taro and pork. It was decent and not the best.

Sweet rice bun: The glutinous outer layer was perfect with a set of sticky rice that fell apart easily with a rich, infused pork flavor. This is a must get for those who are planning to visit.

All together, my dim sum brunch cost $3.60 and was enough to get me full while still have enough room for coffee afterwards. The three limitations I experienced was the poor service, a lack of a place to sit, and I believe their meat quality could be leaner. The older lady who helped me gave me the look of disbelief upon seeing the little food I ordered. I guess they're used to people buying in bulk but they also need to be sensitive and welcoming to those who are trying them for the first time. 

Secondly, unlike their other Chinatown fast food counterparts, this place does not have a place to sit. There is a little table in the back and while I was temporarily using the only set of condiments available on the table, an older White man stood nearby pointed to the table, asked and proceeded to teach me in an authoritative tone, "You're going to clean that up right?" He finger pointed to a small spill of red chili sauce on the table while I was half way done with the condiments. "We are using this table just so you know," as he clarified to me in case I didn't speak English and made sure that I'm fully aware that I was invading his space. Through our exchange somehow he assumed that I was not decent enough to clean after myself while he felt within duty to put me into servitude. Although his behavior is not a reflection on the restaurant and its employees, it was still a part of my experience here that was demeaning as he was using his moral authority to subjugate me into a subordinate position. There is a long and rich history of social and economic struggle in San Francisco Chinatown and given the context I will not let someone like him to tell me that his quality of life is more urgent than mine. Trust me, I made sure that he felt embarrassed for what he did before walking out.

Finally, although their dumplings are flavorful and delicious, the meat quality could still be leaner. I wish there are places like this nearby where I live since the price and level of convenience can't be beat. Despite the many bright spots, I still prefer You's Dim Sum on Broadway in Chinatown and Good Luck Dim Sum and Tao Yuen Pastry in other parts of the Bay Area. Without factor in the unexpected incident, 3.5 stars for the overall experience.
author: Daniel L.

description: you'd walk right past it and never really know, but I'm always happy to get pickup here before going on a road trip. shrimp dumplings, vege dumplings, really tender skin and great fresh taste. very recommended!
author: Grapes T.

description:
We were in the neighborhood and decided to try this place. How would I describe it? Cheap, fast dim sum to-go. This place doesn't pretend to be anything else. The quality is good, too.

It helps that I can speak Cantonese, but the woman serving me was very friendly. We also walked in while they were eating lunch, but she put her food down right away to help me.

We got: 

4 har gow
4 siu Mai
3 chive dumplings
2 shrimp and chive dumplings
2 sesame balls
1 chiu chow fun gor
An order of the red bean filled Mochi-like dessert

This was all only...wait for it...$10!! My bf was shocked. It was a ton of food, and I was stuffed after eating my share.

Will definitely be back!
author: Alison C.

description:
Wow, the Scallion and Shrimp dumplings were incredible. The best dumplings I've ever tasted. Very fresh with scallion as well as cilantro within an extremely thin rice cellophane exterior.

We also tried the pork, shrimp, and shrimp + chive dumplings, which were good as well, but the scallion versions were unreal.

Only seating for 4-6 be prepared to take this meal on the go.
author: Michael S.

description:
Tips:

Chicken feet are sold by the pound and half a pound is the minimum.

----------------------------------------------------------------

Ordered:
half a pound of chicken feet
1 lotus wrapped sticky rice
1 steamed radish cake
Total: $5.60

I forgot the individual prices, but I liked the dim sum from here. The chicken feet was great. 

- One criticism that I have to make is that the lotus wrapped sticky rice was made predominantly of rice. I would have liked it a LOT better if there was more filling.
author: Alice H.

description:
Super cheap.

We lucked out and grabbed the only table in the place. Good dim sum, better if it were hot.
author: Trang B.

description: I did not find any lines here. Got a few shrimp dumplings here and they tasted delicious.
author: Angik S.

description:
I am so glad that my friend told me about this place. The dumplings here are so good! My two favorites are the shrimp dumplings and the chive dumplings. They are steamed to perfection. I've had dumplings at other places where the bottom gets soggy, but that is not the case here. 
This isn't one of those dine in places.There are about 1 or 2 tables. Since the place is pretty tiny and crowded don't expect to get a table.
author: Jenny B.

description: This place is soo good. I went to the top three dim sum places in China town and chose to do buy here a very large order to take home. The other two places weren't what i hoped for, but this place by far was the best. Good mong kok was sold out of shu mai and Char su bows at 1pm and the other items I did purchase from them I thought "what is all the hype about this place"..so I guess to each his own. This place is worth a visit and family is super happy I brought dim sum back from my trip.
author: Sienna L.

description: Was looking around China town for some dim sum when a nice man walked up to us and asked if we were looking around for dim sum and then showed us this place! The food was great and we paid 4.00 for two of us total bargain!! Definitely going back here the next time I'm in San Fran! Thank you to the nice man who showed us this place and ordered the good stuff!!!
author: Amanda M.

description: As with any traditional fast food Chinese place the service is sub par but the food was stellar!! Such a good find. Awesome dumplings for a cheap price. About 5 different foods for $10... what a steal!!!
author: Jessica C.

description: Great dim sum nice people really inexpensive. Nothing fancy but right to the point. Would definetly return for more.
author: R N.

description: Authentic, American SF Cantonese, hole in the wall, counter style, push your way in and get the pink box tied up with pink string dim sum.  I love it.  Brings you back to your childhood.  This is what we ate back in the day and they are still cranking it out, good as ever.  The ha gow, siu mai, scallop dumpling, were the bomb.  Perfect combo of tastes.  The fun goh, the noodle wrapper was a little on the thick side, but still tasty.  Inexpensive, tasty tasty tasty that people inhale once you bring it to where you're going.  They run out of things, so get there early-ish.  Really, my 4 year old inhaled 5 ha-gow pieces in 3 minutes. I could not get him to stop.  Love it.  Get some.
author: Alittle G.

description: Delicious Dim Sum says it all! A hidden little gem on Jackson St. Cash and carry. The menus in the wall are all in Chinese but don't worry, just point and say "two of those, three of those" etc. They're all delicious. A big togo container of 7 dumplings costs about $5. I'm here every San Fran layover!
author: Don S.

description: Literally the BEST dimsum I have ever had and SOOOOO cheap!
author: Michele P.

description: This is my fav place for takeout dim sum.  The har gow and sui mei both have good shrimp and pork flavor.  I like it a bit better than at Good Mong Kok Bakery.  This is also the place that has my fav version of traditional sticky rice.  I showed up around 8:30am and they were really fresh.  They had more peanuts and pork than any other place I tried.
author: Soo H.

description:
The best take out dim sum I have tried in all of SF. 

After waking up from having dreams all night about dim sum, I woke up with a craving so bad I had to give in! I have been to quite a few different dim sum spots in Chinatown SF, and honestly I am always a little disappointed. This time was different though! 

Delicious Dim Sum is a perfect name for this Chinatown hole in the wall. The Shrimp Dumpling (Har Gau), Steam Dumpling (Siu Mai) and the Shrimp and Chive Dumplings were all DELICIOUS! They were so fresh! The dumplings all were constructed very well and the fillings scrumptious! The Har Gau was AMAZING! 4 different items (12 pieces total for $6)

 :-) 

I will DEFINITELY be back!
author: Natalie C.

description: Absolutely lives up to its name!! the Dim Sum was DELICIOUS! Whenever I go back to San Francisco I will definitely be making my way to chinatown for some Delicious Dim Sum. Take it from me I am picky when it comes to places to eat and I was very much impressed with this place!
author: Amanda M.

description: I went here this Sunday around 3pm when the streets were crowded with people for chinese new year. The place was running low on dumplings but the ones we managed to get were really good, especially the shrimp and chive ones. They also had an interesting pork and peanut dumpling that I had never had before. No one really spoke English so I managed to order by pointing at the ones I wanted. We sat at the one table that was available inside, but its definitely a to-go kind of place.
author: Vanathi G.

description:
We Yelped up this place while visiting SF last week. The food was AWESOME!  Indeed, no English signs in the store, very little English spoken by the staff.  We know the names of our favorites and we pointed at a couple more.  $7 was enough to fill up our family of four. 

Next time I'm in town, I'm heading right over.
author: Jon C.

description:
Solid pick-up-and-go dim sum!

Generally I try to stop by for a few dumplings here while on my walks through Chinatown and North Beach.  Their har gow is super delicious, and their scallion dumpling is pretty good too.  Selection is limited, and it's a bit dingy, but this place is a great place to stop by for a snack!
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
At first was wary of a place which has to tell you it's "delicious".

From my experience, if they have to tell you it's good, then odds are, it's not.

Happy to say, this place bucked the trend.  It is very DELICIOUS and the prices even deliciouslier :)

 Perfect place if you're on the go - not a sit down place.
author: Lev E.

description:
I don't know if its age talking or if I'm just out of practice, but I loathe driving into the City to deal with traffic, parking (or lack thereof) and crowds.  So here's a suburban girl's guide to procuring Delicious dim sum:

Prep:
1.) pack chopsticks, napkins, soy sauce and drinks
2.) use the car that will endure spills and food stains easily
3.) bring reliable, foodie driver
4.) prepare cash

Execution:
1.) Do the drive by; be ready to hit the ground running as you jump out of the moving vehicle.
2.) Have driver drive around the block.
3.) Get into store, point to whatever looks good (Har gow, Shrimp with Chives and Shrimp with Scallions FTW).  
4.) Hold conversation to a minimum.  NO questions.  I heard the owner kicks you out if you ask stupid questions like, "Is that good?  What's in it?"
5.) Hand over cash.
6.) Hold bag securely under one arm as you run at pace to jump back into moving vehicle as it comes back around.
7.) Commence eating.  Feed self, feed driver.  Repeat.

You'd have finished your meal by the time you reach the end of the Bay Bridge.  And when  you get home, you'll be ready for a nice nap!
author: Teresa P.

description:
This place is my go-to place for cheap dim-sum in SF now. After happening upon this place two years ago, I've been back several times whenever I'm in the chinatown area.

The shu mai and har gow (xia jiao - shrimp dumplings) here are great, and I'd definitely get a large amount of both. Their lo mai gai (nuo mi ji - sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves) is terrific as well. In addition, they have some leek dumplings and assorted other dim sum offerings. 

A word of advice, however, they sometimes run out of things but have them again later, so if they say the thing you want isn't there, try asking if they plan on having it later on, and perhaps explore chinatown for a bit and come back.

A great place to eat afterwards is the Portsmouth square garden, which is close by. I usually go to the Quickly's nearby and buy some boba tea for a killer combination!
author: Alexander L.

description:
This is my go-to place to get dim sum in Chinatown! They have good dimsum and amazing prices! Every time I come here, I get a good amount of food for less than $5. I always get ha gow (shrimp dumpling), siu mai, and ha churng (shrimp wrapped in rice noodle).
I've tried other dim sum places and I feel like the quality isn't any better and it's usually more expensive. The only reason why this isn't a five-star place is that I can get similar quality and priced dim sum in Oakland's Chinatown.
Keep in mind that at most asian restaurants, you have to be pretty aggressive to get your food.
author: Stephanie W.

description: 3 orders for $5.20: super stuffed. Lucked out n got to sit at the one table they have too!
author: Mimi D.

description: They really need to expand.   There's one table so you basically have to get it to go, but they have the best dumplings I've ever had.  The veggie and shrimp ones are very highly recommended.  The fried ones are good too.  and the price is awesome.  Must try!
author: Soo Jin M.

description:
10 pieces of hao gao, 10 pieces of siu mai, 5 various dumplings, 3 char siu bao, and 1 black sesame ball were only about $17.

The siu mai was good and I'd say were the same or better quality than several dim sum restaurants I've been to. The hao gao was decent, although the dumpling skin was too thick. I wouldn't order the other dumplings again (one was jiou chai huh zhe and I forgot what was in the other). Good Mong Kok's char siu baos are much better (bigger, juicier, and more filling). My mom liked the sesame ball and she's quite picky.

Overall, decent dim sum for a great price, although I think they use MSG.because we all got verryyy thirsty.

I also noticed that we weren't charged for a plastic bag...I thought SF had a mandatory 10 cent (?) charge? tsktsk...
author: Lauretta L.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum really is DELICIOUS.   Problem is... horrid customer service.  LoL.  I expect that in Chinatown joints but this was really bad.  I ask for an extra garlic chili sauce and I thought the woman was going to have a heart attack!  She told me I didn't need more than 1 and when I said I used a lot and really liked it, she argued with me.  I told her to charge me for it and she begrudgingly gave it to me for no charge.  I walked away without waiting for my change to make it up to her though. LoL

Even after that, with such a bad opinion in our mind, my friend and I couldn't deny that this super cheap dim sum was SO good.  We had walked down to the Chinatown park to eat it and almost walked back up to get more!!

I'd definitely go back.  Just take your own garlic chili sauce if you want extra.  (They could just have a lil sign and charge $0.25 cents for extras and avoid all the stress.)

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description: This restaurant was so affordable and so tasty. The only way it could be better is if it had tables where you could eat your food. I had four or five pieces of dim sum and it was maybe $3. How can you beat that? The locals clearly visited there which is always a good sign.
author: Lisa O.

description: Dim Sum at this place was really good.  They had the dim sum in a case so you had to order how ever many you wanted.  They had a large variety.  The only thing about this is that some customers would get a massive amount of dim sum and they would have to make more.  Other than the wait, the food was really good and the price was reasonable.  For three of us, it costed less than $20 to be full.   This was good dim sum.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Excellent dim sum!  One of my favorites in The City.  The pork/veggie buns and the multiple variations of shrimp dumplings are very good.

Other reviewers have complained that this place is tiny and there is limited seating.  This is how Dim Sum is often done in Chinatown.  And people, on the window it clearly says, in big red letters in English...take out Dim Sum.  Delicious is not a tourist joint that will have every little thing a tourist wants (table service, chopsticks, valet parking, etc.)  Make like a Chinatown native: line up, order your grub, and go...
author: Reg R.

description: Dont let the looks fool you. The place is great food worth the wait. Just have your finger ready to point no english menu.
author: Cecil M.

description:
came early about 930, super cheap.. my order including bottled water was under $10

ordered:
-har gow: good
-shu mai: good
-shrimp chive pan fried dumpling: good
-shrimp noodle roll: way too much noodle and it had a weird texture compared to what im used too. terrible..
-char shiu bao: bun was too dry, bbq pork was ok
-egg custard bun: bun wasn't as dry, custard was ok

note:
-take out spot
-1 table w 4 chairs and 2 chairs on the side, if you're eating in

i wouldn't come back here again
author: Raquel T.

description: Nothing too special, but not a miserable experience either. Mediocre dim sum for an affordable price. Shrimp dumplings and steamed pork buns were both heavier on the skin than the meat, which was disappointing; however, they did seem to keep a fresher inventory than some fast food dim sum places I've been to in San Francisco. Id say come if it is convenient-- otherwise try elsewhere.
author: Neal C.

description: If you're exploring Chinatown solo, forget about going to a restaurant and head over to Delicious Dim Sum. Three dim sums for much less than two bucks and those are not small but really good size dim sums. There's one table in the back, tell them you want to eat there and he lady I'll bring you soy sauce and chilli sauce. For less than $8, you will enjoy fantastic dim sums. My favorates were the Pork & vegetables and shrimp and vegetables. Next time I'm in town I'm heading over and ordering less this time.
author: Johnny A.

description: This place is awesome, diamond in a sea of diamonds. Food was amazing, cheap and fresh. Since this is take out only, we went to Union Square park to eat. Definitely worth the walk from the wharf.
author: Lindsey D.

description: Went with a friend for light afternoon dim sum snack. We had no idea what anything was, only that everything had either shrimp, pork, or beef (so I guess all you vegetarians are out of luck). We basically got 4 shrimp things and pointed to three other things at random and got two of each. The ten pieces total were only $7 and by god, every single one of them was amazingly delicious. It was a nice snack for the two of us, but it would a good sized meal for one person and totally worth it.
author: Carlos M.

description: The service here really really sucks!  The boss lady ALWAYS has a sour puss face.  I have never seen her smile or say thank you.  She has the typical China mentality thinking she is doing us a favor.  They are petty -charging you extra for everything - like ten cents for a container.  She wraps dumplings in a tissue paper, and of course, the dumplings are smashed when I got home.  Beware of the pastries in their glass case, stale hard as a rock.  However, today was the final straw.  The boss lady was blowing her nose with her hands, and the older employee lady was changing her socks behind the counter.  That really grossed me out.
author: Do Min J.

description:
WOW! Simply amazed at this hole in the wall dim sum spot. I was at a friends house early morning just Yelping dim sum spots nearby and came across this one. Read the reviews and decided to give it a try. First off I got REALLY LUCKY for coming on a Sunday and getting parking right in front. So that was a plus (for that visit) and not having to wait in line.

It's not a Dine in location, so just make sure you remember it's TO GO only and CASH ONLY. The prices are pretty good, about $1.80 per dish. Duck feet was about $4/lb. Anyways onto the food itself. The insides of the Dim Sum was very filling. It was fresh and soft so you know it wasn't sitting very long. I don't know the names of the dishes I ordered, so I can't tell you which ones were good based on names only by descriptions. The clearlike cilantro dim sum was so good and had so much flavor. Shrimp shumai was really flavorful and soft! The pork one was actually kinda dry when I got it, so I dont know if I'd try that again. The Chives and shrimp dish was pretty good too. Other than that everything I got minus the pork shumai was tasteful and packed inside. I'd definitely go here again.
author: gee b.

description: Dim sum was delicious. I would recommend the pork and shrimp with cilantro. We did not like the beef dim sum and would not recommend to anyone. There is only one table with seating for 4.
author: Sabrina C.

description: Awesome pot stickers and shrimp dumplings.  We waited in a small line, but were rewarded with delicious lunch!  Great experience!
author: Nicole F.

description: Great Dim Sum (takeout but, a couple of tables in back . . . not a great eat in place).  Pleasant, efficient staff.  Great prices.  Cannot be beat.
author: J C.

description: My spot for Dim Sums in Chinatown, can't beat them. Also, prices are incredibly great. If you are in Chinatown I definitely recommend to give it a try
author: Sara C.

description: My go-to for to-go in Chinatown. I often stop by on my walk to work for a cheap and filling breakfast, I buy platters from them when I'm entertaining, and I bring visitors here to sample the shrimp dumplings and pork buns--even people who claim they "don't like dim sum" (???) like these. I've liked everything I've tried here, but the shrimp har gow are definitely always part of my order. Yes, the ladies behind the counter can be brisk (I'd advise against small talk), but they're efficient and make delicious food! I find it's easiest just to point at different items and ask about the filling, rather than try to ask about multiple items on the menu. And in case you're suspicious of Dim Sum recs from a pale Irish/Dutch midwesterner, don't worry--my friends who grew up in China love this place too. :)
author: Alison S.

description: My husband is a big fan of dim sum so we had to find some on our trip to SF.  Yelp helped us to find this place and we was not disappointed.  We sat at the 1 sad little table they have (it really is a take out place) but the food was good and he was very happy.
author: Anne B.

description:
Pure deliciousness every time I come to this place.

SF has a TON of dim sum to go places in Chinatown and on Clement, but for some reason, I always come back here. It's nothing special from the outside but the food is amazing and you and a friend can walk out full for under $10.

I absolutely love turnip cake and this place fulfills my urge every time. The shrimp dumplings and shu mai are some healthy portions. They do a great job with a small staff, like every other place.

I'm starting to believe that the simpler the name, the better it is. Delicious Dim Sum is exactly what I want. Places that are named like Golden Palace, Lucky Garden, etc. never seem to entice me. 

Thumbs up to this place!
author: Alex T.

description:
SOO GOOD! I'm not a Dim Sum expert, but it was freakin good, man. three pieces for $.50... how do you even make profit off of that? Bao pork buns were also $.50 each (for a pretty sizeable bun). 



When my friend asked for another pack of soy sauce, one of the ladies said it was too salty, and refused to give him one. My friend is quite persistent, and was able to argue into getting his way. Victory!
author: Charla A.

description:
Loved their shrimp/cilantro dumplings and shumai.
I felt like these people take their time preparing their food - can definitely taste the quality in their food.
The seating is very limited (maybe 4 chairs only, no tables).
author: S K.

description: the food is good but the customer service is bad, the lady was rude and was acting like she was doing us a favor. not going to be going back there any time soon.
author: Megan V.

description: I was here in August of 2013. The dough on the shrimp and cilantro dumplings & har gow was rubbery. The flavor was average. Steamed Minced pork bun was ok but bread part was a little sweet. I'll try many other places before returning.
author: Gantsa Maven Z.

description: Excellent but note this is primarily a take away place - they were very welcoming but they have just one table to eat in and it is very basic service but the dumplings are amongst the best you will find anywhere (around the world!)
author: Richard O.

description: Shrimp Dumplings and the Shrimp Chive are my go to dim sum.  Haven't tried anything else since I literally can't understand what they're saying when they tell me what they have.  There is not much room to sit and eat, so make sure you're taking it home or have somewhere near to sit down and eat.
author: Kate K.

description:
Not really an eat-in place... there is one (dirty) table in the back where you can sit and eat. I did, with 3 white friends. Thanks to Delicious Dim Sum, they had delicious dim sum (go figure) for just $7pp. I know, that sounds pricey but we did eat a lot. 

Thanks for the dirty table and not bothering at all to wipe it down when we sat, DDS. You lived up to the "we don't care about cleanliness or germs, we just care about tasty food" rule that I schooled my white friends about. 

Thanks for not speaking any English and not having a single word in English on the menu or anywhere in the store. They really felt an authenticity to their meal. 

Thanks for the hocking a loogie soundtrack coming from the kitchen in the back. They now know our secret ingredient.

Yummy food. but a tip for you all... just get take out.
author: Angela C.

description:
I was walking around the city, when a strong urge to buy dim sum came over me.  So I walked up to Chinatown from Union Square and just started looking around for dim sum.  After almost getting hit by a car, I came across a huge line of people waiting at a small dim sum shop.  This must be a good place since there were so many people waiting in line for it.  As I was about to jump in line, my stomach started growling and I decided that I was just too hungry to wait for everyone to order.  So, I walked down the street to look for another dim sum place.  That's when I found Delicious Dim Sum.  It sounded generic enough and the sheer brilliance of the name was calling to a Gweilo like me.  

As I stepped in, I was saddened by the menu only being written in Chinese.  I wondered how can a shop with such a brilliant name have a menu in only Chinese?  Well, after trying my best to tell the lady I wanted Shu Mai, Har Gow and things that are similar, I relented and asked the lady behind the counter if she could show me what they had and I'd point to it.  After the awkward exchange, I ended up buying 3 days worth of Dim Sum for about $10.  Score!  The dim sum was actually good too, much better than what you can get at crummy dim sum places like Joy Luck Place for about a quarter of the cost.  

Moral of the story I guess is, don't let the weird name fool you, the place is pretty good. But, I'll still need to go to the busy Dim Sum place too, but maybe I'll bring one of my Cantonese speaking friends with me, so I don't have to hold up the line with my awkwardness...
author: Joe N.

description: AWESOME!!!! Get the shrimp and cilantro. The wife loved the pork. Cheap and amazing!!!!
author: Sergio L.

description: This place is AUTHENTIC. No english words anywhere. We had the shrimp and vegetable dim sum and they were incredible!
author: Jessica C.

description:
This was my second dim sum stop in Chinatown and definitely a step above my first, which was You's.  As far as the dim sum goes, Delicious has everything you need to satisfy your dim sum cravings, and delivers on both flavor and authenticity.  

I ordered your standard items shui mai, har gow, and shrimp cheong fan, as well as a dumpling filled with shrimp pork and cilantro (def the best of the bunch if you ask me).  Everything was pretty good, with the shrimp pork and cilantro dumpling as the standout.  Make sure that you order this...

Overall I would say that Delicious Dim Sum does in fact live up to its namesake.  No surprises.  Cheap, delicious, and right next door to Golden Gate Bakery, which is a big plus.  Make sure you stop by for some of their egg tarts!
author: Michael C.

description: This place lives up to its name. Everything I had there is amazing. I visit this place every time I'm in SF and they never disappoint. I'm looking forward to visiting them again this spring when I will be visiting some friends in the bay area. I love their ha gao -- I can never say enough about them: the shrimp is tender and juicy, I even enjoy these bad boys without the soy sauce, they're just that good. You can just order a whole bunch, they'll stuff 'em in boxes, and you'll be on your way. Great authentic taste -- every item is simply perfect. Go there, now! And try them!
author: Graham F.

description: Very cheap, delicious dim sum.  Better to go early in the day as it is fresher and you have more choices.  We got 6 pieces for $3.80. Wonderful mid day snack.  Ask for the spicy sauce they keep in the fridge, although it is not homemade, it's awesome.  We had the shrimp/veggie(our favorite) BBQ pork buns were awesome(boyfriend says) the pork dumpling we had wasn't so much our fav bc it was dried out.  It's a take out spot.
author: E T.

description:
The name of the business says it all.

Order Siu Mai, Har Gow, and Char Siu Bao here. It'll cost you maybe $5 for those three orders and you'll be well-stuffed.
author: Kenny O.

description:
While on a self guided tour of Chinatown in San Francisco, we came across "Delicious Dim Sum" (Thanks Yelp!). We ran out of our hotel without having breakfast and while hiking up the hill from Union Square to Chinatown, my fiancé and I realized that both of us were starving. I did what I normally do while traveling... pulled up Yelp app on my iPhone and searched for nearby dim sum places. Delicious Dim Sum was close by and we decided to give it a shot.

When we approached the place, we quickly realized it wasn't really a sit down restaurant, but rather a takeout place. That did not stop us... Lady working inside with very limited English almost did, but after utilizing key words like "shrimp", "chicken" and "pork", we managed to get a few item into a to go box for a quick snack.

We got shrimp steamed dumplings, some kind of pork baked dumplings and a sesame ball. Food tasted fresh, although wasn't very hot. Pork dumplings were my least favorite, but I'm just not a big fan of pork.

This place is good for take-out and a quick snack if you want to try some local food. It's realy cheap too, I believe we paid around $7, for 7 items.
author: Olga C.

description: perfect！！！everything was great and above all, cheap! Only one downside is parking but the service is fast so it is not a big problem!
author: Xinyu H.

description: The best sesame buns ever! They also had this spinach shrimp thing that was so good! Everything was really good. Just pick what looks good. Informal communal table in back. Cash only. The best!
author: Morgan E.

description: Went in as my last stop before the airport. Got some buns, shumai, dumplings, enough to fill a clear plastic container for only $3. No complaints here
author: D D.

description:
My favorite place for har gow (shrimp dumplings) in Chinatown!   In fact, their little vegetable dumpling triangles are my favorites, too.  Their pot-stickers are perfect when you want something more substantial.  Even the Health Department likes Delicious Dim Sum, and that's not something one can say about every restaurant in Chinatown.  
Whenever I meet a tourist asking about a place to eat in Chinatown, I direct them here.  Nobody has been disappointed yet.  And, the price is a pleasant surprise.
author: Mamie B.

description:
No written prices.  No English descriptions of anything.  Nowhere to sit.  The workers may or may not speak a language you can understand (likely not).

So what, I say.  This place gets a well-deserved 5 big stars.

The other reviewers are correct--just point to whatever you want and get as much as you want.  Say, "pork," or "shrimp," or "chives," or "beef" and you will be offered something and you should just nod your head and say how many of that item you want.  But be quick about--the place has a constant line for a reason.  

We got 10 large pieces (more than enough for two people) and the grand total was......$4.80.  For you math-challenged folks, that's $2.40 per person.  Hard to beat that.  

It's all take out, so keep that in mind.  Portsmouth Park is just a couple blocks away if you want to enjoy your food there.  

Best part of all:  almost everything was, as the name suggests, delicious.  The shrimp items, and the potstickers, were particularly good.
author: Craig W.

description: No English spoken here, but this place is worth the trip. Definitely check it out!
author: Ryan S.

description:
I love coming to SF to buy Dim Sum to go. I rarely come to the actual chinatown to get it just because of the parking issues and the pure congestion.  I usually opt for Happy dim sum over in Inner Sunset or Wing Lee at Clement.  But, lucky for me, I wasn't driving that day.

As with any typical dim sum place, this place was small and had a few workers taking your To-Go orders. The menu items are all written in chinese, so I had no idea what any of it said, what they had, nor what price everything was. I just ordered what I usually do - 2 orders of the shrimp dumplings, pork sui mai, fried mince pork ball. I also ordered the shrimp and green onion dumplings.  Got all this for $9!

After having been to mulitple dim sum places, I do have to say that this one is legit. The dumplings were very flavorful. I wish I had more of the shrimp dumpling orders!  We went to another dim sum place across the st and my friend said their shrimp dumplings weren't as good as this place. 

Would definitely recommend this place to my friends!
author: Diane L.

description: One of the best meals of my trip to San Francisco. They have stacks of steamers carrying various dumplings. I just asked for some random ones and was served them in a cute little plastic baggie. I was walking around the city for about 3 hours at this point and needed some food energy. This was a perfect holdover until dinner. The prices and concept of Dim Sum to-go were great.
author: P W.

description: I've been going here since 2004. Still a great Togo dim sum joint. Not really much of a place to sit, but the size of the dim sum is much larger than other places. Also, they are very generous with the meat portions and it is chopped large enough to see the shrimp is large chunks of shrimp. I've had it all, but my fans are the steamed bao, shrimp dumpling and suimai.
author: Callista T.

description: I had a phase when I was younger where I LOVED getting lo mai gai from here. My mom would buy probably around 6 every Saturday for a few months for my brother and I. Neither of us got sick of it for the longest time. It was the perfect food to eat after we got home from high school. Once we left for college, we stopped coming here until recently we would make the occasional trip here to get lo mai gai.  Not going to lie, the lo mai gai tasted just like I remembered it tasting. Super delicious and savory. Everything from the sticky rice to the ground meat to the sausage is damn amazing. The only thing I don't care for much is the little bit of hard boiled egg in it. To me, it doesn't really do much so without it I wouldn't miss it but I guess more protein can't hurt. Their dim sum items like shrimp dumplings, siu mai looks pretty good but out of all the times I've been here I haven't tried it yet. One day I'll try their dim sum items when I decide to get lunch from here but until then, lo mai gai it is!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
The name of the restaurant reflects the taste of the food. Delicious!!! Came here with the fam for a Chinatown dim sum fix, and was it worth it!  If we were to break down how much everything cost per person...the cost of the dimsum (per person) was cheaper than our BART roundtrip tickets!  Their har gao (shrimp dumplings) were incredible! Along with their beef and pork sio mai!

This place is a such a steal. Tasty, delectable dim sum for outrageously cheap prices!  I will definitely be coming back again soon!!!
author: Paula G.

description:
Tiny little place with limited seating. We order a few items and started wandering around looking for a place to eat our breakfast when we finally found an alley with some seats (and didn't have scary people). I only tried a few things here but I liked the dumplings. My friend was having the hardest time trying to eat her chicken feet with a fork...why don't they have wooden chopsticks? Poor thing.

No real reason to come back unless I'm looking for a quick fix of dim sum and I'm nearby.
author: Richard S.

description: Good dim sum but nothing earth shattering. Great prices. This place is busy and there was a long line
author: Jenny P.

description:
This place is my go-to for take out dim sum during my lunch hour. 

The food's always fresh and I'm in and out in less than a minute. No complaints here!
author: Tammy C.

description:
This place lives up to the hype. Their dim sum gets the job done :]

I'm a fan!
author: Jenny L.

description:
i like how the name matches the quality of their food.. the dim sum really is delicious! the chicken feet is soft and flavorful, the shrimp dumpling is big and tasty, the chive dumpling is also good. and all for a cheap price.

theres only two small tables so you might want to find a nearby drink place or head somewhere you can sit down and eat.
author: Thuong D.

description: In town for the day and one of my must goals was to get authentic Chinese food in Chinatown
author: Sonny D.

description:
This is some VERY GOOD, VERY DELICIOUS Har Gow! The BBQ pork bun, both steamed and baked, veggies, sui mai and the chicken feet are also Delicious! Too bad their isn't a place to sit inside (well there is a tiny table for 4 and if it's empty well then you have a place to sit). Regardless, I got my dim sum, starting eating it and I knew that I would want more, so I got back in line, yes people there is a line, which for me means GOOD FOOD. 
The staff is very pleasant and very patient, couldn't make up my mind quickly enough, so many appetizing things! 

I visited there several times during my stay in San Francisco and I have to say, totally worth it!
author: Estela T.

description: Super tasty shrimp dim sum!  They were out of shrimp when we got there, so had to wait 10 min,  but oh so worth it!   Super cheap,  too!  Only paid 6 dollars for a bunch.   Nowhere to sit in there,  really,  though...  so plan on taking your haul to one of the great little local parks to devour.
author: Sander D.

description: Delicious Dim Sum is our go to place in Chinatown for two items of dim sum.  They have great Hargow, and absolutely the best Shrimp and Cilantro dim sum.  The Shrimp and Cilantro dim sum is fantastic.  They also have very good Bao and Shumai, but not as big as you can get at Good Mung Kok up on Stockton Street.  One of the few to go dim sum places you can get some soy sauce and chili sauce here to eat your to go dim sum.  They even have Cokes and water available to drink.  Remember to go across the way after you eat for some desert in the Ross Alley - check out the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory.
author: Bill S.

description: I am. It sure why there is a huge line at the the dim sum house on Stockton as opposed to this one. This one is excellent and their dim sum portions are large. The shrimp har how is awesome but I like the stuff green veggie ones the most. Ladies were always nice to me as well
author: Gally L.

description: The lady helping me was obviously annoyed that I had to ask what each thing was, but everything was very good.  I will look to go again next time I visit.
author: Sang J.

description: Best dim sum in SF!  The rice balls and leek and shrimp dumplings are worth the trek through SF's huge Maze of a Chinatown and dealing with all the rude Chinese people.  Highly recommended!
author: Anh L.

description: Oh my goodness -- this place lives up to it's name! Walked here from our hotel through Chinatown. Tiny little place, no seating, no service. But it gets 4 stars because the food was *THAT GOOD* ! I spent most of the rest of our vacation seeing if we could scheme a way to get back here. Just watch out -- it's closed on Wednesdays.
author: Julius H.

description: BEST DIMSUM EBER!!I eat a lot of dimsum And this place is number one in my book! Their football and shumai were not only fresh but super cheap. I didn't even need soy sauce or chili paste. Texture and taste was on point.
author: Madonna J.

description:
$1.50 for 3 dumplings, can't get any cheaper than that. Other than the price, the dim sum are really good! We always get the shrimp dumplings and my favorite, shrimp and chives dumplings! 

Their pork buns are good, but i prefer the other place a couple of stores down.

Cheap and great tasting dim sum!
author: j s.

description: Ok here's the deal, maybe there is dim sum of equal goodness somewhere in San Francisco, I don't doubt that. But this place gets five stars for the excellent food but it's also nice because you don't have to go into a restaurant to get it. Bare bones place with one table. You order and pay at the counter. 10 pieces of goodness for $6 out the door. Beautiful!!
author: Jesse P.

description: First time in SF and I wanted to try a different place for dim sum.  Not a fan at all.  No prices on anything on the walls.  Ordered two things and I somehow spent $10, a rip off.
author: Nina A.

description: I've been going to this place for as long as I remembered. I started at 8am Saturdays since I was 8 going to Chinese school so I stop by here to get some breakfast. Everyone says that the shrimp dumpling is the best but I can't eat shrimp so I don't really know. My parents get it for my brother a lot so it must be good. I tend to go for the vegetable dumplings because they're really delicious, not to mention, cheap too. I love getting their rice noodles, its really good and if you want a vegetarian one, you can just ask them and they'll make it for you on the spot! I got one beef rice noodle and 3 dumplings for only $3. It's so cheap and so good.
author: Polly L.

description:
Although I live in the Richmond, a place well known for the phenomenal Asian food, I still love this dim sum joint.

The Asian ladies are grumpy as hell and often ignore me since I speak Mandarin, not Cantonese, but the shrimp dumplings are HUGE (2 shrimp min. per dumpling), the custard buns are ridiculously fluffy and the chicken feet (don't judge) are plump and saucy.

Pricing is standard for a take-out dim sum place: 3 pieces for around $1.60 and slightly more for larger items.  Basically, you can fill up for under $10 easily.  Seating is limited...I think there is only 1 table.  But, if you're in a hurry and don't want to wrestle the tourists for some pork buns, this is the place to go!
author: Sherry C.

description:
I dissent, and strongly at that. I wish I could articulate precisely why, but all I know is that a few months ago, really questing for some weekend morning dim sum in the City, I went here because I'd bookmarked the place. I vaguely remember getting a variety of dumplings: shrimp chive, siu mai, potstickers, whatever, and eating them on the way back home. Well, I think that didn't go so well, because I was bummed enough to get out my phone and save a draft review: one star with a terse "awful" below it. Then I suppressed the memory, or something.

Past me might have been overreacting a little, but past me (not unlike present me) has some familiarity with dim sum and knows what's good. For the prices, up one star. But otherwise, I'm going to trust the initial reaction. Go elsewhere.
author: Peter B.
