description:
My favorite dim sum place of all time ever since i was little!

I grew up in norcal and have had dimsum in norcal, socal, even in Arizona, but nothing can compare to the flavorful, mouthwatering, delicious dimsum that this place makes. The price is very reasonable and taste cannot match to others. Their shrimp dumplings are the best in my opinion and became my favorite of all dishes since then, its so flavorful for such a simple item. I have tried almost every dimsum dish and love all of them. 

This place isn't a restaurant but more of a dimsum-to-go place. But IF compared to all the dimsum places I've been too, this beats out the rest. I highly recommend trying this place. The name is exactly what it delivers: delicious dim sum!
author: Tiffany N.

description: Great dim sum- cheap prices and lots of variety. Small indoor seating and more a to- go place.
author: Erica R.

description: San Francisco's china town is always full of surprises. This is one of them. The place has no english signs and no one speaks english. Luckily all you need do is point at the food and eat. Pretty good food Me things. the Dim sum was fresh and tasty.
author: Tripp G.

description:
As in the name, it was DELICIOUS, cheap, & fresh!!

It's only a to-go dim sum place. There was no sitting area, but we were on the go anyway and just needed a quick bite to jump start our day. 

As stated from other yelpers, the dim sum pieces were really big. For $6 we got 4 har gow (shrimp dumplings), 4 sui mai (pork dumplings), 2 sesame balls with red bean paste filling, and 2 deep fried pork dumplings.

They didn't have a ton of variety, but they had the popular dim sum items. For 2 people, we were full from just 6 bucks! Great deal! Cash only though!

For tourists, this place was near that popular fortune cookie making place too! Definitely a good stop for tourists or people on the go!
author: Leanne D.

description: Hole in the wall shop with no seating, but the dim sum is very cheap and the ha gow and gao choi gow were very good.  I got fed good for $5.
author: Matthew P.

description: My 4 year old daughter and I came here for a late lunch. We got two heaping containers of dim sum and it was only $15! The women working were super helpful and patient while we were picking out what we wanted. I loved the shrimp dumplings. My daughter liked the potstickers and the steamed pork buns the best. We will definitely coming back here for our dim sum fix.
author: Elena H.

description: Delicious dim sum is Super delicious! I wish I could just get there earlier. I always get there right before they close due to my work schedule and try to scoop up whatever they have left. My favorite is the shrimp and cilantro dumpling! I almost don't want to say that because I don't want you all to take them all before I get there!!
author: Karah S.

description:
OVERALL:3.8   FOOD:4   SERVICE:4   AMBIANCE:2   VALUE:5
"Deliclous" is as delicious does...OK, so they missed the mark on the awning lettering, but totally make up for any typos with quality, service, taste, and mad bargain prices!  If you're squeamish about Chinatown standards (or lack thereof...?) and engrish, this is a no-brainer: display case is clean, steamy goodies are actually kept covered, and if you wait til the close of business to try snagging some har gao, sorry--they'll be sold out!--no stale leftovers here.  My personal fave is that there are no crazy old ladies with plastic sleeves and sad hair nets...nope, just a super friendly, coherent, POLITE young lady that actually answers "what's in that?" with something other than The Scowl of Death and loud Cantonese that I almost wish I couldn't understand.

My go-to for fresh take out dim sum!
author: Amy K.

description:
Cash only. I only had 7 dollars on me, but I managed to get a full meal with only 4 dollars! 

I live a ten minutes walk away so this review is for the dimsum after 10 minutes of cooling! Each order of the har gaw & siu mai comes with 3 pieces. Char siu bao you can get one bun at a time. 

Har gaw: lots of shrimp, very big but the skin was a little too chewy for me
Char siu bao: lots of the bun part but it's a pretty decent size so I wouldn't say they skimped
Siu mai: not bad but nothing amazing

Honestly, for the price and pretty good overall quality I'd say this is definitely worth it.

Side note: the menu is in Chinese but the lady speaks English fine
author: Justine K.

description: Very good. Cheap. Really like the shrimp and cabbage.  Good char siu bao. Cookies are good too.  Keep in mind that none of these Dim Sum places has any ambiance or chit chat - just get it and get out.
author: Jason B.

description: Went on a sunday for dumplings to-go. This place is counter service, not sit-down service. There's a couple table you could eat at if you want but we took our food to go and took a ten minute walk to the park at the corner of Columbus Ave and Greenwich St instead, which was a good move, I think. The dumplings were great and super cheap. We had shrimp dumplings, scallion dumplings, a pork bun, and a turnip cake. Turnip cake is not my thing (AT ALL) but the others were really good. It wasn't too hard to order, even as an English speaker. I told the staff member what I wanted and it wasn't a problem. Glad we went here.
author: Lauren J.

description: Great tasting food, but I think I showed up a bit late (close to 3pm) because it seemed like most of their steamers were pretty empty, and there were several trays that had nothing in them :( But from what was there, I sampled them  (after I paid for them), and they were super delish!
author: Bruce C.

description: Hole in the wall and it was fresh and delicious! no place for seating, so we got 2 big boxes of dimsum for like $10-$15 and ate in the car. Cash only and i don't mind at all.
author: Coss S.

description: First time in Chinatown in SF and Im a big fan of Dim Sum so i just had to find a place. Asked a local in another restaurant where the best dim sum was in town and with no hesitation told me this place. Regardless of our language barrier, the woman working the counter was able to describe what she was selling. Loved the pork dim sum, didnt prefer the prok bun but i will be back next time Im in SF
author: Ashley S.

description:
Not quite as cheap as you's and honestly not as good. The skin on various items was a bit thick and amount of filling in say the "salty dumplings" was low. 

Prefer You's or a sit-down joint.
author: Alex T.

description: A fantastic place to buy really good dim sum. I just walked in and asked them to give me 8-10 of their most popular pieces and was very happy!
author: Kushan P.

description: Prices are good, dim sums are delicious, the store is always busy. Only $1 for bubble milk tea and it tastes much better than the other milk teas in Chinatown. Recommend the shrimp dumpling, egg tarts, and beef rice rolls!
author: Diana L.

description:
The best place for har gow in chinatown! I've tried their Siu mai, baos and other dim sum and they're all good but their har gow is the best! Plus everything is super cheap! 

The people working there are always nice and friendly. Definitely one of the better places to go to.
author: Katie M.

description: Best dim sum place in Chinatown. Cheap and delicious. Note, this is not a restaurant - you order and you take out. Also note that all the Lee's Delis in the area get their dim sum from this place so if you have the time to make the trek, save yourself a few bucks and go directly to the source.
author: Eric H.

description:
I think it is one of the best Dim Sum takeout in China Town.

They have 100% on health department report!

I especially like their Har Gau (Shrimp) and Gau Choy Gwor (Shrimps and Chives) - thanks you Ken K!

I liked nice pork flavor and perfect skin of Shouron Po but they lacked juice inside.  Pork spare ribs were too fat for me...

I'll go back and try some more.
author: Chie J.

description: This place is so cheap. $5.99 for all you can eat. A dirty clean hole in the wall.  Doesnt serve every dim sum item but enough to get your fix. Just be warned that the ice coffees are watered down too much using starbucks cups. but other than that very friendly service and a yummy grease bomb if your craving dim sum and happen to be ballin on a budget.
author: E C.

description: The name said it all. I really enjoy the dim sum from this place. They are a fast no frills kind of place. Their dim sum are huge! Definitely a good bargain!
author: Helen L.

description: Great Dim Sum for a few dollars. Just hole in the wall Snack place. Veggie ones the best
author: Andreas C.

description: 24 pieces, $11, three very happy adults. I won't come to the city without visiting Delicious Dim Sum! Cash only but well worth it!
author: Boky S.

description: Amazing food. Tiny restaurant with 1 table and some chairs. Really better for takeout, but you won't get better dim sum anywhere!
author: David A.

description: This place is not a dine in restaurant, its to go and take cash only.  But they make one of the best and largest hargow's i've ever tasted.  Our friends referred us here and said it was a good place for take out where you can buy your dim sun and eat on the go or while sightseeing in the city.  They don't give soysauce or utensils unless you ask, but then its still not enough.  But the taste doesn't really need it and you can eat with hands.  Dim sum this good will have you licking your fingers for me.  The prices are super cheap, but prices are not posted.
author: Jacki C.

description: You just got to love this place! I recommend ordering one of everything and then walk out on to the sidewalk, eat it and go back in for seconds of your favorites. There is really no place to sit, but that just adds to the fun.
author: Monica S.

description: I've been going here since I was a child and I love this place. Best dim sum in the bay area and it's super cheap! I love the shrimp dumpling! go there!
author: Alexx B.

description: Amazing dim sum! The shrimp dumplings and scrambled egg & prawn chow fun are so good. Would definitely recommend to anyone!
author: Anna B.

description: I went here based on Yelp reviews and was a little bit disappointed. I ordered one of each of the dim sum. my least favorite was the beef. I didn't like it nor did my friend. My favorite was the shumai but it had a couple of gristle chunks in it. The shrimp dim sum was delicious. I think there was one table in there that had someone sitting in there and eating.
author: Wendy K.

description: Dim sum Togo. Cheap. Delicious. Very delicious. Say no more. Got to have this before you leave San Francisco.
author: Phero V.

description: This place hits the spot when I want some cilantro shrimp dumplings or har gow on the go or after the usual dim sum time ends (~2pm).  $0.60 per dumpling doesn't get any better than this.  Their quality is on par with the best sit-down dim sum spots.
author: Eva W.

description: Very happy to have found another good dim sum take out place in Chinatown. For the longest time, I've been going to Good Mong Kok where the service is rude and the lines long. Granted, the food at Delicious Dim Sum isn't quite as good as Good Mong Kok, but they have a better variety of the dim sum that I want to eat. Looking forward to coming back and trying out new items.
author: Alice W.

description:
All the Chinatown locals (including myself) know that Delicious Dim Sum is one of the better places for dim-sum-to-go. How do we base our judgment? Just look at how thin the skin on the har gow (shrimp dumplings) are! (See ghetto photo on Yelp.)

Most places will overcompensate by making huge, thick-skinned suckers... good for keeping you full but not for making a good impression.  The goods at this joint are perfect: they've got a good variety and they make it well.

One of the other things they make well here are the zhong (some people call them Chinese tamales). The meat is flavorful, which is key, and just one of those sticky-rice-filled monsters will make a great meal (all for less than $2, mind you).
author: Andrey C.

description:
Good takeout dim sum, though we actually sat down at the lone table to eat. Nothing was written in English, so they lifted the steamers to show us the dim sum and fortunately I knew what I was looking for. Everything was tasty, though not as warm as I would like and the place was on the dingy side (not really meant to be a sit down place). 

We were eating, all of the workers in back took their lunch break and sat in chairs against the wall & table we were at (I think we took the table they usually eat at). Very cheap and yummy.
author: Lisa T.

description: Best bang for your buck if you like dim sum. Line of locals proves it's authenticity. Shrimp dumplings, shrimp + chive, potstickers, shu mai, rice noodle things cut up with sauce, all good. Been several times with work buddies, took my little brother and he'd now convert to Chinese if it was a religion.
author: Andrew S.

description: I came here because "Good Mong Kok Bakery" was out of everything! Delicious Dim Sum was fully stocked and I pretty much ordered one of everything. It is a to-go place with only one table in the back. We decided to eat in the back. Chinese ladies were as usual, strictly business and not too friendly. We sat in the back and enjoyed our meal. Dim Sum was perfect temperature and soft.. Shrimp dumpling was not skimpy as most places. Prices are very decent, if not cheap. As we were done with our meal, one of the ladies pretty much slammed a whole rack of frozen dim sum onto our table and began using it as her own table. What the... Maybe she knew we were done eating because we had put all the trash together to throw away..? Whatever, dim sum was good and I expected her to be rude anyways. Haha. She shouted "thank you!" as we left.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Visiting the SF area and looking for a quick dim sum in the Chinatown? This is the place. I tried one of everything and was not disappointed. $3 bucks filled me up.
author: A V.

description:
Three words to sum it up:

BIG

JUICY 

HARGAWS.

Need I say more? 

Ok fine I will... it's also really cheap and their other steamed dumplings are DELICIOUS as well. Yeah the place is kind of dirty but hey, it's Chinatown. I usually just turn the other way until they pack up my dim sum. 

You can't lose when you go here. Just try to go in the morning & lunch times because that's when everything is the freshest.
author: Lynn C.

description:
At 5pm on a Saturday, Good Mong Kok Bakery had a line out the door, yet Delicious Dim Sum was just about empty.  The prices at both places were the same - $1.80 for an order of dim sum.  The natural conclusion would be that Delicious Dim Sum isn't as good.

Therefore, I was surprised to find that both orders I got here (shrimp dumplings, pork shu mai) were very tasty and flavorful, far better than the two orders I had gotten that morning from Good Mong Kok Bakery (though that place provided larger servings, as in larger dumplings).  I'm giving this place five stars for the combination of value and taste.
author: K L.

description:
what's with SF chinatown? we've been to SF chinatown since moving to california about a dozen times now and everytime we always try to find new place. whether it be dim sum, congee, hong kong style egg noodle soups or siu mei type places, to canton and we have yet to find that go to place. we did find one years back and we've been to it a few times but its not a OMG type place. i always forget the name i just know its in a east west type street and it is a siu mei restuarant that will only serve congee until a certain hour. 

we went to DDS because the original place i wanted to go to was closed so DDS was a back up. we also went because we were heading for john muir woods and knew lunch could be a long wait. we ordered the shu mai, cha siu bao, shrimp noodle and veggie dumpling. the shu mai was a little dry and lacking some flavor that even soy sauce couldn't help. the veggie dumplings was so-so, the wrapper was tough and thick. if the veggie wrappers was thick the rice noodle was thicker and rubbery. trying to take it apart needed a knife cause seperating our chopsticks and turning one of them into a knife didn't work to cut them into bite size pieces. rice noodle should be silky and soft not dense and rubbery. i think it might have to do with them keeping it at room temp covered in plastic wrap but even if they kept it steaming that rice noodle was way too thick to soften up. the char siu bao was good but wasn't the brown ones i was looking for that the other place had. it was light, steaming to the touch but the fillings could've been better tasting. 

here's the thing, we weren't expecting it to taste amazing but we've had dim sum at these type of places before and we've come away thinking "that wasn't bad for what it was". it has to be relative to what your getting and where your getting it, its defintely not restaurant quality sunday dim sum but that's not a guarantee either there's some bad restaurant dim sum out there.
author: NYSD G.

description: Their har gow are the best I've had in SF (and this is taking sit-downs like Yank Sing and Hong Kong Lounge into account). The wrappers are incredibly thin and delicious making them the perfect vessel for the fresh shrimp filling. I tried some pork dumplings and shrimp and chive dumplings as well - their rice wrapped items are where they truly excel.
author: Krystle S.

description:
5 stars for value.

No ambience, but dim sum ain't about ambience.  Their hao gao and cilantro and shrimp are excellent, and better than many sit down dim sum restaurants, most of the stuff sitting in the front window is average. Siu mai and bao are solid, but a bit better (imo) at good mong kok bakery.  All in all a great place to get some not only extremely cheap but tasty food to eat in a nearby park (or back at work/home).
author: ErUta N.

description: Another dim sum place I yelped. Tried their shu mai and some type of dumpling that's supposed to have some broth in it, but the ones we got were too dry. It would have been good if there was broth in the dumpling. The place is just okay.
author: Sandy H.

description:
BEST DIM SUM EVER! 
the menu is in Chinese only. 

So we just pointed to what looked good and asked a few questions. Not a hard place to find, all you do is follow Chinatown to Jackson st and turn left. 

THANK  YOU YELP. FOUND this place by browsing place to eat in Chinatown.

 We will definitely stop by here again when visiting SF.
author: Jaselle G.

description:
They have delicious written in their name...and DELICIOUS it is.  Oh how you have brought me back to the days when I was a patron on your nearby competitor, the House of Dim Sum.

Thank you, for letting me know how dim sum should be served.  The only downside...this is strictly to-go only.  How am I supposed to enjoy these tiny little tresures without proper seating?   At least in House of Dim Sum, they had some seating in the front, and more upstairs.  It was tempting to take dumplings from your place, and eating them over there.  But that would be just too rude.

Honestly, you deserve all 5 stars, but lack in seating arrangements.  This is San Francisco Chinatown.  I must not be the only tourist out there.  Delicious Dim Sum, please, accomodate us please.  And soon, I, and others alike, will patronize you.
author: Renee V.

description: If I could come here every day and eat dim sum, I would. This was my first dim sum to go experience in SF when I moved out here, and I've been a fan ever since. I always get the shrimp dumpling, shrimp and chives and shrimp and cilantro (yes I like my shrimp). the shrimp and cilantro dumpling is my absolute favorite, chock full of fillings. Yes, the dumpling wrappers can be a little hit and miss sometimes, but the filling is always delicious. The price is very, very reasonable, I don't think I've ever spent more than 10 bucks here and I always get enough for 2 meals. Yum yum yum. Oh, and don't forget to ask for soy sauce and chilli paste! :) And if you're gonna ask for chicken feet, and you don't like classically chinese, you will get a "are you sure?" look from the ladies behind the counter.
author: Farah F.

description:
At the time of my visit, the sign said "Deliclous Dim Sum" .. but I don't care.  Misspell it all you want, cause the food is great. The service is also very good and did I mention it is extremely affordable. 

Though it helps, you don't necessarily need to speak Chinese. Just point if you don't get someone helping you that speaks, all good. Also we managed to sit down at the only table in the place. If you can swing it, good times.
author: A C.

description: This place is amazing. Spent under $20 for lunch and dinner. They barely speak English but are very sweet and now what they're doing. It's very flavorful and great easy lunch.
author: Kelly P.

description:
TO GO ONLY.

We stopped by here before looking for a sit down dim sum restaurant. To fuel up, we ordered 1 shrimp dumpling and 1 pork dumpling each. Each piece was 50 cents so we each paid $1 for 2 pieces. We wanted some soy sauce and it was kind of awkward trying to eat these while standing, but we had no choice. The one lonely table in the back was being used by one of the employees so we stood outside.

The dumplings were good though so I'll give them that.
author: Justine O.

description: I would eat here everyday if I lived in San Francisco.  OK, maybe not every day, but you get what I mean.  Hot, tasty and cheap food, YES PLEASE.  Shrimp and vegetable and BBQ pork were the favorites.  Point and choose, get everything you see and ask them for their favorites also, box of 12 cost us $7.50.  We ate at 2 Dim Sum spots, couldn't eat it all and was the cheapest meal of the trip.
author: Steven H.

description: This place was OK. The hargow and shumai were good sized and flavorful.  The chive dumplings that everyone said were amazing were only OK to me.  They weren't that crispy and I kept biting into things that tasted like the stronger white part of an onion bulb instead of just the green parts, and the green parts that were in there were kind of tough and stringy.  The Shanghai dumplings had a very thick, chewy dim sum skin and almost no broth, so they were disappointing.  The tapioca steamed item with red bean inside, however, was good. I  was expecting a line but there was almost no wait and the women behind the counter were slightly nicer than the normal dim sum counter ladies I've experienced.  Plus, I spent less than $6 for 9 pieces of dim sum, so I'd probably go back if I were in the area, though I might check out some other places first.  Note, they are very bare bones...  they didn't offer any fork, napkin, chopsticks, soy sauce, etc.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
I am not a fan. Delicious Dim Sum does not live up to its name.  Now I am not a Dim Sum connoisseur nor am I an expert on chinese food, but this was pretty eh. 

The dumplings were pretty good but the rice patty piece was not. The food in general was pretty cold, and not gratifying. Anytime you have tor remove food from your mouth is a bad sign. I've been to some delicious dim sum places but this was definitely not it.
author: Dmitry K.

description: SO happy finding this dim sum during traveling, get enough of sandwiches and burgers, love the food here so much!
author: Qi L.

description:
If you need cheap & great dim sum, this is it.

They don't have nice place or tablewares (my har gow was served in paper dish:). But I don't care. It's totally worth the price. For what they charge, the dim sum is LARGE. And it's delicious too. My brother and I spent less than 7 dollars there eating enough dim sum to fulfill the next 6 hours.
author: Sue R.

description:
This dim sum place was really delicious. We walked around and tried different places and this by far was the best.

The food was really inexpensive like 50 cents each. The shrimp dumplings are really yummy.

I also liked that it seemed really authentic because of the crowd that was their ordering and eating.
author: Kristyn W.

description: Fantastic, authentic China Town dim sum. Cheap and delicious. If there is a better hang over cure, I have not yet found it.
author: Sean C.

description: Okay dim sum, but bad to mediocre service. :(
author: Jessica L.

description: By far the est har gow (shrimp dumplings) that I've had in SF. Had some chive dumplings and turnip cake too, also delicious. As others have mentioned, the lady behind the counter does speak english really well, so don't feel bashful if you're not Cantonese. Cheap and cheerful.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
Was really looking forward to this place due to all of the mostly positive reviews.

Their dim sum is on the larger side as far as portion sizes go.

The Har Gow, Shui My, and Char Sui Bao were on the better side.

The chicken feet, sticky rice in lotus leaf, potstickers, and shrimp and chive dumplings were on the bad to less than average.

The main drawback was that all of the food was cold, some to the point where they were downright frozen.  An Eskimo would have been very happy living inside of the potsticker given is frozen temperature, thick skin and large size.  Probably better than most igloos out there, LOL.
author: Veronica P.

description:
I was shocked and delighted to find that the steamed dumplings at this hole-in-the-wall are as good as any I've ever eaten, and I've had hundreds of dim sum meals in my life (albeit mostly restricted to NYC and LA).

It is a gem.
author: B C.

description:
First place on our food crawl, or maybe second. Hole in the wall is probably THE best way to describe this place. If you don't speak Chinese, you're out of luck...or maybe not. I picked random items and gambled my 3-4 bucks away with unknown foods. The outcome? winner winner chicken dinner! 
For this price, I didn't know what to expect. The flavors burst from each savory dim sum piece we tried. Fresh and tasty, a quick cheap bite if you're in the area. Go ahead, try the unknown!
author: Loic B.

description: A tiny, little shop with hard working Chinese ladies. The dim sum was fresh and tasty. We had the xiu mai, shrimp, and shrimp and cilantro dumplings. There weren't as many options as a restaurant would have. We tried the pork bun too and it was just okay. The price is cheap and there is only one table that you have to share with about 3 other Chinese people or you can stand and eat at the counter. Not sure how hot the take out dim sum lasts so best to eat it there.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Good dim sum at a great price.  This place has a large variety, is not too greasy, and the food is tasty.  The ladies are very friendly and their English is pretty good.  I pointed at some things and the lady that helped told me what it was called and even described it.  Great customer service overall and delicious dim sum.
author: Shannon L.

description: Besides the two dumplings (shrimp and cilantro shrimp), we have since tried and added one more to our must have from here:  the dried shrimp cilantro rice crepe - $1/roll, very good.
author: Gloria H.

description: Great find for take-out only dim sum. Quite authentic, quality ingredients and priced right. I'll be back.
author: Eugene L.

description: Fast food dim sum! Wishing there was tables to eat my dim sum but I had to walk and eat. Wasn't bad , wasn't great either.
author: C W.

description:
So I have been here many times now and this place is in need of a review. 

I was always weary of eating dim sum again because I had a bad experience as a child and told myself that I would never eat it again. Then one day my friends told me that this place was good so I decided to give it a try again. When we got here I realized that this place is mainly to go and that we were pretty much going to eat and walk around Chinatown. When we got there I had my friend do all the ordering for me. We order shrimp dim sum, shrimp and chive, fried chicken ball and some other things that I can't remember. When we started to walk around I took the plunge and started with the fried chicken ball. When I bit into it, the taste of chicken and spices was absolutely amazing that I almost fell in love all over again. The shrimp and the shrimp and chive ones were amazing too.

I have plans to go again in the next few weeks and I am so excited...
author: Lisa W.

description: I love this place, cheap and fast! Only bad thing is that they're closed on Wednesdays. What's up with that?
author: Dan K.

description:
This place has some of the best dim sum in the city. Definitely one of the best, if not better, in China Town.  They make the best har gow; the best. It's very thin skinned wrapped large shrimp, and steamed just right. Everything is so...well, delicious! Would have been five stars but their pot stickers are terrible. The dough is so thick and heavy! I'm glad I only got one instead of the typical 3 per order.

It's a tiny little place and, like most places in China Town, it's cleanliness leaves something to be desired. But at least it isn't filthy. It's reasonably clean by CT's standards. But if you get it to go, instead of trying to eat a one of the tiny tables in the back, you're be okay.
author: Sheba B.

description:
Cheap... Ya get what u pay for!  Bad meat quality, ok veggie and shrimp items, a bit greasy overall. 

I don't eat meat, but my BF does and the steamed pork buns (cha siu bao) and pork dumplings (sui mai) were gristley (sp?) and upset his stomach for over 24 hrs!  I had the har gow and shrimp and cilantro dumplings. It was just ok.
author: Susan Y.

description: We loved the shrimp dumplings and the large vegetarian dumplings. The pork dumpling was also great. We wondered what was in the leaves but thought we might have trouble understanding the answer.
author: Jessica E.

description: This place gives the term "a hole in the wall" a new meaning. This is basically an Asian family that has one steamer keeping the dim sum "warm" from who knows when. My wife is Chinese and she wouldn't even finish the food and I had to throw away four of them. Also it was very very doughy. I'll stick to the frozen 99 ranch dumplings my wife makes me
author: Bill S.

description: The best dim sum I have had in at least 5 years. What an awesome experience eating that aptly named dim sum in Chinatown. Definitely stop in if you see it!
author: Jacob Z.

description: So this was the last place I hit up in Chinatown and soon ad I walk in I wonder where is all the food?!?! I mean there's literally nothing on display just empty trays. then I discover they are hiding all the yummys in big metal things (I suppose to keep them warm). I just order a steamed BBQ pork bun since I've pretty much eaten my way through CHinatown by now but oooooh man it was *SO* delic!! I hope to go back with a less full tummy to be able to enjoy more food.
author: Quisha H.

description: Only bought a steamed BBQ pork bun, because a new dim sum bakery opened up a few doors down. Service was abrupt and not too friendly. I don't think she was happy that I only wanted 1 bun. The bun was good though - fluffy, sweet, soft. The bun itself had an unexpected floral taste to it. The filling was really good - sweet, not too gummy, and it had big chunks of lean BBQ pork (not many chunks of fat like I've found in other buns). $.80 a bun which isn't bad. They also have vegetable pork buns and other dim sum options like har gow and xiu mai. Would go back for the buns.
author: Catherine N.

description:
i never ordered any food here but i felt it important that i let fellow yelpers know that is yet another place where there is no place to sit down and eat.  this is important to know.

and yes, i understand there are numerous dim sum places in SF that are not eat in.  however, i think it is important to note that.
author: mei s.

description:
Huge har gow and xiu mai.. both cost me $3. There are 3 per order at $1.50 per.. very cheap and big on flavor!! 

Big flaw- cash only 

Big +- huge and tasty for what you pay for. I really like the har gow.
author: Tram N.

description:
A small hole in a wall....but for an authentic experience of Dim Sum in Chinatown.....this is worth the price of admission.... 

Don't expect anything fancy about this place.....heck we were about to dismiss it just because the entire menu was in Chinese.....but I'm glad we decided to stay and try the awesome food... 

You pick and choose what you want.....and you can either take it to go or there's a table for you to take your goodies and try em out... 

Mind you there's only one table.....so just keep that in mind hah.... 

The prices were affordable....and all the ingredients were fresh....give this place a go.....thanks Yelp for the recommendation!
author: Jay A.

description:
After collecting everyone's feedback on foods to try here, we decided to go for it. 

A group of 4 of us came on a Saturday around 1PM - the line was long but luckily we got the table in the back to eat! I dont know how we could have ate all the food we ordered while walking/standing around chinatown!! 

We ordered $26 worth of dim sum! Call us crazy, I think the ladies at the counter thought we were buying out the entire store! We practically did. The dim sum is SOOO cheap here, we were surprised.

What we didnt like: (maybe it was because we came so late in the day and all the foods left werent too fresh?)

-pork buns (Char Sui Bao)- eh! not even that spectacular!
-huge sesame balls - not too fancy :/
-har gao - it wasnt that great! The skin was way too thick
-chueng fun (shrimp rice noodle roll) - yuck! 

What we enjoyed:
-shrimp & cilantro dumplings -  a bit on the greasy side though!
-pork shu mai 
-potstickers

When we said that we were eating it there and the lady serving us had already started putting our food in the pink to-go box, she was actually not annoyed like we had assumed she'd be. We were pretty complicated - not gonna lie. I bet she hated us secretly :) 

Overall, you get what you pay for! It's CHEAP! One thing to note is the lack of cleanliness. I was a bit disgusted sitting down at the table in te back and the walls, floor and table were gross and sticky. Oh yeah and CASH only and its best if you know how to say the things in cantonese!! We just let her look at the fellow yelpers reviews and read it aloud to her, it was probably best to let her read it instead of us butchering it. haha
author: Jeena L.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum is the perfect example of why I love San Francisco. Manuvering through Chinatown while dodging the obnoxious dudes trying to shove flyers in my face, mega drained my politness reserves, and left me starving. Luckily, I found this place after asking a sweet lil chinese woman which restaurant she recommended. Judging by her roundness, I took her word as golden, and headed inside. 
            
          Heads up, unless youre fluent in Chinese, there will be a language barrier! The only thing you'll understand on the menus are the prices, everything else is a "excuse me can you repeat that" or a ini-mini-minie-mo game. You can choose between shrimp or pork dim sum, fried shrimp and cilantro, tripe, and shrimp potstickers. Other menu items include 100 year old egg pastries(you heard me, 100!) sweet rice in banana plant leaves, and a tofu shaped dim sum with mystery contents. Oh and for about .25 to .60 per dim sum, you can load up on  a few of each for well under $5.00. Yeah son!
    
          Another disclosure, seating here is limited, and I mean limited to the one table inside the place with only 4 chairs, or to the table at your place. Back to the food...AMAZING!! The pork dim sum was complimented perfectly with green onions and peanuts, the shrimp was simple yet still flavorful, and all the ingredients were fresh.

        After a long day of bumping my way through Chi town, Delicious Dim Sum was the perfect way to end my day.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
Good: Har gow (shrimp dumplings), sui mai (pork/shrimp dumpling thing), cha sui bao (bbq pork buns), Chive and shrimp dumplings.

mediocre: chueng fun (shrimp rice noodle roll) is a okay. not hella good, uses regular soy sauce.

bad: turnip cake - it's really cakey, and heavy. it'll fall apart and just not fried enough on the outside.  ugh.
author: Zu W.

description:
Waking up with a hangover, the best cure besides Gatorade and the bathroom floor is dim sum!  My friend and I stumbled upon this on yelp and decided to walk our disoriented bodies up the hill to the little shop that could.  There is a counter you stand and order from, one table in the place, and nothing in English.  But you just need to know the basic words and point.  It's really that simple!  

I really wanted to do 5 but I had to drop it down 1 star because she didn't give me soy sauce nor chili after I asked politely a few times.  I'm just a sickler for details.  I have to say, this is by far the cheapest and one of the yummiest places for dim sum.  Variety is not as great as a big sit-in with the ladies rolling the carts but still delicious and the right amount of grease.  The two of us ate for $8.00 cash (with leftovers) and I even had a Diet Coke as a poor alternative for my Gatorade craving.  

Definitely try the chives shrimp dumpling and the basics - pork and shrimp dumpling.  Order extras!
author: Deborah V.

description:
Out of all the take out dim sum places in Chinatown, I find that this place has the most tasty items. I usually try to buy a huge box of food so I can eat dim sum for breakfast the entire week. Usually this comes out to around $10.00 for the whole week! I would suggest the chive dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and daikon cakes.

Some downsides are that parking is absolutely horrible around here (like every other place in SF), they only take the cash money, and if you don't speak Cantonese, the lady behind the counter will probably grumpily serve you. It does look a little dirty/sketchy, but I can assure you this little hidden gem is delicious!
author: Angela L.

description: This place was INCREDIBLE. I went and asked for a little of everything for my boyfriend and I. We were given two each of five different kinds for SIX BUCKS. They were all amazing and handmade, and the staff was friendly and helpful. It's a hole in the wall but definitely worth the yelp hype!
author: Kristina J.

description:
This place is TO GO only. There is a small table in the back you can sit. Good cheap dimsum

Cash only and chinese speakers only
author: Julie N.

description: Amazing. A hole in the wall with one table, but the dim sum is mouth watering.
author: Michel U.

description:
I came here last week very excited to try this place b/c of all the review on yelp. When I got there around 4pm on a friday there was barely anything left!!!

I was kinda sad but I tried the har gow, shumai and turnip cake it tasted like shit. I know I came really late b/c dim sum is made in the mornings, but damn everything was straight up cold. The shrimp in the har gow tasted old and left a after taste in my mouth the shumai was chewy and the turnip tasted like it came from ranch 99 market . Everything was really cheap though 50 cent per piece.

Lets talk about the service it blows they lady who helped me looked like she woke up on the wrong side of the bed this morning. She didn't seem to appreciate our company very much and when I asked her for chili paste she pointed at the table in the back that had not thing on it. After blowing me off a few times she realized she placed the chili paste in the fridge thats why I didn't see it. I don't even think this place is worth of my $3 I spent I rather eat packaged ramen noodles with egg and green onion sprinkled on top =).
author: Linh T.

description:
I go to this place every single time I'm in San Francisco.  In my opinion it's the best place for har gao.  The chives and shrimp is also good but not as shrimp-y tasting obviously.  The reason this place is so good is because of the soft tapioca wrapping.  It's very soft and oily, not hard or thick like some other places.  For me that is what sets it apart from the others.  Also, the filling inside is very delicious, just like their name implies.  

As for knowing how to order, you can ask them what's underneath the top baskets.  They are nice and understand enough English to lift it up and show you what's there.  

This place is cash only.  Very cheap and very good.  Another thing is that they keep for a while.  I went this morning, brought some home and they are still good...I even just ate one.  I cannot eat enough of these!  I wish I had bought more =(    I have a plan for next time though... I'm going to freeze some and then steam them when I want to eat.  I hope they still come out soft.  It'd be wonderful to have these ALL the time and not just when I go to Chinatown.
author: Cole T.

description:
They have the best dim sum.

Decent prices and friendly service.

Closed on Wednesday?
author: Keit K.

description: Pretty good dim sum, and inexpensive, too.  When in Chinatown, drop in and indulge!
author: John B.

description:
I remember the days when I would drop off my sister at Chinese school and then double park to get two orders of dim sum at Delicious Dim Sum for breakfast. I just love, love, love their shrimp and chive dumplings! The wrapper is pretty translucent and thin and the filling is ultra tasty. I can't get enough of them! Their shrimp dumplings are just as good too!

This is a take-out joint, so don't expect to have a nice place to sit and eat.
author: Diana C.

description:
So we drove into the city and parked by The House Of Prime Rib. We were in town to end our week long 19th year of marriage celebration. Took a cab into China town, walked around, shopped a bit and decided to get some food, i Yelped Dim Sum and mapped the location, we were just four store fronts away. I ordered for myself, my wife and our two aunts. 2 orders of pork, 2 of shrimp and 1 order of potstickers.

Pork - tasty and they give you lots of it per dumpling

Shrimp - also very tasty and plenty

Pot Stickers -  now these were my favorites, right amount of pork and the cabbage was perfectly cooked, soft with just the right snap when you bite into them... My mouth is watering as i write this.

All this plus 2 drinks for under 11 bucks. Worth every penny!

So why did i not give it 5 stars, cause the ladies in there gave us one napkin each, and a thin one at that, when I asked for more we got 1 each again, so i gave the lady 2 bucks for some more. Finger foods require plenty of napkins. Oh well, good food, good experiance, off to walk this off then the House of Prime Rib.
author: Ruben M.

description:
Went from a loyal "House of Dim Sum" fan to Deliclous Dim Sum.  No misspellings there, that is what their banner says.  

No microwave, just plain, old steam.

Five stars all the way.
author: R J.

description: Small place. Mainly take out. Only one table. Great dim sum. Tried shumai, pork buns, shrimp dumplings & pot stickers. Short wait (if any). Cheap. Got 7 pieces & bottled water for $5. Was able to get a number at Great Eastern, walk to here, order and eat, and make it back to Great Eastern well before they called our number
author: Mark T.

description: Great authentic tiny shop.  It's cheap fast and good.  There is some seating upstairs and helpful staff. Lots of interesting things and unlisted items if you know what to ask. Cash only but it's so cheap you should be fine. English speakers and Cantonese on staff. The did not speak mandarin at all like most in sf. This is a good choice if you like more traditional Asian style stuff. Tourists may prefer something like yank sing or other more western options.
author: Doug W.

description: The name says it all! The food was awesome. Tried some on a walk through Chinatown, had to come back for more the same day!
author: Sae M.

description: The dimsum here are still good like usual..the price are still cheap, but I just have to lower their ratings cause the service here is just getting worse and worse each time I come back. I've been coming here for years now and I am pretty sure they recognize me, so I think I deserve a little respect from them. Every time my family come here, we would order at least $70-100 worth of their dimsum and bring it back home to send it over to Seatlle for my cousins. When we get alot..we would usually get it frozen and it would taste just like new when we steamed it back up. But seriously, the past 4-5x I've been back..the people helping you here seemed so "witchy". Especially the older lady..it's like she doesn't even wanna help me or something. I just love the shrimp dumplings and the veggies dumplings here so much though... But I don't know if it's enough for me to come back to a place that doesn't appreciate my business. I guess I'll come back until I find a better place...
author: Ngoc L.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum is a fitting name for this hole in the wall in Chinatown. Jessica S. and I were in the mood for some fresh dim sum and decided on this one thanks to Yelp! There was a line out the door when we arrived and some dumb lady tried to cut us but got called out...good job putting her in her place Jessica! 

The line moved quickly so I just ordered whatever items I saw out in the open that looked appetizing. Knowing how to speak Chinese is definitely a plus without all of the hand gestures and pointing. We ended up with...

3 shrimp dumplings 
3 pieces of turnip cake 
3 chive dumplings 
2 potstickers 

ALL for less than $6! There weren't any signs or labels in English though so you would have to ask about prices for each item. The shrimp dumplings were delicious with a more chewy wrapper so that its juicy contents didn't fall out so easily. Turnip cake is one of my favorite dishes so I had to try some...they were a little too thick and didn't have that brown, crunchy outer coating that I like. Not bad though. The chive dumplings were awesome...kinda greasy but so mouth watering! Lastly, the potstickers were ginormous! I thought the wrapper was a little on the thick side but I guess it makes sense in order to hold all the pork meat in the middle.

Very tasty and CHEAP meal from Chinatown once again...I love it!
author: Karen Y.

description:
delicious dim sum has been here for decades and it shows. a true hole in the wall.

sampling:
-har gow(3/1.40?)+pork bun(.50?)= 1.90
-har gow: tasty pieces of shrimp
-pork bun: small bun with a  small bit of bbq pork paste in a small bun.
-no chicken bun here.

leftovers
-no menu nor prices posted in english or chinese
-dim sum isn't totally visible just some baked or fried items.
-take out only, few seats to eat in sitdown.
-they probably speak only cantonese here, don't know, didn't try english on them. servers are mid age chinese ladies.
-cash only?
author: Victor G.

description: We wanted Dim Sum on a recent vacation to San Fran.  We stopped here.  It was a bit of a let down.  It is cheap, they do serve Dim Sum items.  Overall I would say this place is good for a snack...Dim Sum in my mind is where you sit down, drink tea and the servers push the carts around with different items on each cart.  It was cheap, and quality of food was good for the price.  Great Eastern is more like my idea of Dim Sum.
author: J S.

description: I do NOT understand why people rank it so high. Food is very average and staff is really cold, plus no where to sit.
author: Wakaba S.

description:
Having an unhealthy obsession with dim sum uniquely qualifies me to say (with conviction) that the shrimp dumplings here are AMAZING.

There's only one table with 4 seats and I don't think their dine-in trays have been washed in 30 years. But since there are several very good dim sum places within a 1 block radius of Delicious Dim Sum, I'd recommend coming here first, having a few (or many) shrimp dumplings . . . then hopping over to one of the other places with more seating to get the rest of your dim sum fill. :)

(Oh, and for TWO people, the total came out to slightly over $5. What. up.)
author: Cynthia T.

description: Super cheap for great tasting food.  Except what we ordered wasn't very warm.. it was actually more on the cold side if anything.  Maybe it's because we showed up around 2pm... either way, the food still tasted great!
author: Stephanie L.

description: 3.5 stars. The dim sum here was tasty, but the workers were much too rude.
author: A L.

description:
Amazing dim sum at incredible prices. Just watch out - they barely speak English and there're no physical menus.

I literally ordered everything... not going to bother with listing.

3 for $1.5 - they've won my heart.
author: Jack W.

description: No place to sit. Looks like a health code violation. But, they put the S in savory!  Good prices too. I'll be back.
author: D W.

description: We ordered potstickers and shrimp cilantro dumplings. They were cheap and good. How're there was an eyelash steamed into the dumpling.
author: Dory W.

description: Total english spoken was: pork, shrimp, vegetables and $4.50.  The $4.50 was for 8 pieces and two spring rolls.  That was lunch for 2 for $4.50.  Good dim sum for the price.  Not an eat-in place, we ate ours in our room at the HIlton.
author: OandG O.

description:
Shrimp dumpling (Har Gao) is the best! Fresh meat, a little crispy and sweet, the transparent skin made just right. I should have bought more. I also like the (Gao Choi) I think it's called chives in English. That's nice too!

The menu is written in Chinese. They have shrimp cheongfun, steamed lotus bun, sponge cake (ma lai go), turnip cake and other things. 

It's a take out type of place, cash only. Ask them what the menu on the wall says.  The dim sums are in the big bamboo basket.  So, it's quite hard to tell what they have.

My ratings 5/5 for the Har Gau and Gao Choi. The rest of the items 3/5.  Staff are friendly. If you can speak Cantonese, it would be better.
author: Amary N.

description: Gf and I stopped by here for a quick snack early in the afternoon.  Overall, the food was pretty solid, though cold.  I'm sure that if we came earlier in the day, it would have been significantly better.  Overall, it was cheap and still tasted good despite being cold.
author: Jeff N.

description: Ordered 3 Custard Bun (Nai Wong Bao) and a BBQ pork bun. The Custard bun had too much dough relative to the filling. Paid $1.80 for the 4 buns. Nothing I would recommend to a friend.
author: Kathy W.

description: Point to order dim sum freshly cooked and/or straight out of the steamers. There are a couple of cozy tables between the counter and the beverage refrigerators. Eat in or take out. Good flavors, great 'snap' to the shrimp in the har gow, very reasonably priced. I'll be back. Only problem was that there was no mustard available for my take out order. .
author: K K.

description: Experience was not 5stars today. The younger woman is not as nice as the elder. I took a date for dinner here and even though i told him how to order he was confused and couldn't which caused the younger lady who has absolutly NO patience to get really upset at us. If you are taking a date, order for them unless they're already acquainted with places like this.
author: Brittainie B.

description: Another great Yelp recommendation! We were a little intimidated by the lack of English, but the people behind the counter were very nice and helped us figure out what was what. We tried the pork bun and the shrimp dumpling, both of which were delicious (lived up to the store's name!). The shrimp dumpling really stood out. And the prices were great, I thought I'd misheard when the total was only $4 for 5 items! Perhaps what tasted the best was not waiting in line for ages to get our food, although I'm surprised because this place really was good. FYI - take out only.
author: Allison K.

description: It was okay, but seemed more pricer than the other dim sum places that surround it.  I chose it because of YELP reviews, but I honestly tasted much better in Chinatown.  Don't go out of your way to this place like I did.
author: Daphnie A.

description: Dirt cheap and delicious.  This is a prime spot for take-out dim sum.  Language and waits not a problem at all.  Astounding amount of tasty stuff for a few bucks.  Bring cash--the credit card machine is still out of service.
author: Phil L.

description:
Maybe we came too late, but the selection was a bit sparse. I was hoping for shrimp dumplings. Less than $5 for a sampling of items was a pretty good deal. I'm sure the two of us could have filled up for about $15.

The bbq pork steamed buns were quite tasty, but I would have liked more filling and less bun. The bun itself was perfectly steamed with a nice fluffy texture.

The shrimp in rice noodle was fine. The shrimp part was tasty but the rice noodle could have been thinner and less heavy. It was hard to grab a piece without getting only shrimp or only rice noodle. 

The potstickers were fat and full of meat and tasty seasonings. The skins were hearty and just thick enough not to get hard after being cooked.  

The shrimp and chive dumplings (i think) were filled more with chive and spinach, or some other green, and maybe one shrimp. The proportions were off by a long shot, but it tasted fine.

This is mostly a takeout place but there is a small table in the back where you can take a tray. The lady behind the counter was very nice despite our obvious lack of chineses and was fine with our order via pointing and blunt request for "pork bun". 

in hindsight, I wish we had loaded up on the pork bun and potstickers before heading to another dim sum place....
author: Bye Y.

description:
this place has been around for almost 2 decades I think.  I have been coming here ever since I was little.  1 order used to be $1, and then it was $1.2, $1.3, ... now $1.7, but I think it's still very reasonably priced.  I'm finally writing the review that they've deserved for so long.  Hopefully they keep up the good work.  

Everything is good here, and most of the dumplings taste A++.  The buns tend to be a little bit doughy, but under $2 for 3 pieces...you really can't beat that.  Some users complained about the small filling in the bbq pork bun, but they need to realize they only paid $1.7 for 3 of them!  Oh, please remember 1 order is 3 pieces, the ladies don't really speak english here, and if you want your order quick and smooth please don't ask to substitute for other things.
author: Adele W.

description:
When you eat dim sum, it was meant to be eaten in small portions,  a variety of them, and it was meant to be inexpensive. Some how or another, that last fact has been lost when dim sum leaves the boundaries of China Towns around this lovely nation of ours.

One thing you notice getting here, there realy is no parking and you can miss it like that. A hole in the wall place this is and that's the way it was meant to be. True food finds are typically a hole in the wall and are always busy with a steady stream of loyal customers. 

I am a fan of this place now after reading about it on Yelp. The ladies who work here know how to make good sausage buns with great dough, juicy siu mai, and my new favorite cilantro dim sum. The irony is that i hate cilantro, I mean I can hated Vietnamese and Mexican food for the longest time because of it, but the cilantro dim sum is just on the right side of amazingly good cheap eats. 

So for two boxes of orders we paid just about $1.20 per order...this still beats most dim sum places I've been to. I want some now, after writing this review. I want some Delicious Dim Sum!
author: robert b.

description: Best dim sum in Chinatown! Everything was super fresh and decent prices.
author: Jamie F.

description: A bit of a hole in the wall place...but genius!  Never been to a dim sum takeout place before!  Apparently, they're popular in Chinatown.  3 pieces/$1.60...can't beat that!  Got there around 4pm so some items were sold out.  Got some Sui Mai, Har Gow, chive dumplings, & pork buns...all were sooo good! :) Tasted better than many dim sum restaurants I've been to!  Wish I had Delicious Dimsum @ home.
author: Vicki P.

description: Love the green onion dumpling. You can have a whole meal for $4 bucks. Score!
author: Roger H.

description: Disappointed.  This used to be one of my go to spots for dim sum. On a recent visit I got a dozen sui mai. They must have changed meat vendors because at least 4 of the pieces had bones or hard fat.  The pan fried chive dumplings and pot stickers were bland.
author: David L.

description:
Thanks to Yelp reviewers, my guy and I decided to try this place -- and loved it.  

We especially loved the shrimp/cilantro dumpling -- this is the must-try item -- the stuffing was flavorful (to me it tasted like shrimp, cilantro, and possibly some spinach, with a little hint of curry-like flavor).  The wrapping was just the right thickness, with lovely suppleness and slight translucence.  Probably the best dim sum dumpling I have ever had.

My guy loved the oversized, pan-fried pork potsticker as well.

Everything was priced very reasonably (we got a large box-full for under $10), fresh (you can see ladies in the back making dumplings in their kitchen non-stop), and tasty.  We tried most of the shrimp and pork items, and there were no misses in the bunch.

Expect to take your food to go -- as other reviewers noted, the whole place is practically one counter.

Food was so good and such a good value that we actually had a huge box-full for breakfast and returned later that morning for more.  We still dream about dumplings from this place from Southern CA (where we are based).  Better than sit-down dim sum, even from fancier places.
author: ReviewChick A.

description:
One of the best ideas I'd have to say is take out/fast food dim sum places, just like this spot in Chinatown.  I know there a bunch out here, but this one is one of the best I'd have to say.  

My friends and I came here to pick up some to go brunch before we went off to Napa and it was good.  Don't you hate it when you see so much food and you can't help yourself but get almost everything?

-Shrimp Dumplings - the bombest in chinatown I personally think, and as confirmed by my dad (Dim Sum Connosieur) and mom who purchases like a dozen a week of these
-Taro and Turnip Cake - so so, they dont' make it as good as others
-Chives Dumpling - like shrimp, its good
-Siu mai - pretty good
-Rice Noodles - although i'm not a big fan of the thick type, at least they're soft compared to other places.
author: Vincent K.

description: Exactly what the restuarant says, but it's cheap dim sum to go since there is one table and a few chairs. Although everything was in Chinese, the ladies here were very helpful and even was nice enough to let the kids sit while we ordered. Even showing us what was hidden in each steamer. We quickly devoured the plates of rice noodles with shrimp, shiu mai and ha cao and moved on to our next meal.
author: Anne T.

description:
It must be my luck this year, not the 1st 4 star rating on Yelp that has disappointed me.
I had BBQ Pork Bun, the filling was unbelievably little, someone probably fell asleep
while filling the bun.
Don't understand the 4 star rating of this one.
If you have to go, absolutely avoid BBQ Pork Bun.
author: chao-ying w.

description:
They are not lying when they called this place Delicious Dim Sum To Go. Exactly what it is. I think this place is better than most of the sit down dim sum restaurants in Chinatown. It's super cheap- $1.20 to get 3 pieces. They have deeelliicccious har gao. 

This place is perfect for taking a friend to get dim sum and walking around Chinatown, or go solo if you're feeling the craving. Not at all a place for a fancy sit down, it is really simple and essentially is exactly what it says - delicious dim sum TO GO.
author: Chelsea W.

description: Great, cheap Dim Sum! Our first trip to SF, we explored Chinatown, then got a big takeout box of dim sum here and ate it in a nearby park. I love San Francisco.
author: Katie J.

description: Based on the Yelp reviews, my fiance and I decided to try this restaurant.  My fiance is Chinese and she tried to ask the clerk a few questions about the menu and clerk was rude to her. We were hungry for good dim sum and ordered pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and sticky rice. We tried to be open minded about the food but were unimpressed. The food was not seasoned well and the dumplings were not tender. We recommend that you try another restaurant for dim sum when visiting Chinatown in San Francisco.
author: Mark P.

description: I ordered a variety of dumplings and was just ok. Not somewhere I would race back to. ...
author: vanessa e.

description:
I didn't read the reviews closely enough before taking my out-of-towners here for a Saturday dim sum brunch. 

This is a hole-in-the-wall take-out place with no prices, no labels, no descriptions. The lady was pretty abrupt and rude about me trying to figure out what to order even though there was no one else in there.

But that's all to be expected! The shrimp dumplings are awesome. I came in around 11:00am, and there was a decent selection left. The rest of the food is cheap and tasty, but greasy as heck.
author: Tammi H.

description: A hidden gem upstairs from the bustle of Grant street. Lots of locals dining here. Kung Pao is amazing!
author: M E.

description:
After a very late start on Sunday we headed to Golden Mountain Dim Sum on Broadway. Obviously we got there at 3:15p and discovered they were closed at 3!! So we turned to YELP for our next option for delicious dim sum and found DELICIOUS DIM SUM. The four stars are very much warranted. 

We had the shrimp and scallion dumplings (my favorite, almost tasted like creamed spinach with shrimp), pork buns (standard), shrimp dumpling(better than usual shumai), rice balls (these were gummy and unecessary, a little like risotto which was just heavy so skip it....

The quality of what we ordered was better and cheaper than at Golden Mountain. The only thing is you miss out on the frenetic cart experience. Here you order from the counter. There's one table in the back and we did sit there to eat it but if it was a nicer day I'd say get your food to go and sit in the park by the financial district or North Beach. 

The food is served medium warm so you can ask them to heat it up if you like it hot. Don't just settle for what;s out on top.. you can ask the women to move the baskets around to show you what else is on offer.
author: Jessica M.

description:
2 pork buns, 4 shrimp dumplings, 2 chive dumplings = $4.25 and a 4 hour nap.  The pieces here are giant and delicious; the ladies here are nice and speak English better than Dick Lee's.  

Yes there's MSG here before you preach your new fad diet to America A) the food here tastes good and B) A nation comprising a population of 35% deemed obese need not criticize the dietary construct of other nations.

Put the fork down fatty!
author: Nico M.

description:
Out of all the crazy Chinese restaurant names out there, this one actually lives up to its name.

Since last Sunday was so gorgeous, I decided to do a little exploring around Chinatown and Delicious Dim Sum was on my list of stops. As soon as I walked in, my heart sank after I seeing how little of a selection was displayed. BUT, don't be fooled! Beneath all the metal dim sum trays are several treasures waiting to be devoured. If you don't know Chinese (like me) be prepared to be assertive- ask a lot of "What are those?" questions because most of these dim sum gems are tucked away.

We had ordered a total of 12 goodies + an Orange Crush soda which totaled a mere 7 bucks! What a steal! And our whole purchase did the job- split between me and my bf's monstrous appetite, we were both full once we chowed down on everything. 

The Siu Mai is an absolute must-have. These are the best, no-skimp, meaty siu mais I've ever had. I later discovered my bff had bought me a few of these a year ago and even then I remember being just as impressed & satisfied by how tasty they were. The shrimp dumplings, pork buns, rice dumplings and chive dumplings were also big winners in my book. There's no need for soy sauce w/ any of these bad boys. They have enough flavor to stand on their own.

Grab some Delicious Dim Sum and park your butt in Chinatown's social courtyard (only a block away) to do some people watching while getting your dim sum fix. It makes for a great afternoon.
author: Tiffany M.

description: Really good Ha Gow and veg shrimp (I dont know the name in chinese cause their aint no english menu..!?)(whish they would jot down a few english characters on a page so I can speed up my ordering!).  I will be back even though the only way I can order is by pointing.  I get a crave for them and every time I go to San Franciso (about 2 times a year) I have to stop by for a fix.  Yummmmm!!!
author: Cory N.

description:
I just went to this place for the first time recently, and I love it!  I'm making the trek here from my office for lunch as often as I can :)

To echo what everyone else said, a) it's so cheap!!, and b) the har gao are really quite tasty.  Other comparable dim sum to go places I've been too, the har gao were falling apart, but here they are very good.  I'll be back for more soon!
author: David W.

description: Super-friendly service! We ordered, ate, and went back to order more because it was so good. The staff can speak English so don't be afraid to ask questions. Very inexpensive for what you get. Only downside is that there is only one table (seats 5).
author: Rod H.

description:
bought 6 shrimp dumplings. sign said $1.60 for 3. rung up $3.20 on register, but verbally told me it's $3.30.  Didn't ask why. Not coming back here since they are not honest.

They brought out fresh shrimp dumpling. what did they do? give me the last 6 cold shrimp dumpling. Another reason I will not return.
author: Patrick L.

description: After reading the great reviews on Yelp I was quite disappointed. Prices are pretty good, but quality of food was mediocre.  Life is too short to eat mediocre food. Lobak Go was barely browned, same for the Gao Choy Gow. Char Siew Bao was lots of Bao and very little Char Siew.
author: MT Y.

description:
Abso-fuc*ing-lutly amazing Dim Sum, hole in the wall place that is best for take out, we got lucky and managed the only table in the house, however i would recommend purchasing to go because it is just that damn good. It was by far the biggest and happiest surprise of the trip!

Eat way more than you think possible...your taste buds will thank you for it.
author: Luis P.

description: This place has great dim sum.  It doesn't look fancy, but it is fantastic.  Light, airy cha su bao, har gao tha isn't over cooked and rubbery but perfect.  Nice variety and always yummy.  It's worth the few extra blocks walk to go to this place.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I have to agree this place has tasty DIm Sum.  While visiting SF, I went here in the mid-afternoon on several different weekends .  They looked a little picked over by the time I usually went, but I still got to try a decent variety of stuff.  Each time I got their shrimp dumplings and pork buns -- they were both tasty, although they went very easy on the pork filling in the pork buns.  I also tried a few other miscellaneous things and they were all pretty good.

Anyway, the place is very no frills, and there's only a table or two inside, but it's great to stop by and grab a few pieces of dim sum for the road.
author: David H.

description: I think I lived 2 blocks from this place for 3.5 years before I ever tried it.  The lack of atmosphere and the fact that it's in the heart of Chinatown is probably why.  Thanks to my friend KP for making me try it late last year,  now I'm a fan.  In fact, I probably grab a bit of dim sum from here virtually every weekend.  It's a great quick meal and super cheap and filling for less than $3.  I love the pork and shrimp dumplings.  Maybe one day I'll experiment with something a bit more exotic, but for right now this is exotic enough.  They aren't particularly friendly, but again it's not the kind of place you go for service with a smile.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I guess I came at the wrong time ( late in the afternoon ) ... everything was quite cold and greasy.
It's definitely cheap but would have loved to try the food when it was fresher.  I will have to stop by again at a better time.
We had the following: 
Shrimp dumpling 
Chive & Shrimp Dumpling
BBQ pork buns
author: Lizete S.

description: I reserve the 5 stars for over the food. I am giving this 4 stars because for the price, it is fantastic. It is not the best dim sum I have ever had but you can get a pretty good sized pork bun for $.50. I ordered three and the lady asked for $1.50. WOW! As far as the food, it was as expected. Nothing over the top great but not bad either. I will be going back. It is a great place for lunch and a far cry from the financial district lunch prices.
author: Asia K.

description:
Come here for their shrimp dumplings and chives/shrimp dumplings. Been coming here for everyweekend now. Very delicious. 

Their chives dumplings tasted very fresh and not greasy like some other dim sum places. I like how the skin of the dumplings is nice and soft, not thick and full of flour. The shrimps in the dumplings are plump and juicy. It is full of flavor..trust me. It is almost like they mix in some scallops in there too. 

I have not tried any of their other items. But so far, these 2 items are my favorite in Chinatown to get Shrimp/Chives dumplings.
author: brad w.

description:
Is it the best Dim Sum in SF? 
Prolly not..

Is it good for it's price?
Absolutely

Do you want to sit down with some friends and have some tea and dim sum?
Too bad go somwhere else.

Do they  have cheap big ass siu mai and shrimp dumplings?
You bet.

Do you like dim sum in a bag??
You may proceed.

Do you need to speak Canto?
Depends. They lady i got actually could speak mandarin(thank  you jeebus. If i was one later i think i could have gotten the [insert sterotypical old asian lady]). Don't know about english though probably will rely on some pointing action.

I got 3 ha gaow and 3 siu mai with 1 cha su bao and 1 pillow of shrimp for less than 5 bucks. Pretty good compared to the yuppi loved Yang Suk. The ha gao and siu mai are pretty big compared to most places. the rice wrapping of the shrimp pillows were really thick. Feels like I'm eating soft  bread or something ... thick. The pork bun -- eh ok not like "omg it's SO overpowered, someone nerf this guy" but it's decent for the price.
author: Bryant Y.

description: SUPER CHEAP. Delicious pork buns. Fast service.
author: Megan L.

description: It is definitely cheap a good portions, but take it home and use your own soy sauce and hot sauce. It definitely has little to no seating. But it is fresh and pretty decent for take out. Definitely no Koi Palace, but quick and easy - that is if you can find parking in chinatown - haha...
author: Minh V.

description: We were on our way to get dim sum at Dick Lee's, but they were closed for a vacation.  Across the street we found Delicious Dim Sum and it's my new favorite dim sum spot.  Normally a restaurant that names themselves declicious or yummy is anything but.  The shrimp and the spinach/shrimp dumplings are really good and they put hefty, fresh skrimps in 'em.  $1 for 3 pieces.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Diana M.

description:
Stop the bus!!! The sweet rice buns!!! They are so yummy it's like a meal in a ball. The shrimp dumplings were absolutely mouth watering. Can't just eat one or two. But I must rave about their braised chicken feet!!! I hijack a bus for those! 

It's a hole in the wall place but the food is so good. They have a multitude of people in the kitchen. They must be a supplier of dim sum??
author: Winane L.

description:
I typically have a rule that automatically eliminates eating at any place that has the words "Great, Yum, or Delicious" in their names.  The only reason I know of this place and eat here is because of my dad who is a foodie and knows all the great, unknown places to eat no matter what city we are in.  I've been coming here for years. We usually buy huge boxes of dim sum to take home to eat because the seating here is minimal and cramped. The dim sum here is some of the best I've ever had, and I'm really picky about my dim sum. All great dim sum places are determined by their chicken feet. If they don't have good chicken feet then they shouldn't be making dim sum! The prices are ridiculously cheap.  

The service isn't great, but these people are overworked making the great food they serve so I totally understand and thank them for not being nazis. I don't think anything I've had here is bad so my advice is if it looks good to you, get it! I must also say that I don't know what soy sauce they use, but it is dynomite. If you are getting your order to go, make sure to get a cup to put that sauce in!
author: Jade L.

description: Watch Out!!  All four of us had the shrimp/cilantro and all four of us became violent sick after eating.  Place is dirty, could definitely use some cleaning up. If you visit, inspect the kitchen before ordering....
author: John S.

description:
My husband and I came in town for business this week. With knowing that San Francisco Bay area has the oldest Chinatown we opted for some really good Chinese food. After reading numerous reviews we decided to venture to Delicious Dim Sum. 

When we arrived at the restaurant, I must admit, I was a bit disappointed with the way the place looked. It really is not a restaurant that is intended for "a sit down service". Rather, it is more like a Chinese bakery meant for carry out, ONLY. To back up my mention, the restaurant had only ONE-UNO table with a jar of hot sauce and a bottle of soy sauce. Nonetheless, my husband and I decided to not give into the stereotype of the exterior of Delicious Dim Sum and gave their food a try. 

There was no serving dish; The lady who we ordered from piled our food on a plastic sheet, much like a plastic bag without an opening of a pocket. She gave us two paper trays & plastic forks to eat our dumplings with. With much anticipation of what we read on Yelp we sat down and dove into a variety of dim sum that we had ordered. EVERYTHING tasted DELICIOUS and neither of us was disappointed! The ingredients were fresh and the fillings of the dumplings were "solid", with no unnecessary starch. YUMMIE! We thought to ourselves. 

My husband and I were glad that we didn't go eat elsewhere because of the "look" of the restaurant. The food was really tasty but, if one is searching for the ambiance as well as service, forget about it, you won't find it here. However, if one is looking for good food at a really cheap price, Delicious Dim Sum is a great place to pick up food for carryout!  

One advice with this place: Do not prejudge. 

Recommendations: Shrimp Dumplings, Pork Shumai, Shrimp Dumplings with Cilantro, Shrimp Dumplings with Chives, Steam Pork Dumplings. 

Happy Eating! ^_^
author: Jenny T.

description: When I'm in San Francisco, I always make sure that I stop here for excellent, inexpensive dim sum.  There isn't really anywhere to sit, but we get our dim sum to go.  It is tasty and fresh and really, really inexpensive.  I shared a dim sum lunch for two for less than $7 and we were stuffed.  Where else can you do that?
author: Lisa B.

description:
Oh my God, I have died an gone to dim sum heaven!!  The shrimp dumplings are simply the BEST!!!!!!!!!  I've had many shrimp dumplings at other places and they don't even begin to compare; I could eat like 20 of those little suckers!!

Everything else is also very good, especially their pork bun.  The prices are super  cheap, which is great because that just means more food for me.  

The place is very small only a couple tables.  I always buy my dim sum and go to the park a few blocks away.

Go to delicious dim sum and get tons and tons of shrimp dumplings... I guarantee you, you won't be able to stop eating them!!
author: Michi R.

description:
In the chaos of San Francisco's Chinatown is a little take-out place specializing in dim sum. The place is really called "Delicious Dim Sum". There is only one table there so you might have to stand and eat; but its worth it. There are several buffet dim sum restaurants nearby - don't bother, go to this place instead. The quality is very good considering the price.

San Francisco's Chinatown is cramped and bustling, parking is hellish and businesses will charge you to use their bathrooms if you don't patronize them...however its a great place once you filter out the tourist traps.
author: vinh t.

description:
Their food is cheap and you get a lot of it. 
My recommendation if you are a white boy like me is to watch an asian guy order food and pay the amount and then you do the same. I believe I have been jacked there before because I don't understand chinese. However, the one time I saw an asian dude order hella food I copied him and they gave me the same thing for the same price (which was literally nothing). the quality of the shu mai and other stuff was great too. All the suburb/residential places are so expensive and not nearly this good!
author: Nir B.

description: The name of this place sure does describe the food.  It hit the spot as a togo driving in the car breakfast.  The pieces of dim sum are huuuge :D
author: David C.

description:
I am lucky enough to work near this place. I come here about once a week or whenever I forget to pack my lunch. You don't need to speak Chinese as the ladies there are friendly and will understand when you point at items.

Dumplings are really fantastic, better than some sit down places. A bit on the oily side but I don't mind it at all. You have to try really hard to spend $5 here. When I'm hungry, I get a bunch of dumplings and buns and it would almost come to $4.

Update April 13, 2009:
After going to Good Mong Kok, I had to knock one star from Delicious Dim Sum. It's a bit too oily for my taste. Still a damn good place for dim sum.
author: Khoi N.

description: The dim sum was fresh and warm, tasty, and super cheap! Only drawback is that this is a to-go place. I was missing the experience of anticipating the push carts and what goodies each would bring.
author: Grace L.

description: The food was pretty good.  The service was terrible.  We ordered a dish that never arrived.  We place a second order of an item.  The waiter told the guy carrying the dim sum to give us one twice, but we never got it.  We ended up cancelling the two orders and paying our bill.  I would probably have given this place four star if the service had been better.
author: Daris B.

description: I think the Hargow is ok at this place.
author: Jim J.

description: I went to this place based on the high number of stars from other yelpers and I was OH so disappointed... the siu mai was chewy, the har gow salty, and the ta tsu bow (steam pork buns) were lacking meat... shame as this place is smacked in the middle of china town in SF
author: Alex B.

description: If I was only to rate the hai gow (shrimp dumplings) NO way would anyone give it less then 5 stars.  When Im in SF its a MANDATORY stop.  No where else will you have Hai Gow as good as this place, I promise you! Its also cheap.  I also buy them frozen to bring them back home to steam, taste just as good!
