The other dim sum is not bad, but dont bother with it as this place is known for its Hai Gow.  One random thing to mention is they are closed on Wednesday!  Why out of all days?  Maybe I was just upset as I drove there on a Wednesday super excited and it was closed and I tried 4 other dim sum places Hai Gow and NOTHING was even close.  Went home empty handed and dissappointed.
author: Hien T.

description: Cheap dim sum, great hours, only a 7-10min walk from my place. My go-to...to-go dim sum spot.
author: Raniel C.

description: Delicious it is! The har gow rocks! Highly recommended!
author: Andrew F.

description: We yelped this place before we went in.  So glad we did because the reviews were right on.  It's this little hole in the wall place but they were fast!  We ordered $8 worth of food and there was a lot to share.  Only bad thing is there's no room to sit and eat. Good thing we were near our hotel so we ate in our room.  It's fast service,  cheap, big portions and yummy!  Can't go wrong here!
author: Trang N.

description:
I came back here under strict advisement from my father. The sound box they have is really funny, but the food is delicious again!

It is cheap, and pretty standard food Cantonese-style cuisines. As an ABC, it is an ease to order. Dim sum is a dwindling competition in Chinatown now-a-days, especially ones that don't get you sick.
author: Michael C.

description:
When the woman behind the counter developed a crush on me some years ago it was the beginning of true love - sadly only for this dim sum standup. All the dim sum favorites you've come to love and expect from the places with the carts without the fuss. 

Har goa, sui mai, char sil bao - the basics - are beyond approach and fun gao and an assortment of crescent shaped wonders are there, as are taro cakes, blood sausages, buns and steamed delights. 

The trick with this place is to ask for what you like - the trays are stacked so you may not see all the treasures. For me, an assortment and a walk down to Portsmouth makes the day.
author: sketch f.

description:
Just as advertised.... great shrimp dumplings, steamed pork bun, friendly staff, hidden gems not seen from outside the restaurant and, yes, numerous chinese women cutting in front of me every moment I took my eye off them.

Go give it a try.
author: Yum N.

description: Pretty good dim sum.  Ordered four items for about 6 bucks.  Pretty good for the price.   Would recommend. Only down side is there's no place to sit.  Other than that, it's good.  Definitely coming back .
author: RJ O.

description: Went for a run this morning that ended a couple of blocks from Chinatown.  The 6 miles made me hungry, so I wandered up the hill to grab some dim sum. This place was empty but smelled good, so I went in.  Ordered 3 har gau, 2 bao, and a taro cake, all for 3 bucks.  The shrimp dumplings were the star, huge and delicious.  The bao were good, though could have used a bit more meat.  Good flavor though. I had never had the taro cake before, but liked it, not too greasy, which tends to happen  with its cousin the turnip cake.
author: Brian G.

description:
I came to SF on a mini vacation and wanted to get some good dim sum in Chinatown without spending too much time in a seafood restaurant waiting for a table.  

I went to Dick Lee the day before and was disappointed by the food quality.  The dim sum here at delicious is very close to a big seafood restaurant.  The skin on all types of dumplings were thin and the food was good.  Ordered a big assortment of hargow, shark fin dumpling, beef, siu mai etc and chinese carrot cake for about $10 for 2 people and we had left overs.  Good deal and good food.  Only thing is they should consider  putting up an english menu for the ones that doesn't speak or read chinese.
author: j t.

description:
OH
MY
GOD. 
I was staying in Palo Alto for two months and constantly found myself looking for excuses to go to SF just to eat here. I literally lay in bed at night thinking of this place's dumplings. Just one of their shrimp dumplings is worth the two hours on the train. There's only one plastic table (which is pretty dirty) and 4 plastic chairs to sit at. The ladies don't speak English besides numbers, "plastic bag", "fork and knife", "sauces", "pork", "shrimp", "green", and the like. But you can get by well enough just pointing. There's not really any good place to sit and eat in the surrounding area, as the closest park is pretty seedy and the rest of Chinatown is too busy to cop a squat in. The food is as authentic Chinese as you'll ever find, though. And honestly, pop one of those shrimp dumplings into your mouth and you'd have visions of Heaven even sitting in San Quentin.
God speed me back to Frisco...
author: Jes S.

description:
I found everything but the pork buns super greasy!  I don't mind greasy from time to time but not on my dim sum!  The pork dumplings were cartilagey and cartilagey is definitely not my thing!  I wanted to like this place so much!  
Although it was super cheap I won't be back.  It was just way too greasy.
author: Sarah T.

description: I don't care for anything else in this place except their SEEN HA FUN GWOR... shrimp, chives and cilantro dumpling. OMG its sooo freaking GOOD! Everytime I come, i swoop up at least 3 orders just for myself! Everything else here is so- so.
author: A L.

description:
ever wonder where to go in chinatown for dim sum? do you venture into a tourist trap? do you try your luck at a hole in the wall? (trust me, i have been asking myself this for all 6 years that i've been living here)

well, here is your answer.  GO TO DELICIOUS DIM SUM!

it is, by far, the finest "cheap" dim sum that i've had in chinatown. soft, delicate char siew bao's, well-seasoned hao gao and siu mai's, and refined grounds of pork and sausage in their lo mai gai. they even had lots of veggie dumplings, something i always opt for to try and get my greens at dim sum. 

some basic info - there is only one server who speaks english. there is not really anywhere to sit. there are loads of options hiding under those steamers, so ask and point! 

and all that, for a buck or two! love.
author: Diana L.

description: It was good. Not great. But definitely cheap and filling. Whatever dumplings they had with chicken and peanuts was delicious.
author: Christine H.

description: This place is good. Just not as amazing as I was expecting. I got 5 different types, including pork and bean, shrimp, and potsticker. They were all really good, but I don't think I'll be dreaming about them. And they were a little greasier than I would have liked. But then again, I'm no expert on dim sum.
author: R N.

description: $1 for 2 steamed buns.  Doesnt matter how they taste for that price.
author: Light Bulb J.

description: I go to this place to get dim sum and it is very cheap and great food. This is the best dim sum place in China Town in my opinion.
author: Origami Z.

description: Tried Delicious Dim Sum based on its yelp reviews and was quite happy to have done so.  Being from LA, I expected to find a large, crowded restaurant with carts rolling by my table - so the small, take out counter with only one table initially threw me off.  Once we made our selections, though, I couldn't have been happier.  Two of us got a large plate of shu mai, char siu, and red bean sesame rolls and 2 bottles of water for $14.  Everything was quite tasty and I left full.  If you want a cheap, delicious, authentic-ish Chinatown dim sum experience, I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Derik L.

description: This place is the quintessential hole in the wall that you want to keep to yourself. As others have said the food is good the prices cheap. We went mid day on a Saturday and it was busy. Be aware there isn't "seating" per se, but there is one or two tables and about 6  seats so grab and go is the keyword here. We managed to grab a couple of chairs and eat, it's best probably to just skip that part and take it with you.. just saying.
author: Sean F.

description: Love their har gaos! No filler (or at least not that much), shrimpy goodness. The mantou is pretty good too!
author: Charlotte T.

description: 2nd time coming here and everything was sub-par. super salty dim sum...
author: Julie Z.

description: Great and cheap, what more can you ask for!! We found the review in Yelp and decided to go in. The place is very simple but the food was delicious. We had the shrimp, shrimp and vegetable dumplings and a pork dumpling. All good but did get cold quickly. The lady did not speak much english but a customer was very helpful. Would visit again!!! It is all take out.
author: Frydel S.

description: Well, I bought some Dim Sum in the morning, if you drive a car, it's impossible to find a parking. I can not deny to say Shu mai + Har Gaw are delicious. But you have to know something , a seller DON'T care about you that much. If you can't speak Chinese. They don't care or pay any attention to your order. When my girlfriend and I try to asking what is that thing inside the streamer, they not answer. We have to guess and order the things that we know. Furthermore, pork bun is a little bit stuff.
author: Prapakorn D.

description: Hands down the best take out dim sum place in the city at a fraction of the price you'd pay at the restaurants down the street.  They have a wide variety to choose from, although I always default to the har gow, siu mai, and the one with the chives.  Delicious!  I've also gotten their sweet rice, which I'll throw in the freezer to have ready for any night I don't feel like cooking dinner, and that is very good as well.  The ladies here are friendly enough, and they'll smile and laugh at me when I forget what something is called and resort to pointing instead.
author: Irene W.

description: Really cheap! I had a pork bun which was very tasty. Take out only. Near the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory, where you can get free samples of hot fortune cookies.
author: Meghan B.

description: More wonderful food than you can handle, instantly, to go, for less than half the price you'd expect. A block and a half from Portsmouth Square. A five-minute walk from my house. Golden.
author: JR H.

description: Just as the name says it is DELICIOUS; I have been coming here for over 10 years.  The place is very inexpensive.  I can get lunch and dinner here for less than $10.  I just point and ask for the dim sum because their English is not very good.  I rarely get my Dim Sum anywhere else because nowhere else can compare to Delicious Dim Sum.
author: anita b.

description: Was able to grab breakfast while on quick business trip --- some of the best dim sum  - period. So much for so little. Shrimp and Cilantro yum.
author: N G.

description: I've been trying out all the neighborhood dim sum joints, and this one seems to have the best har gao (shrimp) and shrimps/chives dumplings.  The har gao pieces are huge!  The shanghai dumplings are pretty tasty though not so soupy.  The char siu baos are pretty good too, though i suspect there are better places for that.  (Still looking . . . )  Also, this place is super cheap - you could fill the stomach's of 3-4 hungry people for about $10.  Nice!
author: Amy C.

description: I have been here countless times.  It's all about the food, though; you will be happy to get your food and run outta there.  Like any dim-sum place-- take a peek inside first.  If there's no one in there but staff, you are too late for the fresh stuff.  Recommended: shrimp dumplings with chives and the BEST fluffy steamed pork buns in the neighborhood.
author: Annabell S.

description: this place looks ghetto from the outside, and walking inside doesn't get much better. However,  the hai gow (shrimp dumplings) are the best! They sell them frozen in large quantities (for bring home to eat later) and also fresh in small plates to eat now. Its really really good!
author: Anthony L.

description: So I went to this place after my horrid experience at New Fortune Dim Sum, (well way after) and bought a lor mai bow, and some lor bak goh.  This is one of the few places that I know of that sells lor mai bow still.  Everyone else sells lor mai guen, which is sweet rice wrapped in white bread, totally not the same.  Well, it's not the best, but it's not the worse.  I'd still come here to buy it.  Also, the lor bak goh was good too.  I definitely think that this place is better than New Fortune.  I recommend this place to all people.
author: Philip L.

description:
I went at noon on a Friday and there was no line.  I tried their steamed BBQ pork bun & shrimp/chive dumpling.

BBQ pork bun: 
Had more bread than meat.  The bread had a couple of hard lumps and an odd texture.   Two stars.

Shrimp/chive dumpling:
Nice chive flavor and the skin is thin which is how the high end restaurants make it.  Four stars.
author: D C.

description: We totally went out of our way to check this place out and couldn't even eat there. Apparently every single item has some pork in it, and since we don't eat pork, we were out of luck.
author: Humaira M.

description: I love their sausage buns! Also their chicken feet is really good!!
author: Janet Z.

description: Not as delicious this time around, but this still makes for one hell of a breakfast.  It isn't cool, though, when there are bits of shell in your shrimp dumpling.
author: Nathan W.

description: Best Ha Gow in the city! The warm, slightly seasoned shrimp...the perfect texture of their soft, thin, chewy wrapper....I'd go earlier in the day rather than later, because by 4ish they're sold out of this half the time I go here! Everything else is pretty standard. I like their Guw Choy Gow too...pan-fried dumpling with chives. The ha gow is the only standout though. I'm pretty sure I could easily grub on 10 of those babies and enjoy the experience thoroughly!
author: Emily L.

description: After reading the following reviews, I look forward to eat here.  I'll be up in Frisco on the 15th to check it out. I'm very picky with my DIM SUMS.  Till then...?
author: Saksit S.

description: I wholeheartedly recommend the shrimp har gao, and half-heartedly recommend everything else. Steamed pork buns were pretty yummy, but the potstickers were venturing into dangerous territory. But, for the amazing price, the har gao makes up for all of it and then some.  Oh yeah, and it's only take-out.
author: Donald R.

description: This place is great for take out dim sum. 3 pieces for $1.40. The haw gaw is very firm and fresh tasting. A lot of places use frozen shrimp which makes the shrimp mushy. This place is great for your office parties. The only problem is that you have to pick it up yourself. If you like Chines tamales  (joong) they are $2.00 each. They have 2 different ones. Peanut or beans. I prefer the one with beans. There is a lot of meat and egg. They are also great to freeze for emergency food hen you are just to tire to go out to eat.
author: Steve w.

description: Great Dim Sum for a reasonable price. That's what you'll find at Delicious Dim Sum. The har gao (shrimp dumpling) and the chinese chive and shrimp dumpling are excellent. Only problem is if you're not walking, then finding parking is a pain (like all of san francisco). We did the park illegally, jump in and buy all we can, and run. There is no dining in unless you call the little table at the back of the shop dining in...
author: Michael D.

description:
When they are freshy fresh the shrimp dumplings ("hog-ow"), shrimp with with greens ("fun-go"), pork buns and pot stickers are very good and cheap!!!!
Closed on Wed
author: Ry G.

description: I have only tried the har gows before. They're good. Looking through the window doesn't make the food look too appetizing.
author: Katherine C.

description:
I've eaten a lot of dim sum in my day (my girlfriend is Chinese), and I'm pretty picky about the stuff despite the fact I still can't pronounce anything. This place stands out as one of the top two dim sum places I've ever eaten at, and definitely the best at this price. My family and I ordered so much food (for five people) for less than twenty dollars.

I'm giving it four stars because, although the food was excellent and cheap, the place wasn't the cleanest in the world, and it turned me and my family off a little bit.

Definitely stop by here if you have the chance. Make sure to keep an eye out; it's basically a whole in the wall.
author: Jay D.

description: I think I like it... and yet another vote for the shrimp dumplings. Yum!
author: Anita B.

description: This place is pretty authentic and tasty.  The shrimp dumplings were amazing.  Flavorful, huge pieces of shrimp.  The taro cake had a good consistency and nice chunks of pork.  The chive dumplings were mouthwatering.  Overall a great experience for a to-go dim sum place.  Plus as people have mentioned it is SO CHEAP.  I still think the flavors and taste are excellent.  However, you get to the end and you pay $13 for a huge meal that 2 people could barely finish.  That is icing on the cake...
author: M K.

description: I went here because of all the great yelp reviews and pictures, but was highly disappointed!! Maybe I went at the wrong time or day, but the dim sum was COLD, NO LONGER FRESH, and poorly contained for take-out. I see the yelp pictures of the buns and dumplings in plastic containers, but then WHY did my friends and I receive our dim sum wrapped in cling wrap, and tossed in a plastic bag without a fork or anything to eat it with. I ordered turnip cake, which was cold and no oyster sauce available for added taste. It's not that hard to provide some condiments on the side or have it there for request -- I did see the yelp picture with soy sauce on the side of dumplings/buns. And I would recommend the owner to cover the dim sum she already prepared, so it doesn't get cold so easily. It would help keep it WARM & FRESH, you know, how normal people would like their food. And hard to know the prices unless you can read chinese, maybe it would help business to add english translation? Luckily we could speak cantonese to the owner.
author: Betty B.

description:
This place was definitely cheap, and a good place to stop by and pick up some quick dim sum. However,  the quality is iffy. The meat inside the chee cheong fun (the rolled up flat rice noodles) wasn't cooked through. I also don't like how they have piles of the stuff left out and the noodle part gets dry. Gotta keep that stuff steamed!

I probably have to sample all their different types of dim sum to give it a fair review though...
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
wanna thank yelp for recommending this place to me... the food taste fresh and i like it... just like how it was back home... just a bit bigger... haha.. 
even had a good conversation with the young ladies there...
i wanna sit down to enjoy my food but it seems that the staff are using it.. i went to the park down the street instead.. very good experience!
author: Ken L.

description:
I've been to many dim sum places all over the city.  Each place have this own distinct food items.  This place is considerably cheap and good.  I constantly go back over and over again.
Recommend items:
*Shrimp & Chive (Seen Ha Fun Gor):  This is the ONLY place in chinatown where they sell these!...They're DELICIOUS.
*Chicken wrapped in Lotus Leave(Lor Mai Gai):  Eventhough they're called "Chicken"..they actually use minced pork.  It still taste better than A LOT of other places...Beware, they sellout by 4pm everyday.
author: Gary Y.

description: easy to stop in for a chive dumpling or bbq bun.  inexpensive
author: Rob C.

description: This is one of the better to-go dim sum places in Chinatown . All of their dim sum is pretty darn good ! I still think that the turnip cake at Ma's is better though . This place also has Shanghai steamed dumplings sometimes which is cool because not much to-go dim sum places have it . Their Shanghai steamed dumplings are pretty good too !
author: Eileen L.

description:
tried it today and it's pretty good.  def cured my dim sum craving.  

ha gow (shrimp dumpling) and siu mai (pork dumpling) were tasty and freshly made.  Chive and shrimp dumpling was also very delicious.  what stands out was how "ungreasy" the food was.  most of the time after eating "take out" dim sum I need to have a pot of tea to cut back all the grease...but not here.
author: Dustin S.

description: Very small, with limited options and no English menu afaict. But very cheap, with tasty shrimp dumplings, OK veggie dumpling (contained cilantro, unfortunately for me), and a decent pork bun with lots of filling. Not much more than that except some baked goods.
author: Mike W.

description: CHIKEN BANS is really worth trying. In addition to delicious chiken, there are Pork Sausage and Shiitake Mashroom. I LOVE it!
author: Takako O.

description:
I love their dumplings--all of them.  I don't always know what's in them, but I've never had one I didn't like.  

For buns, I think Yong Kee (which about half a block down on the same side of the street) is supposed to be better.  Not a big bun person though, so I climb the extra 50 yards up Jackson to go here.
author: Ann T.

description: Take out only.  Bring a translator since signs are in Chinese and server(counter person) English is very limited.\But a great buy for the price versus other dim sum places.
author: William R.

description: The food here is extremely cheap and delicious. It tastes just as good as food you would actually find in Hong Kong. A good meal here for two people usually costs around $10 total. The more popular siu-mai, ha-gow, and other dishes are roughly about $1.40 for 3 pieces.
author: Andrew T.

description: delicious dim sum is a great dim sum take out place...  they're not as busy as the dim sum take out places off stockton, but that doesn't mean their food isn't good...  they have really good har kao (shrimp dumplings), sui my (pork dumplings), beef crepe, shrimp crepe, and chicken feet...  make sure you tell the ladies working there everything you want to order right off the bat (i.e. don't piece meal your order), so they can get the right container or bag for your order...  otherwise they get all pissed at you...  for non-chinese patrons, the women who work here speak sufficient english...  price wise, it's pretty affordable...  h-100...
author: Herb F.

description:
my boyfriend and i walked from our hotel (the st. francis westin) to this location and it was so worth the walk. (about 13 minutes away from the hotel) and cutting through the tunnel off of sutter helped lessen the anticipation. i have to say, this was one of the best eats, as well as the cheapest buys during our stay. $6 total for 4 shrimp dumplings, 2 pork buns, 4 pork dumplings, 1 sesame ball, 1 fried dumpling, and 1 fried shrimp and shallot roll. i have a feeling i'm missing something but i mean, come on! so much food for such a low price. not to mention how yummy and good quality everything was. it might be a bit intimidating for people who are trying dim sum for the first time ( i.e., the old asian ladies repeatingly saying hello to you until you order) but you can always do the point and say how many you would like to order method, and everything is good so you can't really go wrong with that. while you're in nob hill, you can also shop around and pick up some really neat asian trinkets. 

OH and they open super early too, so it's great for a quick breakfast. my boyfriend and i took it to go and ate it in union square park. good times. :]
author: Arlene A.

description: I love this place!  It is so inexpensive and the dim sum is great.  Everything is good, but the siu mai is only okay.  I would stick with the har gow, chive dumplings, and the other steamed dumplings.  My family's association is just a block away, so I always stop here whenever I'm in the area.  I wished they had full sit down dim sum service!
author: Marianne W.

description: I actually give this place 3.5 stars based on the price and quality, but 3 stars for quality only. Their Har-gow is good, but the wrapper is little bit too thick. Their pork shu-mai is ok. Price is incredibly cheap. Only 50 cents each. Overall this place is not bad. It's better than many of the cheap dim sum in Chinatown.
author: Elle S.

description: great prices here!  if you're looking for a cheap very decent tasting place for dim sum when in chinatown, this is your place.  no seating, but you all know that's why they charge the low price for their food.  opens at 7am, so you can catch a dim sum bfast before heading to your downtown office.
author: Eric C.

description: Screw Yank Sing and their little carts and expensive prices.  This place is fresh, delicious, and cheap.  Each piece is about 50 cents.  Walking there and bring back to your apt is ideal since parking is horrendous and driving in chinatown is a big clusterf*ck.  I suppose you can eat there if you ask the old man that sits at the one table there everyday (I think) if it's ok to share a table.
author: LT B.
